Will be transferred to family Cricetidae.

Pending revisionary work, Oryzomys saturatior has been provisionally reassigned to the new genus Handleyomys (Weksler et al. 2006). This species is a sister group to H. chapmani (Almendra et al. 2014).
This species is monotypic (Gómez-Laverde et al. 2015).
Pending revisionary work, Oryzomys melanotis has been provisionally reassigned to the new genus Handleyomys (Weksler et al. 2006).

Pending revisionary work, Oryzomys chapmani has been provisionally reassigned to the new genus Handleyomys (Weksler et al. 2006). Based on molecular phylogeny, this species consists of 2 nonsister lineages (Almendra et al. 2014).
Oryzomys is a generic synonym (Weksler et al. 2006). Synonyms for this species include Oryzomys emmonsae (Musser, Carleton, Brothers and Gardner 1998). This is a monotypic species (Percequillo 2015).
Oryzomys is a generic synonym (Weksler et al. 2006).
This may be a species complex of lenguarum and probably includes some synonyms which are valid species.
Two subspecies are recognized: Necromys obscurus scaligarium and N. o. obscurus
Described as a species of Akodon but referred to a subspecies of Zygodontomys brevicauda by Hershkovitz (1962). Monotypic species (Pardiñas et al. 2015).
Oryzomys is a generic synonym of Mindomys (Weksler et al. 2006).
Synonyms of this species include Phyllotis garleppi. It is a monotypic species (Salazar-Bravo 2015).
The species authority is not Hodgson, 1849, as is entrenched in the literature (see Musser and Carleton 2005).
Neodon irene is sometimes referred to as a synonym of N. sikimensis (Smith and Xie 2008).
Sometimes included as a subspecies of Neodon irene, with which it is morphologically similar (Smith and Xie 2008). Allen (1940) indicated that this form may only be a southern subspecies of N. irene.

This species formerly was recognized as a subspecies of D. groenlandicus. It has distinctive pelage and craniodental characteristics, and apparently uniquely among Dicrostonyx, it lacks specialized nival pelage and foreclaws (see Musser and Carleton in Wilson and Reeder 2005).

Dicrostonyx taxonomy is complex and not well resolved. The complex was regarded as part a single circumpolar species, D. torquatus, until the 1970s when karyological and breeding studies indicated the possible existence of a superspecies complex among North American Dicrostonyx (Rausch and Rausch 1972; Rausch 1977; see also Krohne 1982). Former subspecies occurring in western Canada and Alaska were recognized as separate species based mainly on karyotypes (Rausch and Rausch 1972; Rausch 1977; Krohne 1982; Honacki et al. 1982; Jones et al. 1986, 1992). Musser and Carleton (in Wilson and Reeder 2005) reviewed these and subsequent studies and provisionally recognized eight Dicrostonyx species, six of which (groenlandicus, hudsonius, nelsoni, nunatakensis, richardsoni, and unalascensis) occur in North America; this is the taxonomy adopted here. Baker et al. (2003) recognized D. exsul, D. kilangmiutak, and D. rubricatus as species, but Musser and Carleton recognized exsul as a synonym of D. nelsoni, and kilangmiutak and rubricatus were treated as synonyms of D. groenlandicus.

This species was previously recognized as a subspecies of D. groenlandicus. Dicrostonyx taxonomy is complex and not well resolved. The complex was regarded as part a single circumpolar species, D. torquatus, until the 1970s when karyological and breeding studies indicated the possible existence of a superspecies complex among North American Dicrostonyx (Rausch and Rausch 1972, Rausch 1977, see also Krohne, 1982). Former subspecies occurring in western Canada and Alaska were recognized as separate species based mainly on karyotypes (Rausch and Rausch 1972; Rausch 1977; Krohne 1982; Honacki et al. 1982; Jones et al. 1986, 1992). Musser and Carleton (in Wilson and Reeder 2005) reviewed these and subsequent studies and recognized eight Dicrostonyx species, six of which (groenlandicus, hudsonius, nelsoni, nunatakensis, richardsoni, and unalascensis) occur in North America; this is the taxonomy adopted here. Baker et al. (2003) recognized D. exsul, D. kilangmiutak, and D. rubricatus as species, but Musser and Carleton recognized exsul as a synonym of D. nelsoni, and kilangmiutak and rubricatus were treated as synonyms of D. groenlandicus.

This species was previously recognized as a subspecies of D. groenlandicus. Dicrostonyx taxonomy is complex and not well resolved. The complex was regarded as part a single circumpolar species, D. torquatus, until the 1970s when karyological and breeding studies indicated the possible existence of a superspecies complex among North American Dicrostonyx (Rausch and Rausch, 1972; Rausch, 1977; see also Krohne, 1982). Former subspecies occurring in western Canada and Alaska were recognized as separate species based mainly on karyotypes (Rausch and Rausch, 1972; Rausch, 1977; Krohne, 1982; Honacki et al., 1982; Jones et al., 1986, 1992). Musser and Carleton (in Wilson and Reeder 2005) reviewed these and subsequent studies and recognized eight Dicrostonyx species, six of which (groenlandicus, hudsonius, nelsoni, nunatakensis, richardsoni, and unalascensis) occur in North America; this is the taxonomy adopted here. Baker et al. (2003) recognized D. exsul, D. kilangmiutak, and D. rubricatus as species, but Musser and Carleton recognized exsul as a synonym of D. nelsoni, and kilangmiutak and rubricatus were treated as synonyms of D. groenlandicus.
Following Weksler et al. (2006) Oryzomys devius has been reassigned to the new genus Nephelomys.
Oryzomys is a generic synonym (Weksler et al. 2006). This species was previously considered as a synonym of O. albigularis (e.g., Musser and Carleton 1993).
Oryzomys is a generic synonym (Weksler et al. 2006).

Oryzomys is a generic synonym (Weksler et al. 2006). There are some specimens from the Uribante (Tachira) region with a karyology different and may represent a different species (Aguilera et al. 2002).
Oryzomys is a generic synonym (Weksler et al. 2006).
Oryzomys is a generic synonym (Weksler et al. 2006).
Following Weksler et al. (2006) Oryzomys talamancae has been reassigned to the new genus Transandinomys.
Following Weksler et al. (2006) Oryzomys bolivaris has been reassigned to the new genus Transandinomys.
Oryzomys is a generic synonym (Weksler et al. 2006). This is likely a species complex (M. Weksler pers. comm.). This is a monotypic species (Percequillo 2015).

Although named as a genus and recognized early as such (Cabrera 1961, Gyldenstolpe 1932, Pearson 1958), Paralomys was later submerged as a subgenus of Calomys (Ellerman 1941) or as a subgenus or full synonym of Phyllotis (Hershkovitz 1962, Osgood 1947, Pearson and Patton 1976). Uncertainty over its monophyletic union with those species and taxonomic rank has been revived by broad phylogenetic studies of morphological characters that suggest the distant relationship of gerbillus and amicus to other Phyllotis (Braun 1993, Steppan 1995). Braun (1993) elevated Paralomys to its former generic status, but Steppan (1995) reservedly maintained it as a synonym for want of strongly supported cladistic structure and demonstrable monophyly of gerbillus-amicus in the various trees generated (also see Steppan and Sullivan 2000). Musser and Carleton (2005) include this species in the Paralomys genus; however, some researchers suggest that it should be Phyllotis (Steppan and Ramirez 2015).
The genus need taxonomic revision; this taxa could be two species.
Will be transferred to family Cricetidae.
This rodent was formally considered to be a synonym of D. dorsalis, it was recognized as a species in 1995.
Will be transferred to family Cricetidae.
his species is monotypic (Paresque and Hanson 2015). Previously it has been considered synonymous with Oligoryzomys transitorious.

This species was originally diagnosed as a subspecies of C. venustus and continued to be recognized as such (Cabrera 1961) until Hershkovitz (1962) placed both in synonymy with C. callosus callosus. Specific status of callidus affirmed by Corti et al. (1987), who summarized its distribution, karyotypic traits, and morphometric discrimination; banded chromosomal comparisons with C. venustus and systematic commentary provided by Vitullo et al. (1990).

C. fecundus is the appropriate name for populations of Calomys in the yungas of Chuquisaca, Tarija, and Southern Santa Cruz. C. boliviae is available for specimens from the yungas of La Paz. However, if these two latter forms are found to represent one species then the name C. boliviae should be used for the yungas Calomys (Salazar-Bravo et al. 2003). Argentinian populations could belong to fecundus, but the distinction between boliviae and fecundus is not clear.

Musser and Carleton (2005) include this species as a junior synonym of C. boliviae; however, C. fecundus is the appropriate name for populations of Calomys in the yungas of Chuquisaca, Tarija, and Southern Santa Cruz. C. boliviae is available for specimens from the yungas of La Paz. If further studies latter these two forms are found to represent one species then the name C. boliviae should be used for the yungas Calomys (Salazar-Bravo et al. 2003).

Earlier retained as a species as described (Cabrera 1961, Gyldenstolpe, 1932), but swept under Hershkovitz’s (1962) broad concept of callosus and provisionally retained as such by Musser and Carleton (1993). Olds (1988, also Anderson 1997) recognized C. venustus as separate from C. callosus proper, and defined it broadly to include boliviae and fecundus in Bolivia and NW Argentina (also see account of C. boliviae); others have more narrowly applied the name to the C Argentinian populations (e.g., Salazar-Bravo et al. 2001, 2002a; Vitullo et al. 1990) as distinct from fecundus (here = C. boliviae). Banded chromosomal comparisons with C. callidus provided by Vitullo et al. (1990), who considered the two, along with fecundus (here = C. boliviae) to form a closely related group, as did Espinosa et al. (1997). Salazar-Bravo et al. (2002a) similarly recognized a callosus venustus clade, also embracing callidus and fecundus as species, although the taxa represented in these studies are not entirely equivalent.

Oryzomys is a generic synonym (Weksler et al. 2006). Musser and Carleton (1993) note that this taxon has two subspecies: Aegialomys galapagoensis bauri which occurs on Santa Fe Island (Barrington) and A. g. galapagoensis which occurred on San Cristobal Island (Chatham) and which is now said to be extinct (Dowler et al. 2000). Patton and Hafner (1983) demonstrated that the two populations are conspecific.

This species has sometimes been included in the genus Maresomys. Two subspecies are recognized.
This species formerly was included in Akodon (B. Patterson pers. comm). Taxanomical name change from Abrothrix illuteus to Abrothrix illutea.

Formerly included in Muridae (Musser and Carleton 2005).

Mann (1978) relegated this to a subspecies of A. longipilis, but others have affirmed its specific status (Osgood 1943; Yañez et al. 1978). Previously had been associated with Microxus (Gyldenstolpe 1932) but later allocated to subgenus Abrothrix of Akodon (Osgood 1943, Reig 1987). Muñoz Pedreros (2000) has maintained the species with Akodon.

Formerly this species was placed in the Muridae family. It may be conspecific with Abrothrix longipilis, but this has not yet been formally documented (Pearson 1995, Pine et al. 1979, Patterson et al. 1989). It has been reported as hybridizing with A. longipilis so the validity of the species should be reviewed (G. D'elia pers. comm). D'Elía et al. (2015) demonstrated that A. sanborni included at least two species. Populations from northern Chiloé and adjoining areas in southern Chile were referred to as a new species, described as A. manni.

Systematists have debated synonymy between viewed olivaceus and xanthorhinus. Based on apparent morphological and ecological separation in local settings, some systematists consider them distinct (Osgood 1943, Patterson et al. 1984, Pearson 1995) whereas others consider olivaceus as a polytypic species, also including southern xanthorhinus, based on broader regional trends of morphological and morphometric variation (Mann 1978, Yañez et al. 1978). Recent work with transects between where Valdivian rainforest (olivaceus morphotype) transitions into Patagonian steppe (xanthorhinus morphotype) have given evidence of demic intergradation, which strongly supports the synonymy argument (Smith et al. 2001, Pearson and Smith 1999). This assessment includes the species known as A. llanoi, A. mansoensis, A. xanthorhinus, A. hershkovitzi and A. markhami.
This is a species complex, and the relationship of this species with other Abrothrix needs further taxonomic research and revision (H. Zeballos, N. Bernal and B. Patterson pers. comm.).
Oryzomys is a generic synonym (Weksler et al. 2006). This is a monotypic species (Percequillo 2015).
Oryzomys is a generic synonym (Weksler et al. 2006). This species is monotypic (Percequillo 2015).
Oryzomys is a generic synonym (Weksler et al. 2006).
Oryzomys is a generic synonym (Weksler et al. 2006).

Deltamys has been considered a subgenus of Akodon (Ellerman 1940, Cabrera 1961) and alternatively as a genus (Gyldenstolpe 1932, Massoia 1980). Genus status was determined based on morphological (Bianchini and Delupi 1994, Gonzalez and Massoia 1995) and genetic (Smith and Patton 1999) characteristics. Previous Red List assessment conducted as Akodon kempi.
Will be transferred to family Cricetidae.
Thalpomys lasiotis type specimen belongs to the genus Bolomys, the correct name for this species should be T. reinhardti (Bonvicino and Marinho-Filho pers. comm.).

This species is included in the Phyllotini, but the tribal position of this species needs to be reviewed (H. Zeballos pers. comm.). There is a need to review the taxonomic status of the two subspecies (H. Zeballos pers. comm.).

<span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Monotypic species (Bonvicino 2015). No new changes."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":14720,"10":0,"11":4,"14":{"1":2,"2":0},"15":"Calibri","16":12}">Monotypic species (Bonvicino 2015).
Wiedomys pyrrhorhinos has been variously classified as a species of Oryzomys or Thomasomys (see Musser and Carleton 2005).

In the central distribution in Colombia the species is synonymous with bogotensis (Goodwin, 1955). This species is monotypic. T.m. bogotensis was regarded as a subspecies by some, but Musser and Carleton (2005) simply list bogotensis as a synonym of Tylomys mirae. Validation of subspecies boundaries requires a more thorough evaluation of geographic variation than currently available (Álvarez-Castañeda 2015).
According to Wilson and Reeder (2005) this species is possibly a subspecies of T. mirae according to Cabrera (1961) or a synonym of T. panamensis according to Handley (1966a).
Will be transferred to family Cricetidae.
Will be transferred to family Cricetidae.

This taxon was described as a subspecies of Phyllotis darwini, but it was considered a distinct species by Reig (1978) and Galliari et al. (1996); determination of status and distribution requires further investigation (Musser and Carleton 2005). This species is monotypic. Molecularly, P. bonariensis is included within a widespread clade. A more thorough geographic sampling of these taxa is required to resolve species-level boundaries within this clade (Steppan and Ramirez 2015).
Will be transferred to family Cricetidae.

Will be transferred to family Cricetidae. Species was split, to give new species M. kermanensis (Golenishchev et al. 2000).
The species was described on the basis of unique karyotype. Recently, analysis of mitochondrial DNA has shown that the species is closely related to Microtus guentheri.

According to Modi (1986), karyotypic analysis indicates that Microtus breweri should be synonymized with M. pennsylvanicus; morphological differences between the two are attributable to island effects in breweri. Microtus breweri and M. pennsylvanicus are marginally distinct electrophoretically. Moyer et al. (1988) presented cranial and dental evidence supporting recognition of M. breweri as a species distinct from M. pennsylvanicus. Jones et al. (1992), Baker et al. (2003), and Musser and Carleton (in Wilson and Reeder 1993, 2005) recognize M. breweri as a distinct species.
Will be transferred to family Cricetidae.
This species is sometimes placed in the genus Volemys (Smith and Xie 2008).

Some authors have considered M. abbreviatus to be conspecific with M. miurus of the Alaskan mainland. Jones et al. (1992), Baker et al. (2003), and Musser and Carleton (in Wilson and Reeder 1993, 2005) recognize M. abbreviatus and M. miurus as distinct species. According to Weksler et al. (2005) this species is recognized as a cospecies with M. miurus.
This species was formerly listed as a subspecies of M. arvalis (Musser and Carleton 2005).

authority: Golenishchev, Malikov, Nazari, Vaziri, Sablina & Polyakov, 2003
taxonomicNotes: The species has the same karyotype of Microtus guentheri, but did not hybridize with that species during experiments (Golenishchev et al. 2003). The population of voles that comprises M. qazvinensis was previously assigned to Microtus irani.
The species consists of two allopatric chromosomal races (“arvalis” and “obscurus”: Wilson and Reeder 2005) which are now reported as two distinct species (Tourgard et al. 2013).

There is taxonomic confusion with this species. Some people recognize this species as nudipes, others don't.

Pacheco (2003) suggested that Thomasomys paramorum might be a species complex, based on some geographic polymorphism in several characters (Pacheco 2015).

Pacheco (2003) recognized Thomasomys pyrrhonotus and T. auricularis as distinct species, contrary to previous reviews (Cabrera 1961; Musser and Carleton 1993, 2005). Pacheco (2015) supported the distinction a give a full account for the species
This species is under revision (V. Pacheco pers. comm.).
Will be transferred to family Cricetidae.

Thomasomys gracilis formerly included as a subspecies or junior synonym to T. cinnameus and T. hudsoni. Pacheco (2003) and Voss (2003) indicate that these are unambiguously diagnosable taxa that should be recognized as distinct species.

Recent studies suggest that T. baeops may be composed of more than one taxon (Pacheco 2003; Lee et al. 2011; Pacheco 2015). However, see Lee et al. (2015) because some of the taxonomic confusion involves T. taczanowskii that can cause problems with identification between it a T. baeops. Some specimens from farther north in Colombia are not included, but are part of the baeops species complex and are pending taxonomic review (M. Gómez-Laverde and V. Pacheco pers. comm.). Different species of this group are present in central part of the Cordilleras Central of Colombia (M. Gómez-Laverde pers. comm.).
This species was formerly included in the Thomasomys aureus complex. Currently it is accepted as a different species (Pacheco 2003, Voss 2003).

In the 1900’s, Thomasomys aureus, T. praetor, T. princeps, T. nicefori, T. popayanus, and T. altorum were considered as subspecies of T. aureus (Thomas 1900, Ellerman 1941, Cabrera 1961, Musser and Carleton 1993). Gardner and Romo (1993) assumed that the “T. aureuscomplex” consisted of three or more valid species. Voss (2003) and Pacheco (2003, 2015) discriminated popayanus and praetor from aureus, but Pacheco (2003) also recognizedprinceps and nicefori as full species. Pacheco (2003) recognized two additional unnamed species allied to T. aureus (e.g., Thomasomys sp. 1, and Thomasomys sp. 2 ). Then, Salazar Bravo and Yates (2007) sequenced a specimen of both, reporting enough divergence to consider them as distinct species. Pacheco (2015) suggested that other populations (from the Mérida Andes in Venezuela; Chinguela, Piura, and Río Abiseo, San Martín in Peru; and Unduavi, Bolivia) might deserve also species distinction.

Thomasomys cinnameus was considered a synonym of T. gracilis by Both Cabrera (1961) and Musser and Carleton (1993), but Voss (2003) Pacheco (2003) and Salazar- Bravo and Yates (2007) recognized T. cinnameus as a valid species. Pacheco (2015) noted that some individuals from Ecuador and Colombia show differences that suggest the presence of more than one taxon; however, more samples are required.
Voss (2003) considered Thomasomys hudsoni a valid species, contrasting it with T. cinnameus and T. gracili. Pacheco (2003, 2015) provided a full set of morphological characters for the species.

This species is considered a member of the “cinereus” species group (Pacheco 2003). Although T. caudivarius is considered monotypic, morphological variation suggests that it might include another taxon (Pacheco 2015).
Voss (2003) listed several morphological traits that clearly discriminated T. cinereiventer and T. erro as valid species.

Initially, Thomasomys vulcani was considered as a subspecies or synonym of Aepeomys lugens (Musser and Carleton 1993, Cabrera 1961). Later, Pacheco (in Voss et al. 2002) considered it to be a form of Thomasomys proper. Additional comparisons including the holotype of rhoadsi Stone prompted to recognize that rhoadsi is a junior synonym of T. vulcani (Pacheco 2015).
Will be transferred to family Cricetidae.
Generic synonym Phyllotis. Synonyms include Graomys griseoflavus medius (Cabrera 1961). This is a monotypic species (Braun and Patton 2015).
Will be transferred to family Cricetidae.

This taxon may represent a species complex.
Will be transferred to family Cricetidae.
The species is in need of revision, likely represents a species complex (M. Weksler pers. comm.).

The genus needs taxonomic revision - this species could be a subspecies. Although the the genus Oecomys occurs in Argentina, the presence of O. mamorae is not confirmed; the isolated populations found in Paraguay should be reviewed.

<span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Monotypic species (Carleton and Musser 2015). No new changes."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":14720,"10":0,"11":4,"14":{"1":2,"2":0},"15":"Calibri","16":12}">Monotypic species (Carleton and Musser 2015).
Will be transferred to family Cricetidae.

Allied to Oecomys bicolor or O. paricola; status and distributional extent require study (Musser and Carleton 2005). Langguth et al. (1996) consider it as a subspecies of O. bicolor. It is now recognized as a monotypic species (Carleton and Musser 2015).

Formerly a subspecies under Neotoma fuscipes, N. macrotis was elevated to species status following the discovery of morphological and genetic differences indicating genetic isolation between the two groups (Matocq 2002).
Potentially a subspecies of N. mexicana (Reid 2009).
Will be transferred to family Cricetidae.

Based on concordant patterns of morphological and mtDNA variation, Matocq (2002) split N. fuscipes into two species, N. fuscipes (Dusky-footed Woodrat) and N. macrotis (Large-eared Woodrat). This change was adopted in the North American mammal checklist by Baker et al. (2003). Musser and Carleton (in Wilson and Reeder 2005) also recognized the two as different species but applied the name "Big-eared Woodrat" to N. macrotis.
Will be transferred to family Cricetidae.

There was a previous attempt to divide this species into three separate species, but present evidence does not support this (Abe et al. 2005). Originally named as a species of Evotomys, it has sometimes been placed in the genus Eothenomys and Clethrionomys. Myodes imaizumii, here considered a synonym of M. andersoni (see Iwasa et al. 1999), was treated as a distinct species by Musser and Carleton (2005).
This species is sometimes included within the genus Eothenomys.

There is debate whether the populations on Daikoku and Rebun islands represent a separate species, Myodes sikotanensis (Musser and Carleton 2005, Abe et al. 2005). Specimens identified from China as regulus belong to this species. M. regulus is now considered to be endemic to the Korean Peninsula (Musser and Carleton 2005).
Was included as a synonym of Clethrionomys rufocanus, but recognized as a separate species by Wakana et al. (1996) on the basis of molecular study.
Myodes shanseius is frequently listed as a subspecies of M. rufocanus (Musser and Carleton 2005). It is sometimes included in the genus Eothenomys (Smith and Xie 2008).
Will be transferred to family Cricetidae.

It is a species complex, some portions of which may be threatened; it includes tenicauda from the Venezuelan Cordillera Oriental which may be a separate taxa (M. Gómez-Laverde pers. comm.). Two species similar to the Rhipidomys fulviventer have been found in Bongara, Peru but not much information is known (Tribe 2015).
The two subspecies of this species are debated and need futher research to be validated, R. cariri cariri and R. cariri baturiteensis (Costa et al. 2011).
Will be transferred to family Cricetidae.

<span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Monotypic species (Tribe 2015). No new changes."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":14720,"10":0,"11":4,"14":{"1":2,"2":0},"15":"Calibri","16":12}">Monotypic species (Tribe 2015).

This form may represent the E Andean complement of R. latimanus (see that account). The provisional association of R. nitela tobagi Goodwin, previously placed as a synonym of R. nitela (e.g., Musser and Carleton 1993, Tribe 1996), follows the observations of Voss et al. (2001).

<span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Monotypic species (Tribe 2015). No new changes."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":14720,"10":0,"11":4,"14":{"1":2,"2":0},"15":"Calibri","16":12}">Monotypic species (Tribe 2015).
Will be transferred to family Cricetidae.
Will be transferred to family Cricetidae.

Wang (2003) recognized five subspecies: 1) Eothenomys custos cangshanensis Wang and Li 2000; Yunnan (Cang mountain of Dali); 2) E. c. custos (Thomas, 1912); NW Yunnan; 3) E. c. hintoni Osgood, 1932; W Sichuan; 4) E. c. ninglangensis Wang and Li, 2000; N Yunnan, S Sichuan; 5) E. c. rubellus (Allen, 1924); N Yunnan (Smith and Xie 2008).
Eothenomys chinensis is the type species of Anteliomys, which is in turn a synonym of Eothenomys (Musser and Carleton 2005).
Eothenomys wardi was formerly included in E. chinensis (Smith and Xie 2008).

This species is considered for the assessment as A. olrogi and A. roigi, these are the same species according new studies (A.A. Garcia 2003). A. olrogi was considered in 1996 as Vulnerable in the IUCN Red List; A. roigi was not included in the IUCN Red List. This species is monotypic (Braun 2015).

This species is closely related to Habromys chinanteco and H. simulatus. However, strong morphometric differentiation and geographic isolation help to differentiate the species (Romo-Vazquez et al. 2005).
This species is morphologically similar to H. simulatus (Rogers et al. 2007).
This species has a strong sister group relationship with Habromys chicanteco (Rogers 2007).
This taxon was returned to specific rank by Carleton et al. (2002). It has a similar morphology to Habromys lepturus (Rogers 2007).

Musser and Carleton (2005) list this species as occurring in extreme northwestern Oaxaca, México (specifically: Puerto de la Soledad, Cuicatlán), but this population probably represents a separate species (León-Paniagua et al. 2007). This species has a close morphology to H. chicanteco (Rogers et al. 2007).
This species has a strong sister group relationship with Habromys ixtlani and H. lepturus (Rogers 2007).
This species has a similar morphology to H. ixtlani (Rogers et al. 2007).
Will be transferred to family Cricetidae.
Will be transferred to family Cricetidae.

The distribution limits between this species and O. amazonicus need to be reviewed (B. Patterson pers. comm.). This treatment includes O. juliacae which may be a distinct species (H. Zeballos and B. Patterson pers. comm.).
Will be transferred to family Cricetidae.
This species is sometimes included in the genus Microtus (Musser and Carleton 2005).
This new species of Proedromys is distinguished from P. bedfordi by external and cranial measurements, as well as dentition (Liu et al. 2007).
Also known as Neotoma alleni.

Generic synonym = Cricetulus; Tscherskia.

Will be transferred to family Cricetidae.

Nominal forms as synonyms should be reviewed. Formerly included in Muridae (Musser and Carleton 2005). The following species may be found in sympatry with Akodon budini: A. caenosus, A. fumenus, and A. simulator (Barquez et al. 2006; Diaz and Barquez 2007; Ortiz and Miotti 2008; Jayat et al. 2010).
Will be transferred to family Cricetidae.

Generic synonyms Abrothrix, Chroeomys, Hypsimys, Thaptomys. This species has a synonym A. tolimae (type locality Cordillera Central), also present in 'Cordillera Central y Occidental'). A species complex with taxonomic changes expected (Anderson and Gómez-Laverde pers. comm.).
Will be transferred to family Cricetidae.

Subgenus Akodon, formerly in Muridae family. Populations assigned to this species had been formerly identified as A. serrensis (e.g., Liascovich et al. 1989), but work by Christoff et al. (2000) clarified the karyotypic and morphometric separation of the two species. Christoff et al. (2000) left the assignment of A. paranaensis as species group indeterminate pending additional study of its relationship. Pardiñas et al. (2003) discuss the tenuous basis for segregating paranaensis and reigi; resolution is needed.
It was transferred to family Cricetidae.
Will be transferred to family Cricetidae.
This species is monotypic (Pardiñas et al. 2015).
This species is monotypic (Pardiñas et al. 2015).

This species needs further taxonomic review (N. Bernal pers. comm.). Formerly assessed for the Red List as A. puer in Muridae. Subgenus Akodon, A. boliviensis species group (Myers et al. 1990). In that revision of the boliviensis group, Myers et al. (1990) referred lutescens, classified as a subspecies of A. andinus by Cabrera (1961) to subspecies of A. puer.  Some years after Anderson (1997) indicated that lutescens has priority over puer.

There are significant taxonomic problems with this name. It may represent an undefined number of species for which the distribution limits are very poorly known (J. Dunnum, J. Vargas and N. Bernal pers. comm.). Pardiñas et al. (2015) regard this species as monotypic.

This is a species complex; the relationships of sylvanus, pervalens, tartareus, varius and azarae need further consideration (Anderson, 1997). Subgenus Akodon, formerly Muridae family. Status and relationship variously recognized: named as a subspecies of A. sylvanus by Thomas (1925; as followed by Musser and Carleton, 1993); reallocated to a subspecies of A. varius by Cabrera (1961); retained as a nominal species similar to A. cursor by Myers (1989); placed as a synonym of A. serrensis by Hershkovitz (1990). The status of A. pervalens as a full species, supported by some authors (Myers 1990; S. Anderson 1997; Musser and Carleton 2005; M. M. Díaz and Barquez 2007), and the proper delineation of its distribution require further studies focused on topotypical material (see Jayat, Ortiz et al. 2007) and the reexamination of the specimens assigned to this species by S. Anderson (1997) (Pardiñas et al. 2015). Taxonomic resolution is needed.
Will be transferred to family Cricetidae.
This species is monotypic (Pardiñas et al. 2015).
This species is monotypic (Pardiñas et al. 2015).

This species is monotypic. It has been treated mostly as its own species; however, some have suggested that it is a local variant of Akodon aerosus confined to the Urubamba Valley (Pardiñas et al. 2015).
This species is monotypic (Pardiñas et al. 2015).
This species has been misidentified with A. mimus and A. fumeus in the past. This species share many morphological attributes with A. fumeus and present a sister relationship (Smith and Patton 2007).

There has been some confusion between specimens of A. orophilus and A. mollis. Further taxonomic review of these species is needed as there are three distinct karyotypes (H. Zeballos and E. Vivar pers. comm.). Records of this species from Ecuador (Moreno and Albuja, 2005) are considered to be A. mollis (H. Zeballos and V. Pacheco pers. comm.). There are two recognized subspecies of Akodon orophilus, A.o. orophilus and A.o. orientalis. Both subspecies were originally described as subspecies of A. mollis. Intergradation between subspecies A. orophilus and A. orientalis has been reported in the Puca Tambo region, and color variations have been related to differences in environmental conditions (Pardiñas et al. 2015).

This species could be synonymous with A. paranensis (A. Langguth pers. comm.). Subgenus Akodon, A. cursor species group sensu Rieger et al. (1995). Formerly Muridae family. Principally contrasted to A. cursor and A. serrensis; misattributed reports of this new species as A. serrensis clarified by González et al. (1998). Status and distributional limits with regard to A. mystax and especially A. paranaensis require careful review (see discussion by Pardiñas et al. 2003).
This species is monotypic (Pardiñas et al. 2015).
This is considered to be a species complex which requires further taxonomic investigation.
This species is monotypic (Vilela et al. 2015). No new changes.
This species is monotypic. No new changes. It is possible that this species may be synonymous with Brucepattersonius paradisus or Brucepattersonius iheringi (Vilela et al. 2015).
This species is monotypic. No new changes. It is possible that this species may be synonymous with Brucepattersonius paradisus or Brucepattersonius iheringi (Vilela et al. 2015).
This species is monotypic (Vilela et al. 2015). No new changes.
This species is monotypic (Vilela et al. 2015). No new changes.

This taxon reflects a species complex, more studies are needed. Cabrera (1961) recognized three subspecies as did Voss (1988:334). Each proposed subspecies describes a single local population. Ichthyomys h. hydrobates of Venezuela, I. h. nicefori of Columbia, and I.h. soderstromi of Ecuador (Voss 2015).

<span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"This species is monotypic (Voss 2015)."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":15037,"3":{"1":0},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"12":0,"14":{"1":2,"2":0},"15":"Helvetica","16":10}">This species is monotypic (Voss 2015).
Synonyms of this species include Ichthyomys orientalis (Anthony 1923). Monotypic species (Voss 2015).
Synonyms of this species include Ichthyomys caurinus (Thomas 1924) (MSW). Monotypic species (Voss 2015).
Will be transferred to family Cricetidae.
This species is also known as Aporodon creper.
Will be transferred to family Cricetidae.

Two subspecies are recognized: Reithrodontomys raviventris raviventris and R. r. halicoetes, which some authors have proposed as distinct species. Neither Baker et al. (2003) nor Musser and Carleton (in Wilson and Reeder 1993, 2005) recognized halicoetes as a distinct species.  Subspecies raviventris is distinguished by a dark, cinnamon coloured back and lighter underbelly, whereas subspecies halicoetes is known for a lighter coloured back and white underbelly (Kays and Wilson 2009).
Will be transferred to family Cricetidae.

<span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Monotypic species. No new changes. (S\u00e1nchez 2014)"}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":14720,"10":0,"11":4,"14":{"1":2,"2":0},"15":"Calibri","16":12}">This is a monotypic species (Sánchez 2014).
Reithrodontomys bakeri was recently described based on genetic data. Morphologically, this form closely resembles Aporodon microdon.
Needs taxonomic research.

Further research is needed to determine whether the Peruvian record is the same as thase in the Colombian and Venezuelan populations (V. Pacheco pers. comm.). This species is a synonym with Ichthyomys trichotis (Thomas 1897), Rheomys trichotis (Thomas 1906), Anotomys trichotis (Handley 1976). It is a monotypic species (Voss 2015).

<span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Monotypic species (Voss 2015). No new changes."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":14720,"10":0,"11":4,"14":{"1":2,"2":0},"15":"Calibri","16":12}">Monotypic species (Voss 2015).

Tamayo and Frassinetti (1980) included delfini as a subspecies of C. megalonyx. Teta et al. (2015) considered delfini a form related to Geoxus and Chelemys.

Two subspecies, megalonyx and microtis (Phillippi 1900), are sometimes recognized (e.g., Osgood 1943; see Teta et al. 2015). The form microtis would come from and unknown place in the east of the Maule province. No recent study has assessed the distinction between these two subspecies. After the placement of macronyx in its own genus, Paynomys Teta et al. (2016), megalonyx is the single species of the genus Chelemys.
This species is occasionally included in the genus Microtus (Smith and Xie 2008).
Weksler and Valqui (2015) treat this species as monotypic.
This is often regarded as a synonym or subspecies of the mainland Oryzomys couesi (Wilson and Reeder 2005). Following Weksler et al. (2006), it is maintained here as a valid species.
Will be transferred to family Cricetidae.

The species was assessed as a composite of three nominal forms (fronto, chacoensis and planaltensis). Kunsia fronto is now Gyldenstolpia fronto, after a study by Pardiñas and Bezerra in 2008 (Pardiñas and Bezerra 2015).
Will be transferred to family Cricetidae.
Previously included in genus Sigmodontomys, this species is now recognized as Tanyuromys aphrastus (Pine et al. 2012, Weksler 2015).

There is no consensus on the proper generic allocation for this species. It was placed in the genus Arborimus by Johnson and George (1991), Musser and Carleton (in Wilson and Reeder, 1993, 2005), Hayes (1996), Adam and Hayes (1998), and Baker et al. (2003); and included in the genus Phenacomys by Carleton and Musser (1984), Repenning and Grady (1988), and Verts and Carraway (1998). Bellinger et al. (2005) noted that recognition of Arborimus as a distinct genus is subject to interpretation of data.

This species is represented by Californian populations previously recognized as Arborimus (or Phenacomys) longicaudus. Recognition as a species distinct from A. longicaudus is based on chromosome differences, smaller overall size, and certain skull and muscle differences (Johnson and George 1991; Blois and Arbogast 2006). Musser and Carleton (in Wilson and Reeder 1993, 2005) and Baker et al. (2003) accepted A. pomo as a species distinct from A. longicaudus.

There is no consensus on the proper generic allocation for this species. It was placed in the genus Arborimus by Johnson and George (1991), Musser and Carleton (in Wilson and Reeder 1993, 2005), Hayes (1996), Adam and Hayes (1998), and Baker et al. (2003); included in the genus Phenacomys by Carleton and Musser (1984), Repenning and Grady (1988), and Verts and Carraway (1998). Bellinger et al. (2005) noted that recognition of Arborimus as a distinct genus is subject to interpretation of data.

Johnson and George (1991) separated California populations previously regarded as Arborimus longicaudus and described them as a new species Arborimus pomo, based on chromosome differences, smaller overall size, and certain skull and muscle differences. Musser and Carleton (in Wilson and Reeder 1993, 2005) and Baker et al. (2003) included this new species.

There is no consensus on the proper generic allocation for this species. It was placed in the genus Arborimus by Johnson and George (1991), Musser and Carleton (in Wilson and Reeder 1993, 2005), Hayes (1996), Adam and Hayes (1998), and Baker et al. (2003); and included in the genus Phenacomys by Carleton and Musser (1984), Repenning and Grady (1988), and Verts and Carraway (1998). Bellinger et al. (2005) noted that recognition of Arborimus as a distinct genus is subject to interpretation of data.
Will be transferred to family Cricetidae.
Will be transferred to family Cricetidae.
Will be transferred to family Cricetidae.

This species previously has been considered a synonymous with Nesoryzomys narboroughi (see Musser and Carleton 1993). Recent evidence suggests that the two should be treated as separate species (Dowler et al. 2000). More research is needed to confirm that these are really two different species (M. Weksler pers. comm).

Previously this species was considered synonymous with Nesoryzomys indefessus (see Musser and Carleton 1993). Recent evidence suggests that the two should be treated as separate species (Dowler et al. 2000). More research is needed to confirm that these are really two different species (M. Weksler pers. comm).

<span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"This species is monotypic (Pardi\u00f1as and Teta 2015)."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":15037,"3":{"1":0},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"12":0,"14":{"1":2,"2":0},"15":"Helvetica","16":10}">This species is monotypic (Pardiñas and Teta 2015).

The entire genus requires taxonomic revision. Cricetulus tibetanus is often included in C. kamensis (Smith and Xie 2008). R.S. Hoffmann separates the forms kamensis, lama, and tibetanus, following earlier taxonomic work recognizing each as good species. This treatment is followed by the Mammals of China (Smith and Xie 2008). This form is treated as a synonym of C. kamensis by Musser and Carleton (2005).

The entire genus requires taxonomic revision. Cricetulus lama is often included in C. kamensis (Smith and Xie 2008). R.S. Hoffmann separates the forms kamensis, lama, and tibetanus, following earlier taxonomic work recognizing each as good species. This treatment is followed by the Mammals of China (Smith and Xie 2008). Cricetulus lama is treated as a synonym of C. kamensis by Musser and Carleton (2005).

The entire genus requires taxonomic revision. R.S. Hoffmann separates the forms Cricetulus kamensis, lama, and tibetanus, following earlier taxonomic work recognizing each as good species. This treatment is followed by the Mammals of China (Smith and Xie 2008). The Mammals of China recognizes two subspecies Cricetulus kamensis kamensis (eastern Xizang and southern Qinghai) and C. k. kozlovi (northern Qinghai, northwestern Gansu, and southern Xinjiang) (Smith and Xie 2008). The forms lama and tibetanus are treated as synonyms by Musser and Carleton (2005).
Generic synonym Rheomys. This species is monotypic (Voss 2015).

Taylor et al. (2011) revised the O. typus complex resulting in this species being split into: O. typus, O. cheesmani, O. simiensis and O. yaldeni in Ethiopia. The taxonomy and phylogeny of Ethiopian Otomys species remains largely unresolved and additional research is necessary (Taylor et al. 2011).

This species was included in O. typus but, based on pronounced morphometric divergence, was recognised as distinct by Musser and Carleton (2005) and Carleton and Byrne (2006). The validity of the species was further confirmed in Taylor et al. (2011).

This species was previously a synonym of Otomys anchietae. It was found to be distinct by Taylor and Kumurai (2001). O. lacustris has a seemingly allopatric distribution with Otomys denti sungae in the Southern Rift and Eastern Arc Mountains (Taylor et al. 2009). Taylor et al. (2009) suspect that O. lacustris represents a species complex and that further genetic sampling may reveal additional taxonomic subdivision. It is expected that O. lacustris should be split into two lineages, with the lineage from the Southern Rift retaining the name O. lacustris, while a new name is designated for the Eastern Arc species (Taylor et al. 2009).
This species was removed from the synonymy of Otomys anchitae by Dieterlen and van der Straeten (1992).

Its close taxonomic relationship with Otomys burtoni (a second West African species), and weak association to East and northeast African members of the O. typus s.l. and O. tropicalis s.l species complexes suggest a single West African radiation of the species (Taylor et al. 2014). Based on its smaller cranial size, this species can be morphometrically distinguished from all other Otomys species (Taylor et al. 2014). Additional taxonomic assessments are necessary to determine whether the specimens from Nigeria are a different species (R. Hutterer pers. comm.).
This species was previously synonymized with O. irroratus. Current taxonomic research supports the distinctiveness of this species (S. Maree pers. comm.).
This species was previously considered a subspecies of Otomys tropicalis.
This is most likely a species complex. Otomys kempi is possibly distinct from this species based on mitochondrial DNA sequencing data (S. Maree pers. comm.).
Previously noted as a synonym of Otomys typus, but Taylor et al. (2011) consider this a valid species.
This species previously included the forms lacustris, barbouri and occidentalis.
This was included as a synonym of O. typus, but Taylor et al. (2011)  resurrected this species.
This species needs further taxonomic study (Musser and Newcomb 1983).

Described as a species of Rattus (Sody 1931), later treated as a subspecies of R. infraluteus (Chasen 1940), but shown to be a very distinctive species and member of the suite of endemic Javanese murines (Musser and Newcomb 1983). Still only represented by specimens collected between 1932 and 1935 by Max Bartels Jr. Phylogenetic relationship may be closer to S. muelleri than to S. infraluteus as judged by morphology (Musser and Carleton 2005).
There is a need to compare specimens from Borneo and Sumatra to determine if these populations represent the same taxon (K. Aplin pers. comm.).
Synonym = P. albocinereus.

Pseudomys pilligaensis is treated as a separate species following Musser and Carleton (2005), but it might be best considered a population of P. delicatulus that shows evidence of past hybridization with P. novaehollandiae (F. Ford pers. comm.). It is not recognized as a distinct taxon by Ford (2008) or Woinarski et al. (2014), and the recent comprehensive treatment of the taxonomy of Australian mammals (Jackson and Groves 2015) considered it as conspecific with P. delicatulus, although noting that ‘this taxon needs further investigation’.

No subspecies are recognised for Pseudomys fieldi. The original Shark Bay specimen was described as Pseudomys praeconis, but research demonstrated that P. praeconis should be synonymised with P. fieldi, described from a single Alice Springs specimen (Baynes 1990).

No subspecies are recognised for Pseudomys novaehollandiae. Ford (2003) found that the genetic distinctiveness of P. novaehollandiae from P. delicatulus was no greater than that among individuals of P. delicatulus. He suggested that the two may not be separate species and that P. novaehollandiae may be a subspecies of P. delicatulus.
No subspecies are recognised.

Recently, Papagomys theodorverhoeveni was reported to be still extant on Flores island on the basis of a single museum specimen consisting of a skull and mandibles, collected in 1974 at Ruteng, Manggarai, West Flores and was stored in the collections of the Museum Zoologicum Bogoriense (Suyanto and Watts 2002). However, based on comparison with extensive zooarchaeological material from Liang Bua, all evidence suggests that that record is not an example of P. theodorverhoeveni, but of P. armandvillei. Therefore, the identification of this specimen is refuted (Zijlstra et al. 2008).
Included within the genus Chrotomys by Corbet and Hill (1992).
No subspecies are recognised. Mahoney (1977) found that the single skull was distinct from other Notomys and that it was likely to be most closely related to Mitchell’s Hopping-mouse N. mitchellii.
No subspecies are recognised.
No subspecies are recognised for this species.

Initially the single, monotypic species R. pumilio was recognised (Sparrman, 1784). Several subspecies have been proposed based on extensive variation in pelage colour and morphology across the distribution. Within southern Africa, Roberts (1951) proposed 20 subspecies of which Meester et al. (1986) regarded only seven as being valid. Rambau et al. (2003) recommended the recognition of two species based on cytogenetic and mitochondrial sequence data, the xeric R. pumilio and mesic R. dilectus, which was adopted by Musser and Carleton (2005). The authors further suggested the presence of two subspecies, R. d. dilectus and R. d. chakae within the latter taxon. This was confirmed in a recent molecular and chromosomal analysis of R. dilectus, which revealed high genetic divergence within the species, and the presence of three distinct clades (Castiglia et al. 2012). The basal clade, recognised as R. d. chakae is endemic to South Africa, while the two distinct sister clades (R. d. dilectus) are distributed allopatrically across northern parts of its range, into East Africa, including a new divergent karyotype found in the high altitudes of Mt. Meru and Mt. Kilimanjaro (Castiglia et al. 2012). Reproductive isolation due to pre- and post-mating barriers have been found among R. pumilio and R. dilectus, as well as among the proposed subspecies within the latter taxon (Pillay 2000, Pillay et al. 2006). Subsequently, du Toit et al. (2012) indicated three genetic lineages with distinct distributions related to biome boundaries within the xeric R. pumilio. Based on deep mitochondrial genetic divergence, paraphyly of R. pumilio with respect to R. dilectus and different ecological preferences of the three genetic lineages within R. pumilio, the recognition of four species (R. dilectus, R. pumilio, R. bechuanae, and R. intermedius) was suggested (du Toit et al. 2012). However, Monadjem et al. (2015) recognise R. chakae as a valid species due to at least one case of known sympatry between R. d. dilectus and R. d. chakae. Further molecular research (particularly including more nuclear data) and cranial morphometric analyses would be useful to fully resolve the taxonomy of the genus. Until such time, it is recommended that Rhabdomys be treated as a species complex.

Chromosome data suggest that populations from southern Viet Nam and north-east Thailand are not conspecific, but further comparison is needed; it is possible that the name pasquieri (type locality Xiangkhouang, north-east Lao PDR) might be available for the latter (Yong et al. 2012, Abramov et al. 2012).
This is probably a species complex (K. Aplin pers. comm.).

This species belongs to subgenus Coelomys Thomas, 1915. Ellerman (1961) listed three subspecies, namely Mus famulus famulus Bonhote, 1898, Mus famulus cooki (sic) (Ryley, 1914) and Mus famulus popaeus (Thomas, 1919). Mus famulus cooki (sic) (Ryley, 1914) is now considered as a separate species Mus cookii Ryley, 1914, and Mus famulus popaeus (Thomas, 1919) - earlier reported as Leggada nitidula popaea Thomas, 1919, has been proposed to be a subspecies of Mus cervicolor by Corbet and Hill (1992). Thus, presently only Mus famulus Bonhote, 1898 is a valid name from the region.

Many specimens have been assigned to this species from the work by Petter et al. 1971 where they attributed the 2n = 36 and FN = 36 karyotype to this name. (But difficult to apply any morphological characters to this [E. van der Straeten pers. comm.]). Therefore the range is different to that indicated by Musser and Carleton (2005).
This species forms and unresolved species complex with Mus minutoides in East Africa and Central Africa.

Although originally described as a species; Mus neavei was later regarded as a subspecies of M. sorella (Ansell 1978; Meester et al. 1986; Skinner & Smithers 1990). More recently, however, Petter (1981) suggested that M. neavei should be reclassified to species status, as it differs from M. sorella in its fur colour, body size, and its cranial and molar structure. This recommendation was corroborated and accepted by Musser and Carleton (1993) and Bronner et al. (2003). Although, commonly confused with M. indutus (the Desert Pygmy Mouse) and M. minutoides (the Pygmy Mouse), this species can be distinguished by its lower three-rooted second molar and pro-odont incisors (Meester et al. 1986).

authority: Cucchi, Orth, Auffray, Renaud, Fabre, Catalan, Hadjisterkotis, Bonhomme & Vigne, 2006
taxonomicNotes: "A new species of the genus Mus has been discovered on the island of Cyprus, namely Mus cypriacus. Molecular phylogeny of complete D-loop sequences, as well as that of a nuclear gene intron (ABP), evidence that this new taxa is not an island variant but deserves a species rank on its own, as a sister species of Mus macedonicus and Mus spicilegus, the two closest mainland relatives. Classical and geometric morphometry provide diagnostic morphological criteria separating Mus cypriacus from European species." (Cucchi et al. 2006). Genetic and archaeological evidence suggest that the common ancestor of M. cypriacus and M. macedonicus arrived on Cyprus during the Middle Pleistocene by a founder event on a natural raft (Cucchi et al. 2006). This species is one of only three surviving endemic mammal species on Mediterranean islands that originate from ancient natural colonization events (Gippoliti and Amori 2006).

authority: Auffray, Orth, Catalan, Gonzalez, Desmarais & Bonhomme, 2003
taxonomicNotes: This species is highly distinct genetically, but morphologically very similar to M. cervicolor, therefore, this species is probably much more widespread, as some specimens are hidden within M. cervicolor (Musser and Carleton 2005).

This species belongs to subgenus Pyromys Thomas, 1911. Ellerman (1961) listed six subspecies, namely Mus platythrix platythrix Bennett, 1832, Mus platythrix sadhu (Wroughton, 1911), Mus platythrix ramnadensis (Bentham, 1908), Mus platythrix bahadur (Wroughton and Ryley, 1913), Mus platythrix gurkha (Thomas, 1914), and Mus platythrix shortridgei (Thomas, 1914). However, Marshall (1977) has rearranged Mus platythrix complex under three species namely Mus platythrix Bennett, 1832, Mus saxicola Elliot, 1839 and Mus shortridgei (Thomas, 1914). The last species does not occur in South Asia. One population of Mus platytheix with chromosomal variation from Araku, Andhra Pradesh and Pune, Maharashtra (Agrawal 2000)
Possible taxonomic changes due to DNA studies
F. Dieterlen and L. Lavrenchenko disagree with Happold and consider the presence of this species as valid in Ethiopia.
This species forms part of the Lophuromys flavopunctatus species complex. Recent taxonomic splits have described at least nine representatives of this group endemic to Ethiopia.
This species was formerly included in the genus Melomys. There is a levipes-like species on the island of New Britain, Papua New Guinea, which needs to be examined (Flannery 1995).
This species was formerly included in the genus Melomys. It was also previously considered to be a synonym of Paramelomys rubex.
This species was formerly considered to be a synonym of Paramelomys lorentzii.
This species was formerly included in the genus Melomys.
This species was formerly included in the genus Melomys.
The population from Tokunoshima originally attributed to this species, was recently elevated to species status as Tokudaia tokunoshimensis by Endo and Tsuchiya (2006).
Ohiya rat is the sole member of the genus Srilankamys. Srilankamys is currently classified in the Dacnomys division of the tribe Rattini (Musser and Carleton 2005).
This species was in the genus, Hydromys; transferred to Baiyankamys by Helgen (2005).

Based on morphological evidence, Nesokia is synonymized with Erythronesokia (Kryštufek et al. 2017). Nesokia, Bandicota and the Ryukyu island endemic Diplothrix Thomas, 1916b, form a lineage of phylogenetically closely related albeit morphologically diverse species which hold a sister position against Rattus Fischer, 1803 (Kryštufek et al. 2017).
Formerly included in Hadromys humei, it is now considered a distinct species (Musser and Carleton 2005).
This species has been included in the genus Neohydromys by some authors (e.g., Flannery 1995).
This species was previously considered to be part of Mayermys ellermani. Both species have now been transferred to the genus Pseudohydromys.

Comments from Musser and Carleton (2005): "Now thought to be a good species but originally described as a species of Hylomyscus, but differs significantly from any species in that genus in morphological and chromosomal traits (Misonne 1969; Robbins et al. 1980), ecology (Duplantier, 1989), and complete mitochondrial DNA cytochrome b sequences (Lecompte et al. 2002b). Chevret et al. (1994), however, suggested that the degree of nucleotide substitutions indicated fumosus could remain in Hylomyscus under subgenus Heimyscus."
We follow Happold (in press) in including Thamnomys major within T. kempi.

Originally described as Epimys fraternus, but subsequently treated as a subspecies of Rattus rapit (Chasen 1940), R. orbus (Ellerman 1941), or Niviventer rapit ( = Chasen’s R. rapit; Musser 1970; Corbet and Hill 1992); the latter authorities also included the Bornean rapit and Malay Peninsula cameroni as subspecies (Musser and Carleton 2005).
This may be a species complex (K. Aplin, G. Musser and D. Lunde pers. comm.).
This species is sometimes inappropriately referred to as coxingi.

Specimens reported as Niviventer andersoni or N. coxingi andersoni from Taiwan, southeast China, or any other locality well outside of the geographic range described in this account are not N. andersoni (Smith and Xie 2008). On Taiwan they probably represent the large-bodied N. coninga; elsewhere they likely represent N. tenaster or large-bodied N. fulvescens, or an undescribed species misidentified as N. andersoni (Musser and Lunde, ms). Wang (2003) lists Niviventer andersoni lushuiensis Wu and Wang, subsp. nov., 2002; but this has yet to be published with a diagnosis and identification of the holotype (Smith and Xie 2008).
This species was formerly included in Niviventer confucianus and as a subspecies of N. niviventer (Musser and Carleton 2005).

Originally described as a species, tenaster was later arranged as a subspecies of N. cremoriventer (Ellerman 1941, 1961; Ellerman and Morrison-Scott 1951) until the type specimens were shown to represent a separate species (Musser 1973, 1981).

Crateromys schadenbergi is an ecological and morphological equivalent of large-bodied tropical tree squirrels (Sciuridae), which do not occur in the Greater Luzon Faunal Region (Musser and Carleton 2005).

Coryphomys buehleri is one of four species, each in its own genus, of giant rats (three have yet to be named and described) endemic to Timor; all are known only by subfossils (Glover 1986) and may be related to the New Guinea Old Endemics placed in the Pogonomys Group (Musser and Carleton 2005).

Molecular analyses support P. degraaffi, P. mutoni and P. minor as distinct species within the P. jacksoni complex (Mizerovská et al. 2019). They appear well characterised by ecology and morphology and there is little doubt that they correspond to distinct biological entities (Kennis et al. 2011).
Taxonomy needs revision.
Was Malacomys verschureni. Transferred to Praomys but this might want recognition as a new genus (E. Van der Straeten pers. comm).
This species is possibly not a Malacomys, and it appears to be closer to Praomys. It is possible that this taxon may represent a new genus.

Further study is needed on the taxonomic status of this species, especially its relationship with Melomys lutillus. According to Musser and Carleton (2005) these two species are closely related, and M. frigicola was formerly considered a subspecies of M. lutillus, but was elevated to full species status by Menzies (1996).
Melomys bougainville was previously considered to be a subspecies of M. rufescens. There is still some doubt as to whether or not it is distinct from M. rufescens.
This species may represent a species complex.

This species is still known only by the type series (Helgen 2003). Originally it was described as a species of Uromys, then placed in Pogonomelomys by Rümmler (1938), kept there by Tate (1951), but returned to Melomys by Laurie and Hill (1954). Melomys fraterculus shares many derived cranial features with the Australian M. cervinipes complex and may be more closely related to the indigenous Australian Melomys than to those on New Guinea (Musser and Carleton 2005). Menzies (1990), however, wrote that "Without more material and additional study it is difficult to say more about it. For the present it is best left in Melomys," and for Flannery (1995) "It may ultimately be necessary to create a new genus for it." Helgen (2003) promised a review in a forthcoming report.

Flannery (1995) states that in view of the confused state of the Melomy lutillus group, it is difficult to assess the validity of this taxon. Musser and Carleton (2005) provisionally treat M. bannisteri as distinct noting that the Kai Islands are in deep water and are not part of the continental shelf connecting Australia and New Guinea.
Includes M. caurinus, M. fulgens, M. talaudium.

This species was formerly considered to be a subspecies of Melomys rufescens, but is now considered to be distinct (Musser and Carleton 2005). It has often been listed as M. gracilis (e.g., Musser and Carleton 1993; Flannery 1995).
This species is sometimes considered a subspecies of A. draco (Smith and Xie 2008).

A good review of the systematics of Mastomys is provided by Granjon et al. (1997). Mastomys spp. are cryptic and difficult to distinguish morphologically but clearly separable by molecular and chromosomal markers (Britton-Davidian et al. 1995; Lecompte et al. 2005). For example, within the assessment region, M. coucha and M. natalensis can be distinguished only through chromosome number (in M. coucha 2n = 36; in M. natalensis 2n = 32) and molecular markers (Colangelo et al. 2013) but not on cranio-dental features, nor a multivariate analysis (Dippenaar et al. 1993).
Mastomys verheyeni was treated as a junior synonym of M. kollmannspergeri by Musser & Carleton (2005), a classification confirmed by recent molecular and cytogenetic analyses (Dobigny et al. 2008).
This species clearly does not fit in Mastomys, but there is no decision yet on where it is best placed (see Musser & Carleton account in Wilson and Reeder 2005 for discussion on this).
A split from M. natalensis.
Treated by Musser and Carelton (2005) under Gerbilliscus validus (Bocage, 1890).
Includes type locality of T. musculus. Treated by Musser and Carelton (2005) under Gerbilliscus phillipsi (de Winton, 1898)
Treated by Musser and Carelton (2005) under Gerbilliscus nigricaudus (Peters, 1878)
Treated by Musser and Carelton (2005) under Gerbilliscus guineae Thomas, 1910
Treated by Musser and Carelton (2005) as a synonym of Gerbilliscus kempi Wroughton, 1906. We follow Happold (in press) in recognizing G. gambiana as distinct from G. kempi.

Although previously classified as Tatera afra (Skinner & Chimimba 2005), this species was recently recognised by Musser and Carleton (2005) as Gerbilliscus afra (Gray 1830). Aside from Gerbilliscus paeba (readily distinguished from G. afra by its smaller size, relatively long tail and hairy soles on its hindfeet), this is the only Gerbilliscus species present within its range (Monadjem et al. 2015), and no subspecies have been recognised (Dempster 2013).

The single specimen from Sichuan is larger and darker than typical examples of the species, with more specimens needed to determine if it represents a separate species (Smith and Xie 2008). This may be a complex of several species, and further taxonomic studies are needed to resolve this.
Taeromys taerae is the north east peninsular highland and morphological relative of T. hamatus, which is found only in mountains of central Sulawesi (Musser and Carleton 2005).
Generic synonym = Rattus.
Should perhaps be included in Praomys.
Was Myomys albipes. Transferred to Stenocephalemys.
Generic synonym = Rattus. Specific synonym = mearnsi.
Synonym = Uromys salamonis.
Two populations (one from southeastern Papua New Guinea and another from the Arfak range) have been attributed to this species, but these may represent undescribed species.

Ellerman (1961) and, Agrawal and Chakraborty (1980) included this form under Vandeleuria oleracea (Bennett, 1832). Corbet and Hill (1992) quoting Musser (1979) treated it as a species by itself separate from Vandeluria oleracea (Bennett, 1832), a trend also accepted by Musser and Carleton (1993) by virtue of its distinct montane distribution, pelage colouration, external and cranial traits.
Vandeleuria oleracea represents a complex of several similar species. Further studies are needed to clarify the taxonomic status of populations currently allocated to this species.
Pogonomys fergussoniensis was previously considered to be a subspecies of Pogonomys loriae.
This species was long considered to be a synonym of Colomys goslingi Thomas and Wroughton, 1907. It was resurrected by Kerbis Peterhans and Patterson (1995).
Synonym = A. petraeus?
This almost certainly represents a species complex and taxonomic revision is underway (L. Heaney pers. comm.).
The taxonomic status of the species needs revision, as there is significant geographic variation (L. Heaney pers. comm.).
Information and specimens previously referred to this species (Heaney et al. 1998) probably relate to members of the Apomys datae group. The species has since been redescribed (Heaney et al. 2014).
The genus Apomys was reviewed by Musser (1982), with modifications by Musser and Heaney (1992). The species has since been reviewed and remains as a distinct species (Heaney et al. 2011).

Corbet and Hill (1992) stated that the name Apomys hollisteri should be used for this species, but Musser and Carleton (1993) continued usage of A. microdon. The taxonomic status needs revision (L. Heaney, D. Balete, and P. Alviola pers. comm.).
Previously included in the genus Melomys.
According to Nanova 2014, the species rank of Meriones dahli requires verification with genetic data.

Leopoldamys sabanus represents a complex of several similar species. Further studies are needed to clarify the taxonomic status of populations currently allocated to this species. (Musser and Carleton 2005).
The relationship of Leopoldamys neilli to other Leopoldamys spp. requires resolution (Musser and Carleton 2005).
This species was formerly considered a subspecies of Leopoldamys edwardsi (Musser and Carleton 2005). Balakirev et al. (2013) confirmed L. milleti as a distinct species.
The taxonomic status of populations in the two geographic areas needs to be assessed. This species was formerly considered a subspecies of Leopoldamys edwardsi (Musser and Carleton 2005).
This concept of Hybomys badius follows Denys et al. (2014) in considering H. eisentrauti as a valid separate species.
Represented by a small extant series from the northern peninsula, and by both modern specimens and subfossils from the south western peninsula of Sulawesi (Musser 1970, 1984).

The taxonomic status of this poorly known species requires further molecular examination and morphometric analysis of specimens (Monadjem et al. 2015). It has previously been included within Thallomys paedulcus and T. nigricauda (Ellerman et al. 1953). While it is currently recognised as a distinct species (Bronner et al. 2003, Musser and Carleton 2005, Skinner and Chimimba 2005), its relationship with other species of this genus has not been fully resolved (Monadjem et al. 2015). It can be distinguished from T. nigricauda by its smaller bullae and indistinct black facial mask (Monadjem et al. 2015).

There is a lot of geographic variation is present and probably represents a complex as it occurs continuously from lowland areas up into high elevations. A taxonomic review is needed (L. Heaney pers. comm.).
Generic synonym = Rattus.
Formerly included in D. incomtus but elevated to a full species by Carleton & Martinez (1991).
Generic synonym = Thamnomys.

Represented only by the holotype. In many characters, R. koopmani resembles the Sulawesian R. hoffmanni and bears the same degree of relationship to that species as the Peleng R. pelurus does to mainland R. xanthurus. More specimens are needed to assess morphological variation and better estimate phylogenetic affinity (Musser and Holden 1991). Occurs with R. pelurus, a member of the R. xanthurus group. No other species of Rattus have been found on Pulau Peleng, but past biological surveys have been limited (Musser and Carleton 2005).
This species is often considered to be part of Rattus niobe. It was recognized provisionally as a distinct species by Musser and Carleton (2005) pending further study of the R. niobe complex.
Generic synonym = Rattus.
Synonym = R. ruber.
Synonym = R. tatei.
What is currently called, Rattus novaeguineae, might contain more than one species.
This species is closely related to Rattus losea (K. Aplin pers. comm.).

Although Rattus marmosurus has been listed as a subspecies of R. xanthurus (Ellerman 1941, Laurie and Hill 1954), most researchers besides Thomas have recognized its specific uniqueness (Misonne 1969, Musser 1971, Musser 1984, Musser and Holden 1991, Sody 1941, Tate 1936). Furthermore, the two are sympatric in north east Sulawesi (Musser 1971). R. facetus is close relative, but considered a distinct species (Handika et al. 2021).

Rattus omichlodes has been considered previously as a synonym of R. richardsoni and R. niobe, and has been confused with R. arrogans (a member of the R. niobe complex) with which it may be synonymous. We follow Musser and Carleton (2005) who provisionally treat R. omichlodes as a distinct species pending further taxonomic study of Rattus niobe and its relatives.
Phylogenetically distant from other species of Rattus endemic to the Philippines (Musser and Heaney 1992).
The species is closely related to Rattus hoffmanni. Further taxonomic research is needed as there is some uncertainty surrounding its status.

Ellerman (1961) included this species under subgenus Rattus Fischer, 1803. Corbet and Hill (1992) remark that “it has been suggested that this name might be based upon a ‘sample of extremely large Rattus rattus kelaarti males’ (McKay, 1984) but the teeth are very distinctive and preclude that possibility, a conclusion supported by Musser (1986)”. Phillips (1980) gives a detailed account of this species.
Populations in the highlands might represent a distinct species (T. Leary pers. comm.).
This species is closely related to Rattus tiomanicus (Musser 1986).

Ellerman (1961) treated this species along with Rattus burrulus (Miller, 1902) and Rattus burrescens (Miller, 1902) as conspecific. Corbet and Hill (1992) synonymized all the three species under Rattus tiomanicus (Miller, 1900) with doubtful status, and further commented that the "inclusion of the forms on the Andaman Islands is tentative, although the three forms described from there, burrus, burrulus and burrescens, are very similar to each other and probably conspecific". Agrawal (2000) remarks this being close to Rattus rattus (Linnaeus, 1758) and also mentions that the recent study by Musser and Heaney (1985) shows its affinity to Rattus tiomanicus (Miller, 1900).

Still known only by the holotype. Although Sody (1940) described adustus as a species, he later listed it as a subspecies of R. rattus in a section also containing lugens and mentawai, populations endemic to the Mentawai islands (Sody 1941). In morphology and geographic proximity, R. adustus is related to R. lugens, the two are allies of R. simalurensis from the Simalur Archipelago, and all three share close kinship with Sundaic R. tiomanicus (Musser and Heaney 1985). Rattus adustus, R. enganus, and R. tiomanicus are the only native Rattus (and the sole native murines) on Pulau Enggano (Musser and Carleton 2005).
This species is often considered to be a subspecies of Rattus niobe. It was recognized provisionally as a distinct species by Musser and Carleton (2005) pending further study of the R. niobe complex.
Formerly known as Rattus jalorensis, this species is closely related to Rattus baluensis (Musser 1986).

Some of the large series of subfossil fragments collected in east Timor by Glover (1986) may be this species. Phylogenetic affinities unclear (Kitchener et al. 1991). Albumin immunological analysis suggests a close phyletic affinity with Bunomys chrysocomus from Sulawesi and Komodomys rintjanus from Nusa Tenggara (Watts and Baverstock 1994); the close alliance between rintjanus and timorensis, and their great phylogenetic distance from Rattus, is supported by a recent unpublished allozyme electrophoresis study (K. Aplin in litt.. 2004). Recently K. Helgen (in litt.. 2003) collected an extant specimen from a forest fragment on Timor that is not R. timorensis, but an undescribed species that is also represented by large series in Glover’s subfossil collections.
Synonym = R. leucopus.

Still represented only by the holotype and another specimen. Originally described as a species (Miller, 1942), but later included in R. tiomanicus (Musser and Califia 1982, Corbet and Hill 1992, Musser and Carleton 1993). Recent multivariate analyses employing morphometric traits of Sundaic samples of the R. tiomanicus complex indicate blangorum to be distinct from all other insular samples in that assemblage (Musser and Carleton 2005). The taxonomic validity of this species is in question (D. Lunde and K. Aplin pers. comm.).
Further taxonomic research is needed as it's currently unclear to what extent this species differs from others in the Rattus xanthurus species group.
Generic synonym = Melomys.
The taxonomic status of a number of populations needs to be re-evaluated.
Nesoromys ceramicus has been included in the genus Stenomys by some authors (Flannery 1995).

The taxonomic relationship between Chiruromys forbesi and Pogonomys fergussoniensis needs to be resolved. The population from Sudest Island is being described by G. Musser as a new species, which will need to be assessed in due course.
This species often listed as Pogonomelomys bruijni (e.g., Flannery 1995a, b; Musser and Carleton 2005), but the correct spelling from Peters and Doria (1876) is bruijnii.

This species is considered to be a subspecies of Pogonomelomys bruijnii by Musser and Carleton (2005), but it appears to be distinct morphologically to the extent that it should be treated as a separate species pending further taxonomic work (Helgen 2007).
Generic synonym = Melomys.
Originally described as the only species in Mindanaomys (Sanborn 1953), but that genus is considered inseparable from Batomys (Misonne 1969; Musser and Heaney 1992; Musser et al. 1998).

Haeromys minahassae is the only described species of Haeromys from Sulawesi. However, the individuals recorded from montane forests in the central core of the island may represent an undescribed species of Haeromys (Musser and Carleton 2005, Musser 2014).
This is a newly described species from the Kalinga province in northern Luzon Island, Philippines (Balete et al. 2006).

On the northeast peninsula, B. chrysocomus is sympatric with B. fratrorum; in the central core of the island it is marginally sympatric with B. andrewsi at low elevations and B. penitus in montane forest.

There is a lot of morphological variation in collected specimens, and this name may represent more than one species (G. Musser pers. comm.); this species is sometimes referred to as a species complex.
Sometimes considered to be a synonym of A. cahirinus, but recognized as an independent species by Musser and Carleton (2005).
Was previously considered under A. cahirinus.

A poorly defined species. Likely to be part of Acomys cahirinus, but currently recognized as valid (see Barome et al. 2001, and Musser and Carleton 2005 for discussion). Studies by Frynta et al. (2010) and Giagia-Athanasopoulou et al. (2011) also support that this is a subspecies of A. cahirinus.

The species is highly variable at least in pelage color and there is taxonomic uncertainty regarding some populations, the genetic boundary between this species and P. cumingi requires clarification. There is uncertainty whether this species is valid (L. Heaney pers. comm.)
Phloemys cumingi is sometimes considered conspecific with P. pallidus, but P. cumingi is a distinct species (Corbet and Hill 1992, Musser and Heaney 1992, Thomas 1898).
Generic synonym = Mus.
The extent of morphological and genetic variation (and its taxonomic significance) across the markedly discontinuous range of Xeromys myoides is poorly resolved.
Species one of the undescribed species mentioned in Flannery (1990).
This is a species complex which requires systematic revision (K. Aplin, G. Musser and D. Lunde pers. comm.).

Treated in the past as a subspecies of M. surifer, but morphological features support its independence as a species; uncertain whether M. panglima is more closely related to M. surifer or M. rajah (Musser et al. 1979).

This species was once regarded as conspecific with Maxomys surifer (Ellerman and Morrison-Scott 1951, Misonne 1969). It occurs sympatrically with that species and although samples of each are regularly misidentified, the two differ in a suite of morphological, ecological, behavioural, and biochemical traits, as well as albumin immunology (Chan et al. 1979, Corbet and Hill 1992, Musser et al. 1979, Yong 1972, Watts and Baverstock 1994).

Originally described as a species by Robinson and Kloss (1922), later listed as a subspecies of either Maxomys surifer or Rattus coxingi (=Niviventer coninga), but finally reinstated as a distinct species (Musser et al. 1979, Van Peenen et al. 1969).
Generic synonym = Rattus.
We follow Happold (in press) by including Dephomys eburneae in D. defua.

Zyzomys argurus is remarkable for its genetic uniformity; Queensland and Northern Territory populations are not genetically distinct. Pilbara populations do show some signs of allopatric divergence, but at a very shallow level (F. Ford pers. comm.).
This species is listed as Zyzomys palatilis by Musser and Carleton (2005), but the correct spelling is Z. palatalis.
No subspecies are recognised for Leporillus conditor.
Previously listed as a subspecies of A. chrysophilus.
Previously listed as a subspecies of A. hindei.
Flannery (1990) states that the species is only known from the type series collected on Mount Kunupi, Irian Jaya in 1933.
Further studies are required to determine whether the northern and central records are the same species (Musser and Carleton 2005).
This may be a species complex (K. Helgen pers. comm.).

The Thevenard Island form was previously thought to be a distinct taxon found on islands, but research has shown that this is merely a larger form of the same species. Further taxonomic study may be warranted to consider the extent and implications of morphological variation across the species's extensive range.
Generic synonym = Rattus.
This distinctive species is replaced at higher elevations by Tarsomys apoensis in the region of Mt. Katangland (Musser and Carleton 2005).
This species was previously included in the genus Melomys.
It remains somewhat uncertain as to whether Mylomys rex represents a valid species. See Musser and Carleton (2005) for a detailed summary of the difficulties surrounding this taxon.
A split from A. niloticus.
A split from A. niloticus.
