Lutra sumatrana was first described by Raffles in 1822 as Lutra barang; by Gray in 1865 as Barangia sumatrana; and Lutra lovii by Gunther 1876. Pohle (1919) identified three species L. sumatrana in Sumatra, Malay Penisula and Thailand, L. lovii and L. brunnea in Borneo. Pocock 1941 compiled three species to L. sumatrana including in Vietnam. Recent genetic studies have confirmed it as a single species related to Lutra lutra (Koepfli et al. 2008).

The species was named as Lutra perspicillata by Geoffroy 1826 and as Lutrogale perspicillata by Gray 1865. Two subspecies were reported (Pocock 1941) (1) L. p. perspicillata - in northeast and southern India, Myanmar and Sumatra; and (2) L. p. sindica - in north and northwestern India and Pakistan. Another subspecies L. p. maxwelli, whose current status is uncertain, is reported from the marshes of southern Iraq (Mason and Macdonald 1986).

The spelling of the species epithet as Aonyx cinerea (Illiger, 1815) was incorrect; the genus name 'Aonyx' is masculine and hence the adjectival species name 'cinerea' should be changed to have a masculine ending. The species is now correctly named as A. cinereus (Illiger, 1815).

Also referred to as Amblonyx cinereus (Illiger, 1815), Amblonyx concolor Rafinesque, 1832 and Amblonyx cinerea Pocock 1941. Two subspecies have been reported (Pocock 1941): (1) A. c. concolor in northeast India, Myanmar extending to Sumatra, and (2) A. c. nirnai in the hill ranges of southern India (Hussain et al. 2011).

There are no recognized subspecies of Sylvilagus robustus (Hall 1981). Sylvilagus robustus was formerly considered a subspecies of S. floridanus, but has been shown to be an independent species (Ruedas 1998, Lee, Pfau and Ammerman 2010, Ruedas and Dowler 2018).

No subspecies. Only three specimens definitively identified as Sylvilagus tapetillus exist. The Rio de Janeiro Dwarf Cottontail was originally described as an independent species, and later subsumed as a subspecies of the Tapetí (S. brasiliensis). Recently, on the basis of a comprehensive morphological evaluation, cytochrome-B data, and karyotypic attributes, it was classified as independent and removed from synonymy from brasiliensis (Bonvicino et al. 2015, Ruedas et al. 2017).
Sylvilagus sanctaemartae was recently removed from synonymy from S. brasiliensis (Ruedas 2017, Ruedas et al. 2017).

Sylvilagus andinus was originally described as an independent species, and later subsumed as a subspecies of S. brasiliensis. Historically it has gone back and forth between these two assessments, but recently was classified as independent and removed from synonymy from brasiliensis (Ruedas et al. 2017). However, its taxonomic and geographic boundaries remain nebulous. It may include as many as 15 subspecies in what could be called a “polytypic S. andinus group”: S. capsalis, S. kelloggi, S. a. carchensis, S. a. chotanus, S. chillae, S. andinus, S. a. canarius, S. a. chimbanus, S. nivicola, S. salentus, S. fulvescens, S. apollinaris, S. purgatus, S. nicefori, and S. meridensis. The taxon purgatus may not belong in this assemblage (Ruedas and Smith 2018).
There are no recognized subspecies of Sylvilagus cognatus, which was formerly included as a subspecies of S. floridanus (Hall 1981).

This species along is thought to be parapatric with respect to C. becarii. Altitudinal segregation exists between the two species, with this species occurring at lower elevations, but the extent of any overlap is not known (Ruedi 1995).

Previously regarded as a single species, Gemsbok (O. gazella) and Beisa Oryx (O. beisa), from East Africa, are now considered distinct species based on taxonomic results revealing high (40%) genetic divergence between haplotypes (Osmers et al. 2012), morphology and geographic distribution (Grubb 2005). Osmers et al. (2012) do, however, recommend further molecular investigations into the genetics of the species to confirm their results. Currently, no subspecies have been identified within the assessment region.

authority: Dung, Giao, Chinh, Touc, Arctander & MacKinnon, 1993
taxonomicNotes: This species is in a highly distinctive monotypic genus with uncertain affinities within the Bovidae (Gatesy and Arctander 2000, R.J. Timmins pers. comm. 2006).

Based on the number of pale transverse stripes on the body (Haltenorth 1963), four African subspecies of Tragelaphus strepsiceros have been recorded (Ansell 1972); although only T. s. strepsiceros is present in southern Africa (Skinner & Chimimba 2005).

In the past the single family was included in the order Insectivora, but now the family is in the monophyletic order Macroscelidea and the newly created super-cohort Afrotheria. Currently, there are 19 living species recognized in four genera. The soft-furred sengis or elephant-shrews include three genera: Petrodromus is monospecific, Macroscelides has three species, and Elephantulus contains 11 species. The four species of giant sengis belong to the genus Rhynchocyon. The common name "sengi" is being used in place of elephant-shrew by many biologists to try and disassociate the Macroscelidea from the true shrews (family Soricidae) in the order Soricomorpha. See the Afrotheria Specialist Group web site and www.sengis.org for additional information.

The taxonomy of Phascogale tapoatafa is unresolved. It was long considered a single, widely distributed species (Ride 1970). Based on morphological analysis, Rhind et al. (2001) proposed three subspecies: P. t. tapoatafa from south-eastern Australia, P. t. pirata from northern Australia (Kimberley and Northern Territory) and an unnamed subspecies from south-western Australia. Using genetic analyses, Spencer et al. (2001) proposed that Phascogale comprised four distinct lineages: the three groups mentioned above plus P. calura, and inferred that the three taxa within P. tapoatafa be recognised as full species. Later, Soderquist and Rhind (2008) recognised the Northern Territory, but not the Kimberley, population as P. pirata, labelling the Kimberley population as an undescribed subspecies; however no analyses supporting this taxonomy have been published. In this Action Plan, we have followed this taxonomy. M. Westerman et al. (pers. comm.) have unpublished genetic data supporting the separation of P. pirata from P. tapoatafa, but have been unable to obtain samples from Kimberley animals. As currently recognised, there are three subspecies:

P. t. tapoatafa is Near Threatened;

P. t. (south-western Australia) is Near Threatened;

P. t. (Kimberley) is Endangered.
Often confused with bogotensis (Simmons 2005).

Temminck originally described the African Wild Dog (hereafter Wild Dog) in 1820 from a specimen collected in coastal Mozambique, which was originally thought to be species of hyaena and was classified as Hyena picta (Creel & Creel 2002). Later, in 1930, it was placed in the subfamily Canidae (Creel & Creel 2002) and today, Wild Dogs belong to the family Canidae. DNA sequencing suggests that Wild Dogs are phylogenetically distinct from other wolf-like canids (such as wolves and jackals) (Creel & Creel 2002). Thus, they are considered to be a monotypic genus where they are the only remaining representatives of the genus Lycaon (Mills et al 1998; Creel & Creel 2002).

Based on a recent taxonomic split, the Central African populations of Megaloglossus woermanni are now recognized as a distinct species and distinguished from the newly established West African species M. azagnyi (Nesi et al. 2013). The study used molecular and morphological data which revealed high genetic differences that clearly support the species split, even though the two species show high morphological similarity, with M. woermanni being slightly larger. The limits of the distribution of M. woermanni are currently not known, and it is not clear if it occurs in sympatry with M. azagnyi. Molecular data of individuals from Benin and Nigeria is required to allocate exact species boundaries.

Meester et al. (1986) recognised three subspecies, including the nominate subspecies (Taphozous perforatus perforatus) from Egypt (where this species was initially described), T. p. sudani Thomas, 1915 from Sudan, and T. p. haedinus Thomas, 1915 from Kenya. However, it remains uncertain how the geographically isolated southern African population (named T. p. rhodesiae, and described from the Shashi-Limpopo confluence; Harrison 1964) is related to these subspecies (Monadjem et al. 2010). T. p. rhodesiae was originally recognised as a subspecies of T. sudani (T. sudani australis), which was previously identified as a distinct species from T. perforatus (ACR 2015).

Mickelburgh et al. (1992) noted that two sub species (Epomops f. franqueti and E. f. strepitans) had been described but observed that Bergmans (1989) found these to be poorly differentiated and synonymized them. Simmons (2005) in Wilson and Reeder (2005) therefore also does not recognize the sub species for this taxon.
Generic synonym = Capromys.
May be taxonomic issues.

This species was initially classified in the genus Bradypus, as it was thought that it was related to South American sloths, due to the absence of the two first upper incisors. Debate persists as to whether this species should be in the mono-specific genus Melursus, or in Ursus (Pagès et al. 2008, Krause et al. 2008, Kitchener 2010).

Two subspecies have been recognized. There is some evidence that they are distinct genetic clades (Fain et al. 1994). Melursus ursinus inornatus only occurs on the island of Sri Lanka and is physically smaller with shorter and sparser hair than its mainland (M. u. ursinus) counterpart.

The principal colour phase is black, with a white or cream/yellow crescent on the chest. Rusty brown phases are also known. The species is often confused with the Asiatic Black Bear (Ursus thibetanus), due to similar appearance.

There are currently five generally recognized subspecies:
  1. Equus hemionus hemionus - the Mongolian khulan (in northern Mongolia) (E. h. luteus - the Gobi khulan or dziggetai in southern Mongolia and northern China, is probably a synonym of E. h. hemionus (Oakenfull et al. 2000, Grubb 2005, Kaczensky et al. 2011a)
  2. E. h. khur – the khur (India)
  3. E. h. kulan – the Turkmen kulan (in Turkmenistan, re-introduced in Kazakhstan, Uzbekistan, Ukraine and mixed E. h. kulan x E. h. onager in Israel)
  4. E. h. onager - the onager (Iran and re-introduced and mixed E. h. kulan x E. h. onager in Israel)
  5. E. h. hemippus – the Syrian wild ass (Extinct, formerly from the eastern shore of the Mediterranean Sea south into the Arabian Peninsula)
However, the taxonomic arrangement of equids is quite complicated and modern (particularly genetic) analyses may result in future changes or clarifications (Oakenfull and Ryder 2002).

Recent genetic analysis of archaeological, historical and modern samples indeed suggest that there is only one species of Asiatic Wild Ass (Bennett et al. 2012, Bennett et al. in prep., assigning the modern Equus hemionus and Equus kiang as well as Equus hydruntinus which went extinct during the Holocene (Crees and Turvey 2014) to the same species), which is subdivided into regional subpopulations rather than subspecies. Comparative analysis of modern samples of Equus hemionus from Iran (E. h. onager) and China (E. h. hemionus) and Equus kiang also did not support monophyly (Rosenbom et al. 2015). However, this Red List assessment does not include Equus kiang and did not attempt to include semi-reserves where Equus hemionus was reintroduced in central or western Europe – the former distribution range of Equus hydruntinus.

authority: Heaney, Balete, Rickart, Alviola, Duya, Duya, Veluz, VandeVrede & Steppan, 2011
Peterhans, Hutterer, Mwanga, Ndara, Davenport, Karhagomba & Udelhoven, 2010
Helgen, Pinto, Kays, Helgen, Tsuchiya, Quinn, Wilson & Maldonado, 2013
taxonomicNotes: The genus Bassaricyon was revised by Helgen et al. (2013), who noted that this species lacked any available name, although individuals in the pavt had been misidentified as B. alleni. Four subspecies have been identified; B. n. herzhkovitzi, B. n. neblina, B. n. osborni and B. n ruber.
The genus Bassaricyon was revised by Helgen et al. (2013), who recognised two subspecies of B. medius: B. m. medius and B. m. orinomus.

Two subspecies have been named: C. d. dorsalis in West Africa from Guinea-Bissau to Togo and C. d. castaneus from east of the Niger river in Nigeria through Central Africa to the Albertine Rift and south to northern Angola (Kingdon and Feer 2013). These forms are based on body size and pelage features, though Grubb and Groves (2001) note considerable variation in C. d. castaneus.

authority: Ojala-Barbour, Pinto, Brito M., Albuja V., Lee Jr. & Patterson, 2013

taxonomicNotes: Margaretamys christinae is the fourth species from the genus to be identified (M. beccarii, M. elegans and M. parvus) (Mortelliti et al. 2012). Margaretamys is a member of the Dacnomys division of Murinae (Pagès et al. 2016).

Nesi et al. (2013) recently elevated the taxon Myonycteris leptodon to species rank. This species was originally described by Anderson (1908), but synonymised with Myonytceris torquata by Bergmans (1976) and has remained in synonymy since then (e.g. Simmons 2005). However, recent molecular analyses have shown that M. leptodon from West Africa differs by 4.8-6.6% in its Cytochrome_b sequence from M. torquata from Central Africa (Nesi et al. 2013). The two species are morphologically similar, but their distributions appear to be non-overlapping.

Previously this was assessed as the subspecies Lophostoma silvicolum occidentalis. But according to Velazco and Cadenillas (2011), the congruence between the morphological and molecular variation support the recognition of L. occidentalis as a valid species and the consideration of L. aequatorialis as a junior synonym of L. occidentalis.

This species has been recently described by Martínez-Lanfranco et al. (2014), based on genetic and morphologic characters, which clearly separate the species from the commonly known, and more wide-spread Lutreolina crassicaudata. Lutreolina massoia is smaller in size than L. crassicaudata, both externally and for craniodental characters.

Rousettus obliviosus was previously considered to be a subspecies of R. madagascariensis (e.g., Peterson et al. 1995), but the two forms have been shown to be distinct species (Kock 1978, Goodman et al. 2010a).

Tupaia ferruginea hypochrysa was originally described  by Thomas (1895), but was later elevated to T. hypochrysa by Lyon (1913), who included it with T. chrysogaster in his ‘Hypochrysa Group’. Chasen (1940) synonymised T. hypochrysa with T. glis, a decision followed in subsequent classifications (Honacki et al. 1982, Wilson 1993, Helgen 2005). It has been recently resurrected as T. hypochrysa from Java (Sargis et al. 2013).

Described as Tupaia ferruginea Raffles (1821), from Bencoolen, Sumatra. Considered a subspecies of T. glis by Lyon (1913). This taxon generally remains in synonymy with T. glis (Chasen 1940, Corbet and Hill 1992, Helgen 2005, Honacki et al. 1982, Wilson 1993). T. ferruginea is now recognised as a distinct species restricted to Sumatra and Tanahbala (Sargis et al. 2013, Sargis et al. 2014).

Seven subspecies have been recognized, many of which have been corroborated as distinct genetic clades (Kim et al. 2011, Yusefi 2013, Wu et al. 2015).

This species was previously included in the genus Selenarctos (meaning moon bear). The principal colour phase is black, with a white or cream/yellow “crescent moon” on the chest. Rare brown phases are also known, and a rare blond colour phase was discovered in Cambodia, Thailand, and Lao People’s Democratic Republic (Galbreath et al. 2000). One case of a wild Asiatic Black Bear–Sun Bear (Helarctos malayanus) hybrid has been reported in Cambodia (Galbreath et al. 2008).

authority: Fan, He, Chen, Ortiz, Zhang, Zhao, Lio, Zhang, Kimock, Wang, Groves, Turvey, Roos, Helgen & Jiang, 2017
taxonomicNotes: This taxon is monotypic; it was formerly considered a population of H. leuconedys. The previous generic name, Bunopithecus, was changed by Mootnick and Groves (2005) to Hoolock (Haimoff  1984).

Prosciurillus alstoni is a member of a species group that includes P. leucomus, P. weberi, P. topapuensis, and P. rosenbergii, all endemic to Sulawesi and nearby islands (Musser et al. 2016). On mainland Sulawesi, P. leucomus, P. alstoni, P. weberi, and P. topapuensis have allopatric ranges relative to each other.

Modern taxonomic arrangements of the colobus monkeys either distinguish the red colobus monkeys and the Olive Colobus as separate genera, Piliocolobus and Procolobus, respectively (e.g., Groves 2001, 2005, 2007; Roos et al. 2011, Kingdon 2015), or consider them to belong to one genus Procolobus, with two subgenera (Procolobus for the Olive Colobus and Piliocolobus for the red colobus) (Oates et al. 1994, Grubb et al. 2003, 2013; Oates 2011). Ting (2008) placed all the red colobus as subspecies of Procolobus (Piliocolobus) badius. The 2008 IUCN Red List assessments followed the taxonomy of Grubb et al. (2003).

The arrangement of two genera in Groves (2001, 2005, 2007) is followed here: a monotypic Procolobus de Rochebrune, 1887 (Olive Colobus) and polytypic Piliocolobus de Rochebrune, 1887 (red colobus).

Piliocolobus tholloni was treated as a subspecies of Procolobus pennanti [sic] by Gautier-Hion et al. (1999). Grubb et al. (2013) and Struhsaker and Grubb (2013), on the other hand, considered it a subspecies of P. rufomitratus. Groves (2001, 2005, 2007), Groves and Ting (2013). Kingdon (2015) treated tholloni as a distinct species.

Modern taxonomic arrangements of the colobus monkeys either distinguish the red colobus monkeys and the Olive Colobus as separate genera, Piliocolobus and Procolobus, respectively (e.g., Groves 2001, 2005, 2007; Roos et al. 2011, Kingdon 2015), or consider them to belong to one genus Procolobus, with two subgenera (Procolobus for the Olive Colobus and Piliocolobus for the red colobus) (Oates et al. 1994, Grubb et al. 2003, 2013; Oates 2011). Ting (2008) placed all the red colobus as subspecies of Procolobus (Piliocolobus) badius. The 2008 IUCN Red List assessments followed the taxonomy of Grubb et al. (2003).

The arrangement of two genera in Groves (2001, 2005, 2007) is followed here: a monotypic Procolobus de Rochebrune, 1887 (Olive Colobus) and polytypic Piliocolobus de Rochebrune, 1887 (red colobus).

Colyn (1991) and Groves (2007) suggested that oustaleti is one of between three (Groves 2007) and five (Colyn 1991) forms contributing to what is commonly regarded as a hybrid population of red colobus that occurs immediately to the south of the range of P. oustaleti and extends to the southern forest – savanna ecotone in eastern DRC, at about 4°S. Groves (2007) referred this intergraded taxon as “ellioti”.

As its synonyms indicate, this population of red colobus monkeys has been classified under a number of different names, sometimes regarded as a species, a subspecies, or just as a local population of a subspecies. In the last edition of the Red List, it was treated as a subspecies of P. rufomitratus, which included the subspecies rufomitratus, semlikiensis, foai, langi, oustaleti, parmentieri, tephrosceles and tholloni. Struhsaker and Grubb (2013) continue to place it as a subspecies of rufomitratus, along with ellioti, foai. langi, lulindicus, parmentieri, tephrosceles and tholloni.

Kingdon (1997), following Colyn (1991), treated oustaleti as the Central African Red Colobus, with parmentieri, foai, langi, lulindicus, ellioti, semlikiensis and tephrosceles as subspecies. Kingdon (2015) maintained the same classification, expect that he placed semilikiensis as a synonym of ellioti.

Gautier-Hion et al. (1999) regarded P. oustaleti as a complex of six forms, three west of the Ubangui (P. oustaleti sensu stricto with synonyms umbrinus Matschie, and nigrimanus Trouessart, and an undescribed form from the vicinity of the Lobaye River, a tributary of the lower Ubangui, Central African Republic) and three to the east (shubotzi Matschie, powelli Matschie, and brunneus Lönnberg with synonym multicolor Lorenz). Piliocolobus oustaleti is known to be highly variable in coat colour (Colyn 1993, Struhsaker 2010, Struhsaker and Grubb 2013). Ting (2008) found considerable mitochondrial genetic diversity among populations included within P. oustaleti sensu lato and suggested that either oustaleti might consist of numerous taxa, or that there have been past introgressions of mitochondrial lineages between neighbouring forms.

Grubb et al. (2003) considered oustaleti as a subspecies but did not assign it to species. Its synonyms included brunneus Lönnberg, powelli Matschie, nigrimanus Trouessart, and schubotzi Matschie. 

Groves (2007) treated oustaleti as a monotypic species, but with four “types”: 1) a dark brown type (oustaleti, powelli and, most extreme, umbrinus and schubotzi); 2) a raw sienna type in the Ubangui/Lobaye basins in the Central African Republic (unnamed and possibly the unnamed form mentioned by Gautier-Hion et al. 1999); 3) a brownish-fawn type from the Uele gallery forest region in DRC (brunneus) in the east; and 4) a red type (nigrimanus in the west. Groves (2001) placed oustaleti as a subspecies of foai, but also mentioning the four types as described in his 2007 revision.

For the purpose of this assessment, we follow Groves (2007) in treating this evidently diverse taxon as a single taxonomic entity. However, we recognise that the taxonomic status of this form remains fluid (Struhsaker 2010).

Modern taxonomic arrangements of the colobus monkeys either distinguish the red colobus monkeys and the Olive Colobus as separate genera, Piliocolobus and Procolobus, respectively (e.g., Groves 2001, 2005, 2007; Roos et al. 2011, Kingdon 2015), or consider them to belong to one genus Procolobus, with two subgenera (Procolobus for the Olive Colobus and Piliocolobus for the red colobus) (Oates et al. 1994, Grubb et al. 2003, 2013; Oates 2011). Ting (2008) placed all the red colobus as subspecies of Procolobus (Piliocolobus) badius. The 2008 IUCN Red List assessments followed the taxonomy of Grubb et al. (2003).

The arrangement of two genera in Groves (2001, 2005, 2007) is followed here: a monotypic Procolobus de Rochebrune, 1887 (Olive Colobus) and polytypic Piliocolobus de Rochebrune, 1887 (red colobus).

Groves (2001, 2005, 2007), Grubb et al. (2003) and Kingdon (2015) treated rufomitratus as a monotypic species. Considering vocalisations and pelage colour patterns, however, Grubb et al. (2013) noted that tephrosceles, ellioti (semlikiensis a synonym), oustaleti, langi, lulindicus, foai, parmentieri and tholloni were similar, if isolated, forms, and placed them all as subspecies of rufomitratus. Excepting lulindicus (a synonym of foai) and ellioti (possibly a three-way hybrid swarm), Groves (2007) treated all, including semlikiensis, as species.

Grubb et al. (2003) treated Cercopithecus wolfi as one of seven subspecies of C. pogonias: pogonias, nigripes, grayi, denti, wolfi, elegans and pyrogaster. The 2008 IUCN Red List followed this taxonomy and assessed C. wolfi as the subspecies C. pogonias wolfi. Gautier-Hion et al. (1999) considered C. wolfi as a distinct species and included denti, elegans and pyrogaster as subspecies of C. wolfi. Groves (2001, 2005), Gautier-Hion (2013), Healy (2013) and Kingdon (2015) treated C. denti and C. wolfi as distinct species with wolfi, elegans and pyrogaster as subspecies of the latter.

In Guschanski et al.’s (2013) phylogenetic study of mitochondrial DNA, wolfi and elegans were most closely related with minimal divergence, and pyrogaster was the sister taxon to the elegans and wolfi clade. Likewise, in a recent phylogenetic study of the Y-chromosome’s TSPY gene (~900 base pair fragment) elegans and wolfi had the same Y-DNA haplotype, suggesting a common, recent ancestry (Leroy 2016). Thus, the genetic evidence supports elegans as a subspecies of wolfi and not a sister taxon to denti, as suggested by Sarmiento and Kingdon (2013).

Recent fieldwork indicates that C. w. elegans forms a cline in pelage coloration, with the palest forms occurring at the southern limits of the range in the forest-savanna ecotone, and the more brightly coloured forms, approaching colouration of the nominate subspecies, to the north and west (Colyn 1988, Niehoff 2016).

The 2016 assessment follows the recent consensus to elevate wolfi to species level and to recognise the three subspecies C. wolfi wolfi, C. w. elegans and C. w. pyrogaster.
This new species is a member of the Hipposideros bicolor group.

Modern taxonomic arrangements of the colobus monkeys either distinguish the red colobus monkeys and the Olive Colobus as separate genera, Piliocolobus and Procolobus, respectively (e.g., Groves 2001, 2005, 2007; Roos et al. 2011, Kingdon 2015), or consider them to belong to one genus Procolobus, with two subgenera (Procolobus for the Olive Colobus and Piliocolobus for the red colobus) (Oates et al. 1994, Grubb et al. 2003, 2013; Oates 2011). Ting (2008) placed all the red colobus as subspecies of Procolobus (Piliocolobus) badius. The 2008 IUCN Red List assessments followed the taxonomy of Grubb et al. (2003).

The arrangement of two genera in Groves (2001, 2005, 2007) is followed here: a monotypic Procolobus de Rochebrune, 1887 (Olive Colobus) and polytypic Piliocolobus de Rochebrune, 1887 (red colobus).

Piliocolobus parmentieri is little known, and its classification is inconsistent due to the significant complexity and debate in the taxonomy of red colobus monkeys (Groves 2001, Grubb et al. 2003, Struhsaker 2010, Grubb et al. 2013). Colyn and Verheyen (1987) noted that parmentieri differed strongly from tholloni and placed it as a subspecies of the polytypic rufomitratus. Colyn (1991) considered the Lomami Red Colobus to have a stable phenotype, supporting a distinct taxonomic status for the population. Gautier-Hion et al. (1999) treated it as a subspecies of Procolobus pennanti [sic]. Struhsaker and Grubb (2013) on the other hand identified it as one of nine subspecies of rufomitratus: foai, langi, oustaleti, parmentieri, tephrosceles, lulindicus, ellioti (semlikiensis a synonym), and tholloni. Groves and Ting (2013) elevated seven of the nine rufomitratus subspecies to distinct species; the subspecies ellioti and lulindicus were not recognised as distinct taxa. Kingdon (2015) treated it as a subspecies of oustaleti, along with foai, langi, lulindicus, elliotiand tephrosceles. Groves (2001, 2005) treated it as a subspecies of foai, along with ellioti, oustaleti, and semlikiensis, but in his 2007 review of the taxonomy of the African colobines he classified it as a separate species. The current assessment follows Groves (2007) in recognising parmentieri as a distinct species.

Gautier-Hion et al. (1999), Groves (2001, 2005) and Kingdon (2015) altered the epithet to the plural—parmentierorum, but Groves (2007) argued that it was possible (and more expedient) to maintain parmentieri.

Modern taxonomic arrangements of the colobus monkeys either distinguish the red colobus monkeys and the Olive Colobus as separate genera, Piliocolobus and Procolobus, respectively (e.g., Groves 2001, 2005, 2007; Roos et al. 2011, Kingdon 2015), or consider them to belong to one genus Procolobus, with two subgenera (Procolobus for the Olive Colobus and Piliocolobus for the red colobus) (Oates et al. 1994, Grubb et al. 2003, 2013; Oates 2011). Ting (2008) placed all the red colobus as subspecies of Procolobus (Piliocolobus) badius. The 2008 IUCN Red List assessments followed the taxonomy of Grubb et al. (2003).

The arrangement of two genera in Groves (2001, 2005, 2007) is followed here: a monotypic Procolobus de Rochebrune, 1887 (Olive Colobus) and polytypic Piliocolobus de Rochebrune, 1887 (Red Colobus).

The taxonomy of this form is complicated and not fully resolved. Piliocolobus langi was treated as a subspecies of Procolobus pennanti [sic] by Gautier-Hion et al. (1999). Kingdon (2015) considered it to be subspecific to Piliocolobus oustaleti. Colyn (1991) suggested that P. langi and P. semlikiensis (which he referred to as a subspecies of Colobus badius) of the eastern Congo Basin were major contributors to a population of polymorphic red colobus that he characterised as a large zone of intergradation between the ranges of the two taxa. Groves (2007) recognised langi and semlikiensis as valid species, and assigned the name “ellioti” to what he referred to as a three-way hybrid swarm between semlikiensis, langi and oustaleti, bound in the north by the Aruwimi River (with populations of P. oustaleti ranging north of that) and to the west by P. langi and east by P. semlikiensis, without apparent barriers to dispersal separating them. Genetic surveys to determine the origins and composition of red colobus populations over this zone of intergradation, and their relation to the proposed parental forms, have not been conducted. Based on mitochondrial DNA analysis, Ting (2008) suggested that, P. langi should be considered a subspecies of P. rufomitratus, along with (among others) the forms tholloni, oustaleti, parmentieri, foai and ellioti (which he treated as the senior synonym for semlikiensis). This classification is also largely accepted by Struhsaker and Grubb (2013), who stated that P[rocolobus]. r[ufomitratus]. ellioti “probably represents a large hybrid swarm involving langi and semlikiensis”. While we use Groves’ (2007) nomenclature here, we recognise that the taxonomic status of this form is not well settled.

While Grubb et al. (2003) did not list any subspecies of Lophocebus albigena, Groves (2001, 2005), building on his earlier work (Groves 1978) recognized three subspecies: L. a. albigena, L. a. johnstoni and L. a. osmani. After further studies of the cranial morphology of this group, Groves (2007) upgraded these three subspecies to species rank, and recognised a fourth, Lophocebus ugandae (Matschie 1912). This classification is followed by Mittermeier et al. (2013). However, at a Red List assessment workshop in 2016, experts from the IUCN SSC Primate Specialist Group were not in agreement about a four-species taxonomy and decided to retain a one-species, four-subspecies arrangement for the purposes of the current Red List.
Grubb et al. (2003) recognized two subspecies, L. a. aterrimus and L. a. opdenboschi, in contrast to Groves (2001, 2005) who considered the two as worthy of recognition as distinct species.

Byrne et al. (2016) split the genus Callicebus into three new genera, namely:  Cheracebus (torquatus-group sensu Roosmalen et al. 2002), Plecturocebus (cupreus-, moloch-, donacophilus-groups sensu Roosmalen et al. (2002) and Callicebus (personatus-group, sensu Roosmalen et al. 2002). According to Byrne et al. (2016), Plecturocebus includes 22 species.

authority: Pontes, Gadelha, Melo, de Sá, Loss Junior, Costa & Leite, 2013
taxonomicNotes: This species was described in 2013 (Mendes Pontes et al. 2013).
This species was placed in the genus Allosciurus by Rosevear (1969), Grubb et al. (1998), Schennum and Thorington (2013) and Monadjem et al. (2015).

authority: Lavrenchenko, W. Verheyen, E. Verheyen, Hulseman & Leirs, 2007
taxonomicNotes: Lophuromys chercherensis forms part of the L. flavopunctatus species complex (Lavrenchenko et al. 2007). Data show that L. chercherensis is differentiated from all known and newly recognised taxa of Ethiopian L. flavopunctatus (Lavrenchenko et al. 2004, Lavrenchenko et al. 2007).

Crocidura ninoyi is part of the Philippine clade of species, which includes C. beatus, C. grayi, C. mindorus, C. negrina, C. palawanensis, and C. panayensis. Upon further analysis C. ninoyi has been shown to be sister species of C. negrina, C. palawanensis. Conversely, a second specimen analysed believed to be C. ninoyi was in fact found to be further removed, with no evidence inferring it as a sister species to C. ninoyi (Giarla and Esselstyn 2015). This information could show a second species on Sibuyan island that has yet to be formally described and more research needs to be undertaken to understand the taxonomy and distribution of the two species.

This species is a closer relative to Crocidura species from Sulawesi rather than species from the Philippines, with studies suggesting no relationship with Crocidura species on Palawan island or neighbouring Mindoro island (Esselsytn et al. 2009). DNA analysis shows C. batakorum to be closely related to Crocidura elongata, and Crocidura lea suggesting speciation has occurred from over water colonization and subsequent allopatry (Esselstyn et al. 2009). The species was initially misidentified as Crocidura attenuate (Hutterer 2007).

Kingdon (1997) recognized two subspecies: C. c. cephus and C. c. cephodes. Subsequently, Colyn (1999) described the subspecies C. c. ngottoensis, which is included as a valid form in the classifications of Grubb et al. (2003) and Groves (2005). However, Grubb et al. (2003) remarked that the taxonomic status of ngottoensis needed more research because it appears to be both geographically and morphologically intermediate between C. cephus and C. ascanius. Gautier-Hion (2013) recognizes three subspecies C. c. cephus, C. c cephodes and C. c. ngottoensis.

Cercopithecus hamlyni, along with the recently discovered Lesula (Cercopithecus lomamiensis), form a clade of highly terrestrial monkeys restricted to lowland and montane forests of eastern Democratic Republic of Congo. Outside DRC, only one small isolated population of C. hamlyni is known from western Rwanda (Easton et al. 2011). Two subspecies have been named (see Grubb et al. 2003, Groves 2005, Hart et al. 2013): C. h. kahuziensis, characterized primarily by its lack of a prominent white nose stripe, is described from an area of the bamboo forest zone of Mount Kahuzi, DRC. C. h. hamlyni, is the form found throughout the remainder of the species' range. The range of C. h. kahuziensis, purportedly limited to a very small area between 2000 and 3000 m in Kahuzi-Biega National Park, is poorly defined and adjoins, without evident barriers, the range of the nominate form (Maruhashi et al. 1989). Recent surveys in Kahuzi-Biega identified C. h. hamlyni, with prominent white nose stripes, in areas reported to represent the range of C. h. kahuziensis (Hart and Kaleme, personal observation 2002). In addition, the nose stripe appears to be variably present in populations across the species’ range (Hart et al. 2013). The recent publication (Hart et al. 2012) of a photo of a young animal, kept as a pet, and collected east of Kisangani, about 350 km from the reported range of of C. h. kahuziensis, had no evidence of a nose stripe and resembles photographed animals described as C. h. kahuziensis in the publication of the taxon by Colyn and Rahm (1987). The subspecies, C. h. kahuziensis, is not treated further here, pending confirmation of its taxonomic status.

Molecular analysis shows Crocidura munissii to be a member of the Crocidura monax clade (Stanley et al. 2015). Although C. munissii is endemic to the southern Eastern Arc Mountains (EAM), it is a member of a clade that includes the East and West Usambaras (C. tansaniana), the South Pares (C. usambarae), Mt. Meru (Crocidura newmarki), Kilimanjaro and North Pare (Crocidura monax), and Ngorongoro (Crocidura mdumai). This geographic distribution of members of the C. monax clade is significant as it spans two geologically distinct mountains groups the Northern Highlands and the EAM (Stanley et al. 2015).
This species was listed under Hipposideros bicolor, but is now considered distinct following Douangboubpha et al. (2010).

The relationship of this species with others in this genus is unknown (Holden and Levine 2009, Holden et al. 2016, Monadjem et al. 2015). The allopatric West African endemic Graphiurus crassicaudatus is currently hypothesised to be its closest relative based upon morphology (Holden and Levine 2009, Holden et al. 2016). The geographic range of G. walterverheyeni may overlap with that of G. lorraineus and/or G. surdus, although neither species has been documented to occur at or even close to the two localities from which G. walterverheyeni is known (Holden and Levine 2009, Holden et al. 2016).

authority: Fabre, Pages, Musser, Fitriana, Semiadi & Helgen, 2013
taxonomicNotes: The genus is currently monotypic (Fabre et al. 2013).
C. lwiroensis is distinguishable from other members of the genus both externally and cranio-dentally (Kerbis Peterhans et al. 2013).

Modern taxonomic arrangements of the colobus monkeys either distinguish the red colobus monkeys and the Olive Colobus as separate genera, Piliocolobus and Procolobus, respectively (e.g., Kingdon 1997, Groves 2001, 2005, 2007; Roos et al. 2011), or consider them to belong to one genus Procolobus, with two subgenera (Procolobus for the Olive Colobus and Piliocolobus for the red colobus) (Oates et al. 1994, Grubb et al. 2003, 2013; Oates 2011). Ting (2008) placed all the red colobus as subspecies of Procolobus (Piliocolobus) badius. The 2008 IUCN Red List assessments followed the taxonomy of Grubb et al. (2003).

The arrangement of two genera in Groves (2001, 2005, 2007) is followed here: a monotypic Procolobus de Rochebrune, 1887 (Olive Colobus) and polytypic Piliocolobus de Rochebrune, 1887 (red colobus).

This taxon was long regarded as a subspecies of the Western Red Colobus P. badius, along with temminckii (e.g., Kingdon 1997, Grubb et al. 2003; see Oates and Ting 2015). Dandelot (1971) and Groves (2007) treated waldroni as a full species and, although Ting (2008a) continued to treat it as subspecies of badius, in his thesis Ting (2008b) indicated that it should be a species (see Oates and Ting 2015).

Groves (2007) used the name waldronae for this monkey; however, Brandon-Jones et al. (2007) argued that waldroni is the correct epithet, as it was first named.

Morphological, craniometric and phylogenetic analyses revealed that Fukomys livingstoni is distinct from other populations of Fukomys (Faulkes et al. 2017). It is suggested that historic geological and volcanic activity isolated F. livingstoni and F. hanangensis populations following their earlier dispersal into this region of East Africa, resulting in distinct evolutionary lineages (Faulkes et al. 2017). Based on morphology and molecular (DNA sequence) data, this species can be clearly distinguished from F. hanangensis and the neighbouring F. whytei, whose range extends into southwestern Tanzania (Faulkes et al. 2017).
Grubb et al. (2003) treat this as a subspecies of Cercocebus galeritus, but Groves (2005) and Kingdon (2001) both treat it as a distinct taxon.

Modern taxonomic arrangements of the colobus monkeys either distinguish the red colobus monkeys and the Olive Colobus as separate genera, Piliocolobus and Procolobus, respectively (e.g., Groves 2001, 2005, 2007; Roos et al. 2011, Kingdon 2015), or consider them to belong to one genus Procolobus, with two subgenera (Procolobus for the Olive Colobus and Piliocolobus for the red colobus) (Oates et al. 1994, Grubb et al. 2003, 2013; Oates 2011). Ting (2008) placed all the red colobus as subspecies of Procolobus (Piliocolobus) badius. The 2008 IUCN Red List assessments followed the taxonomy of Grubb et al. (2003).

The arrangement of two genera in Groves (2001, 2005, 2007) is followed here: a monotypic Procolobus de Rochebrune, 1887 (Olive Colobus) and polytypic Piliocolobus de Rochebrune, 1887 (red colobus).

Although considered a subspecies of badius by Rahm (1970) and of pennantii by Delson et al. (1982), all recent taxonomic appraisals have treated the Zanzibar Red Colobus as a monotypic species (Dandelot 1971, Napier 1985, Oates 1986, Kingdon 1997, 2015; Groves 2001, 2005, 2007; Grubb et al. 2013), Groves and Ting (2013), and Siex and Struhsaker (2013).

Although up to eight Chacma forms have been suggested in the literature (Hill 1970), today only three are commonly accepted (Jolly 1993, Groves 2001). These are: P. u. ursinus, P. u. griseipes, and P. u. ruacana. Papio u. ursinus, the typical Chacma, is a large baboon with black nape fringes, dark brown hair, black hair on hands and feet and a relatively short tail. This variant occurs in the more southerly and westerly part of the Chacma range, including South Africa and some parts of Botswana. This group incorporates Hill’s (1970) ursinus, orientalis and occidentalis subspecies. Papio ursinus griseipes, the Grey-footed Baboon, is more fawn coloured and found in southwestern Zambia, Zimbabwe, in Mozambique south of the Zambezi, in parts of the Limpopo Province of South Africa, and in the Okavango Delta, Botswana (Jolly 1993). These baboons are smaller than P. u. ursinus and have grey hands and feet, the same colour as their limbs, and a longer tail. This group incorporates Hill’s griesipes, ngamiensis, chobiensis and jubilaeus subspecies. Today it is clear that jubilaeus is in fact a Yellow Baboon and not a Chacma at all. Papio ursinus ruacana is a small black-footed baboon that is darker than P. u. griseipes and smaller than P. u. ursinus. It is found in Namibia and southwestern Angola (Groves 2001).

Mitochondrial genetic data confirm at least two distinct lineages within Chacma separating the species into northern (griseipes) and southern (ursinus) populations (Sithaldeen et al. 2009; Zinner et al. 2009). A third genetic clade may represent orientalis (Keller et al. 2010). As yet, no definitive data exist that distinguish a genetically distinct ruacana clade.
Listed as a separate species from Colobus polykomos following Oates and Trocco (1983) and Groves (2005).

The genus Oryctolagus appeared in the fossil record (Middle Pliocene) before any other modern leporid genus. Oryctolgus cuniculus was widespread across much of the Mediterranean area and central Europe in the Late Pleistocene, but following the maximum glacial period and Early Holocene it became confined to its current range in the Iberian Peninsula and adjoining areas in France (López-Martínez 2008).

Two subspecies are recognized: O. c. cuniculus and O. c. algirus. The latter is only present in the Iberian Peninsula and some islands, while the former occurs in most of the species’ introduced range. Based on genetic evidence they have apparently evolved independently beginning approximately 2 mya during the Quaternary glaciations (Ferrand 2008). The independence of these two subspecies has been reinforced by data on parasitology, behaviour, reproduction, and morphology (e.g. Gonçalves et al. 2002, Ferreira et al. 2015). Due to their genetic incompatibilities and reproductive isolation in their zone of contact in the middle of the Iberian Peninsula (e.g. Carneiro et al. 2010), some feel that they should be considered separate species (Delibes-Mateos et al. 2018). The domesticated rabbit originates from O. c. cuniculus.

Four subspecies are known:
Muntiacus reevesi jiangkouensis (mainland China);
Muntiacus reevesi reevesi (mainland China);
Muntiacus reevesi micrurus (Taiwan);
Muntiacus reevesi sinensis (Anhui and Zhejiang).

Wang (2003) also listed two undescribed subspecies, as “Yunnan form” (eastern Yunnan) and “Shaanxi/Gansu form” (southern Shaanxi and southern Gansu) but scientific names were not provided.

authority: Shekelle, Groves, Maryanto, Mittermeier, Salim & Springer, 2019

taxonomicNotes:
Modern taxonomic arrangements of the colobus monkeys either distinguish the red colobus monkeys and the Olive Colobus as separate genera, Piliocolobus and Procolobus, respectively (e.g., Groves 2001, 2005, 2007; Roos et al. 2011; Kingdon 2015), or consider them to belong to one genus Procolobus, with two subgenera (Procolobus for the Olive Colobus and Piliocolobus for the red colobus) (Oates et al. 1994, Grubb et al. 2003, 2013; Oates 2011). Ting (2008) placed all the red colobus as subspecies of Procolobus (Piliocolobus) badius. The 2008 IUCN Red List assessments followed the taxonomy of Grubb et al. (2003).

The arrangement of two genera in Groves (2001, 2005, 2007) is followed here: a monotypic Procolobus de Rochebrune, 1887 (Olive Colobus) and polytypic Piliocolobus de Rochebrune, 1887 (red colobus).

Kingdon (1997, 2015), following Colyn (1991), treated oustaleti as the Central African Red Colobus, with parmentieri, foai, langi, lulindicus, ellioti, semlikiensis and tephrosceles as subspecies. Grubb et al. (2003) considered tephrosceles be a subspecies but did not assign it to a species. Considering vocalizations and pelage colour patterns, Grubb et al. (2013) placed tephrosceles as a subspecies of rufomitratus, along with ellioti, foai, langi, lulindicus, parmentieri, oustaleti and tholloni.

Groves (2007) treated tephrosceles as a monotypic species, with gudoviusi Matschie as a junior synonym. For the purpose of this assessment, we follow Groves (2007) in treating tephrosceles as a monotypic species.

authority: Boubli, Byrne, da Silva, Silva-Júnior, Costa Araújo, Bertuol, Gonçalves, de Melo, Rylands, Mittermeier, Silva, Nash, Canale, Alencar, Rossi, Carneiro, Sampaio, Farias, Schneider, & Hrbek, 2019
Gusmão, Messias, Carneiro, Schneider, de Alencar, Calouro, Dalponte, de Souza Mattos, Ferrari, Buss, de Azevedo, Santos Júnior, Nash, Rylands & Barnett, 2019

taxonomicNotes: Several arrangements of the gazelles in the genus Eudorcas have been proposed, varying from one to four species. Thomson’s Gazelle (Eudorcas thomsonii) has been treated variously as conspecific with Mongalla Gazelle (E. albonotata) and/or Red-fronted Gazelle (E. rufifrons) (Gentry 1972, Kingdon 1997, East 1999) or as a separate species. The form tilonura, from east of the Nile River, is either considered a subspecies of E. rufifrons (e.g. Grubb 2005), or a distinct species (Groves 2013). The treatment here follows Groves (2013) in recognizing, at least provisionally, four species, including E. thomsonii. Genetic research to clarify the relationships between all four forms is highly desirable.

Was previously considered conspecific with Lynx lynx by some authorities, but is currently accepted as a distinct species on the basis of both genetics (Johnson et al. 2006, Eizirik et al. submitted) and morphology (Werdelin 1981, Wozencraft 2005).

A member of the Trachypithecus obscurus group, that also includes T. obscurus and T. barbei, a sister clade to the T. cristatus group (Roos et al., 2007). Groves (2001) grouped T. obscurus and T. phayrei, but he was unsure of the affiliation of T. barbei and placed it in the T. cristatus group, suspecting (p.266), however, that it should in fact be allied with T. obscurus. Roos et al. (2007, 2020) defined this group phylogenetically (mtDNA haplotypes), confirming Groves’ (2001) suspicion and including T. barbei as a sister species to phayrei. Napier (1985) and Groves (2001) placed crepusculus Elliot, 1909, and shanicus Wroughton, 1917, as subspecies of phayrei. Leidigk et al. (2009) and Roos et al. (2019, 2020), however, showed that crepusculus was in fact the earliest branch of the francoisi group. Roos et al. (2020) found that phayrei comprised three clades that diverged about 1 Mya: besides phayrei, shanicus, which they synonymized with melamera Elliot, and a third previously unnamed form that they called popa—each as full species.

Two subspecies have been described and these persist in theory (Meester et al. 1986). Felis nigripes nigripes, the nominate genotype form described by Burchell, was first described from near Kuruman in the Northern Cape. Its range includes present-day south eastern Namibia, Botswana, Northern Cape, North West, Gauteng, Limpopo and marginally into Mpumalanga. Felis nigripes thomasi (Shortridge 1931) is described from a specimen collected near Grahamstown in the Eastern Cape. Its range includes the present-day Eastern Cape, westwards to the southern regions of the Northern Cape and the Free State.

However, Smithers (1971) doubted the validity of two subspecies, and his thought is shared by Sliwa (2013) who suggests that the species may be polymorphic in the centre of its range but does exhibit on some geocline variations towards the extremes of its range. The northern race typically tends to be paler with less distinct striping whereas the southern race has a more tawny appearance with bolder patterning. However, since there are no obvious geographical or ecological barriers between the ranges which are the leading causes of genetic drift and speciation (Hoskin et al. 2005), it is likely that the subspecies status is invalid (Wilson 2016).
Capra walie is here treated as a distinct species from Capra ibex and Capra nubiana, following Grubb (2005).

This taxon was formerly considered a subspecies of Nycticebus coucang, with which there is a small hybridization zone in peninsular Thailand. Based on genetic evidence, it was elevated to species level by Roos (2003). Considerable variation exists in body size (850–2,100 g), genetics and coat colour (white to crimson red; absence of head forks to possession of light head forks) in this taxon, which may lead to at least three new taxa being described.

Butynski and De Jong (2018) provide a detailed account of the taxonomic history of this species. Although described by Thomas (1885) as a subspecies of Colobus guereza, De Rochebrune (1887) considered it sufficiently distinct to be a species; a classification that was accepted by most other taxonomists at that time. Schwarz (1929), however, designated all the black-and-white colobus monkeys to just one species, Colobus polykomos (Zimmermann 1780) with 20 subspecies, caudatus one of them. Pocock (1935) argued that there were four species of black-and-white colobus, and his proposition was taken up by Dandelot (1965, 1968, 1974), resulting in the acceptance of five species today—polykomos, vellerosus, guereza, satanas and angolensis—but caudatus was left behind as a subspecies of guereza. Using the Phylogenetic Species Concept, Butynski and De Jong (2018) argued that caudatus should be considered a species on the basis of its geographic isolation, distinctive cranial morphology and coat colour patterns, and its calls—Oates et al. (2000; p.444) found significant differences in the loud call of caudatus from Mt Meru, Tanzania, when compared with Colobus guereza occidentalis.

A phylogenetic analysis of the lorisiform primates by Pozzi et al. (2015) showed that Galagoides demidoff and Galagoides thomasi comprise a clade separate from other species currently in the genus Galagoides: G. rondoensis, G. orinus, G. zanzibaricus, G. cocos, and G. granti. This latter group is sister to the lesser galagos Galago É. Geoffroy Saint-Hilaire, 1796, with the two lineages diverging about 15 mya. As such, this latter group has been allocated to a new genus, Paragalago (Masters et al. 2017). Galagoides is now restricted to the more western forms: demidoff (G. Fischer, 1808), thomasi (Elliot, 1907), and kumbirensis Svensson et al.,2017.

Two subspecies, both endemic to Tanzania, are listed here following Butynski et al. (2006) and Honess et al. (2013), the nominate form from Unguja (Zanzibar) Island and P. z. udzungwensis from the mainland. A population discovered in Mlola Forest Reserve, Mafia Island, has not been identified to subspecies level (A. Perkin pers. obs. 2008).

Goral Naemorhedus spp. taxonomy was recently clarified by Mori et al. (2019) based on mitochondrial DNA. Three goral species are now recognised: long-tailed goral Naemorhedus caudatus, red goral Naemorhedus baileyi and Himalayan goral Naemorhedus goral. Only one species of red goral has been confirmed, all current and earlier references to Naemorhedus cranbrooki should be considered as N. baileyi.

The Pallas’s Cat has retained the monotypic genus Otocolobus and has been placed within the Leopard Cat lineage (Johnson et al. 2006). O'Brien and Johnson (2007) estimated that Otocolobus manul diverged from a Leopard Cat ancestor approximately 5.9 million years ago. There have been no recent molecular or morphological studies on the species, and two subspecies (O. m. manul [Pallas, 1776] in the Southwest and Central Asia and O. m. nigripectus [Hodgson, 1842] in the Himalayas) have been tentatively suggested, largely based on variation in pelage colouration (Kitchener et al. 2017).

authority: Louis Jr., Coles, Andriantompohavana, Sommer, Engberg, Zaonarivelo, Mayor & Brenneman, 2006

taxonomicNotes: This taxon was formerly considered a subspecies of N. concolor, however, the light-cheeked gibbons were subsequently separated (Dao Van Tien 1983; Ma and Wang 1986; Ma et al. 1988) and then further divided into the four taxa currently recognized with the separation of N. gabriellae (Groves 1993), then N. siki (e.g. Groves 2001; Mootnick 2006; Geissmann 2007; Van Ngoc Thinh et al. 2010a; Van Ngoc Thinh et al. 2010b; Mootnick and Fan Pengfei 2011; Van Ngoc Thinh et al. 2011) and finally with the recent description of N. annamensis (Van Ngoc Thin et al. 2010c). Nomascus leucogenys was previously considered to overlap with N. concolor in Viet Nam and Yunnan, China (Dao Van Tien 1983; Ma and Wang 1986), however, there seems to be insufficient evidence to currently conclude this (Fooden 1996; Geissmann et al. 2000; Rawson et al. 2011).

This species belongs to bicolor species group. This species was listed under Hipposideros bicolor (Temminck, 1834), but is now considered distinct (Hill et al. 1986, Srinivasulu and Srinivasulu 2012). Based on morphology and bacular structure, Srinivasulu and Srinivasulu (2018) upgraded the taxon gentilis Andersen, 1918 to specific rank, and suggested that H. pomona Andersen, 1918 sensu stricto is restricted to southern India, and H. gentilis sensu lato occurs from northeast India to Southeast Asia.

This species belongs to bicolor species group. Based on morphology and bacular structure, Srinivasulu and Srinivasulu (2018) upgraded the taxon gentilis Andersen, 1918 to specific rank, and suggested that H. pomona Andersen, 1918 sensu stricto is restricted to southern India, and H. gentilis sensu lato occurs from northeast India to Southeast Asia.
Formerly considered a subspecies of Eulemur fulvus, but later raised to species level (Groves 2001).

Previously, there had been a debate over whether this taxa was a full species or a subspecies of Avahi laniger (Avahi laniger occidentalis). Rumpler et al. (1990) used cytogenetic data to justify elevation of this taxa to a full species, A. occidentalis.

Previously, this species was considered to have two subspecies: Eulemur macao macaco, the Black Lemur and E. m. flavifrons, the Blue-eyed Back Lemur or Sclater’s Lemur. Taxonomic revision of each member of the Eulemur fulvus subspecies complex to full species status (Mittermeier et al. 2006), left E. macaco as the only species in the genus that was classified as polytypic (i.e., E. m. macaco and E. m. flavifrons). However, given the degree of morphological differences between the Black Lemur and the Blue-eyed Black Lemur, retaining this subspecific taxonomy was assessed as not consistent with the available comparative data on the two taxa. Pair-wise genetic distance values between the Black Lemur and the Blue-eyed Black Lemur range from 68–72 bp -- this is in the same range as what has been found between the former E. fulvus subspecies (29–90 bp; see Pastorini 2000). In the late 1980s and early 1990s, reports of a north-south geographical morphocline in subspecific traits was reported in the region between Maromandia and the Manongarivo Special Reserve (Meyers et al. 1989, Rabarivola et al. 1991), but more recently completed survey work indicates that the hybrid zone between the two taxa is restricted to the northeastern geographic range of the Blue-eyed Black Lemur and southern portions of the Manongarivo Special Reserve (Andrianjakarivelo 2004, Schwitzer et al. 2005, 2006, Tinsman et al. 2019). In light of these findings, the Blue-eyed Black Lemur was raised to full species status (i.e., E. flavifrons) by Mittermeier et al. (2008, 2010).
Formerly considered a subspecies of Eulemur fulvus, but later raised to species level (Groves 2001).

Cytogenetic and molecular data do not distinguish Hapalemur alatorensis from H. griseus griseus (Fausser et al. 2002, Pastorini et al. 2002), although the former is differentiated based on its larger size (Rabarivola et al. 2007).

authority: Hotaling, Foley, Lawrence, Bocanegra, Blanco, Rasoloarison, Kappeler, Barrett, Yoder & Weisrock, 2016

taxonomicNotes: Analyses of morphometric, genetic, and behavioral data (Kappeler et al. 2005) resulted in the recognition of Mirza zaza as distinct from M. coquereli. Mirza coquereli is the larger of the two, with a distribution nucleus in southwestern Madagascar. Mirza zaza is found in the northern western dry forest domain and the Sambirano region and (Kappeler et al. 2005).
Formerly included within Apodemus uralensis and prior to that under A. sylvaticus. A. wardi as considered to be conspecific with A. pallipes.

Until Corbet and Hill (1992) the forms here treated as P. philippensis were almost universally treated as conspecific with P. petaurista (e.g. Lekagul and McNeely 1977), meaning that much information concerning P.  philippensis has been published under the name P. petaurista. Great care is, however, needed in determining what information refers to which species because the two (as here constituted) are widely sympatric. Even Petaurista philippensis possibly represents a complex of several similar species. Further studies are needed to clarify the taxonomic status of populations currently allocated to this species.

Morphological evidence suggests this is a species of the sinica species group. Two subspecies are considered, based on pelage variations namely the bright brown northern subspecies, Macaca arctoides arctoides and the black southern subspecies Macaca arctoides melanota (Koyabu et al. 2008) But in this assessment it is considered monotypic (Fooden 1971, Malaivijitnond and Hamada 2005).

Pipistrellus tenuis probably represents a complex of several similar species. Further studies are needed to clarify the taxonomic status of populations currently allocated to this species. This taxon was traditionally assigned to the “coromandra” subgroup of “pipistrellus” species group (e.g.: Corbet and Hill 1992). According to available molecular genetic data (Roehrs et al. 2010, Benda et al. 2016, orig.), P. tenuis is a part of genetic cluster of Oriental pipistrelles. This cluster is quite distinct from all the West Palearctic pipistrelles and may be referred to as “javanicus” species group. The taxon P. t. mimus Wroughton, 1899 now represents forms from Indochina, Sri Lanka, Pakistan and Afghanistan (Bates and Harrison 1997, Simmons 2005, Srinivasulu and Srinivasulu 2012, Benda and Gaisler 2015). The taxon glaucillus Wroughton, 1912, considered earlier as distinct subspecies, is synonymized following Sinha (1980) (Bates and Harisson 1997, Srinivasulu and Srinivasulu 2012). We follow the IUCN SSC Chiroptera Specialist Group (P. Racey pers. comm. 2008) in recognizing Pipistrellus murrayi as distinct from P. tenuis. Benda and Gaisler (2015) opine that this taxon represents a complex and needs a thorough review.
Grubb et al. (2003) listed two subspecies of E. pallidus: E. p. pallidus from Bioko Island and E. p. talboti from Nigeria and Cameroon.

A phylogenetic analysis of the lorisiform primates by Pozzi et al. (2015) showed that Galagoides demidoff and G. thomasi comprise a clade entirely separate from the remaining species currently placed in the genus Galagoides: G. rondoensis, G. orinus, G. zanzibaricus, G. cocos and G. granti. This latter group is sister to Galago É. Geoffroy Saint-Hilaire 1796, with the two lineages diverging about 15 mya, and has been attributed to a separate genus Paragalago Masters et al. 2017. Galagoides is now restricted to the more western forms of Central Africa and West Africa: demidoff (G. Fischer, 1806), thomasi (Elliot, 1907), and kumbirensis Svensson, Bersacola, Mills, Munds, Nijman, Perkin, Masters, Couette, Nekaris and Bearder, 2017.

Papio kindae was previously considered a subspecies of the Yellow Baboon, P. cynocephalus (Grubb et al. 2003; Groves 2001, 2005; Altmann et al. 2013) and was assessed as such in 2008. It is now widely recognized as a full species because it is morphologically, genetically and behaviourally distinct from the other baboon species (Jolly 1993, Burrell 2009, Zinner 2013, Weyher et al. 2014, Petersdorf et al. 2019). Papio kindae hybridizes with Yellow Baboons (P. c. cynocephalus) and Chacma Baboons (P. ursinus griseipes) in their respective contact zones in Zambia (Jolly et al. 2011, Zinner 2013).

Hill (1962) and Stanyon et al. (1995) listed five subspecies of the Red-handed Howler Monkey, Alouatta belzebul: A. b. belzebul Linnaeus, 1766 restricted by Cabrera (1957) to the Rio Capim, eastern Pará; A. b. discolor Spix, 1823 from Gurupá, Pará; A. b. ululata Elliot, 1912, from Miritiba, Maranhão; A. b. mexianae Hagmann 1908, from the island of Mexiana, in the Marajó Archipelago, Brazil; and A. b. nigerrima Lönnberg, 1941 (restricted by Cabrera (1957) to Patinga, Amazonas).

Cruz Lima (1945) listed the form nigerrima Lönnberg 1941 as a full species. Cytogenetic studies also indicated that A. b. nigerrima is sufficiently distinct as to warrant species status (Armada et al. 1987, Lima and Seuánez 1989), and that it is more closely related to A. seniculus than to A. belzebul (Oliveira 1996). Groves (2001, 2005) and Gregorin (2006) list it as a distinct species.

The taxonomy and distributions of A. belzebul have been reviewed by Langguth et al. (1987), Bonvicino et al. (1989) and Gregorin (2006). Groves (2001, 2005) did not recognize any subspecies for A. belzebul: the forms discolor, mexianae and ululata were given as junior synonyms of A. belzebul (Linnaeus, 1766). Here we follow Gregorin (2006) who recognized the forms belzebul, discolor, and ululata as full species and placed mexianae as a junior synonym of A. discolor.

Hill (1962) and Stanyon et al. (1995) listed nine subspecies of the red howler monkey, Alouatta seniculus: A. s. seniculus, A. s. arctoidea, A. s. stramineus, A. s. macconnelli, A. s. insulanus, A. s. amazonica, A. s. juara, A. s. puruensis, A. s. sara.

Alouatta s. arctoidea is here recognized as a full species because Stanyon et al. (1995) concluded that the number of chromosomal differences between A. s. sara and A. s. arctoidea (which resulted in A. s. sara being a considered a full species) was on a similar scale to that found between A. s. sara and A. s. seniculus by Minezawa et al. (1986). Groves (2001, 2005) nevertheless maintains it as a subspecies of A. seniculus.

An undescribed subspecies of A. seniculus north of the Río Orinoco was reported by Bodini and Pérez-Hernández (1987). It may, however, be Mycetes auratus Gray, 1845 and M. laniger Gray, 1845, both from the Orinoco.

The taxon is distinguished from other Alouatta species by a distinct sexual dichromatism (adult males are black and adult females are yellowish or brindled tawny) and by some characteristics of the hyoid bone in  males (particularly the lack of a tentorium) (Cortés-Ortiz et al. 2015). Although Nascimento et al. (2005) and Ascunce et al. (2007) suggest the existence of two black-and-gold howler monkey taxa based on phylogenetic analyses using the cytochrome b gene, Cortés-Ortiz et al. (2015) call for caution and the need of additional data from a wider range of locations to better evaluate this issue.

Hill (1962) listed five subspecies of the red-handed howler monkey, Alouatta belzebul: A. b. belzebul (Linnaeus, 1766) (restricted by Cabrera [1957] to the Rio Capim, eastern Pará); A. b. discolor (Spix, 1823) from Gurupá, Pará; A. b. ululata Elliot, 1912, from Miritiba, Maranhão; A. b. mexianae Hagmann, 1908, from the island of Mexiana, in the Marajó Archipelago, Brazil; and A. b. nigerrima Lönnberg, 1941 (restricted by Cabrera [1957] to Patinga, Amazonas).

Groves (2001, 2005) considered A. discolor (Spix, 1823) and A. ululata Elliot, 1912, to be synonyms of A. belzebul. Here we follow Gregorin (2006) who recognised the forms discolor and ululata as full species based in morphology of the cranium and hyoid apparatus and pelage colour and patterns.

Rylands and Brandon (1998) and Gregorin (2006) discuss the validity and the use of the alternative names of fusca and guariba for the brown howler monkey of the Atlantic forest in Brazil and Argentina. Rylands and Brandon-Jones (1998) suggested that guariba Humboldt, 1812, is the correct name, while Gregorin (2006) stated that fusca E. Geoffroy, 1812, should be used. Kinzey (1982; see also Rylands et al. 1996) described color variation of pelage in brown howler monkey. Gregorin (2006), studying the morphology of cranium and hyoid apparatus, considered the two brown howlers, listed by Rylands et al. (2000) and Groves (2001, 2005) as subspecies, to be full species. Harris et al. (2005), analyzed cytochrome b sequences and found significant differences between populations of A. guariba clamitans from Rio de Janeiro and those from Santa Catarina. The authors could show that cytochrome b sequences correspond to differences in the karyotype reported by Koiffman (1977) and Oliveira et al. (1995, 1998, 2002). Maximum genetic distances found by Harris et al. (2005) were considerably greater than those recorded for A. caraya and A. belzebul by Nascimento et al. (2005), and they argued that further genetic research may result in the recognition of three species of brown howler monkeys. A similar inference was obtained by Jerusalinsky (2001) in a preliminary analysis of the mtDNA Control Region. Martins et al. (2011), who also analyzed the cytochrome b gene obtained from samples from Rio de Janeiro, São Paulo and Santa Catarina, found two distinct haplogroups corresponding to the northern and southern populations, with both haplogroups occurring in sympatry within São Paulo State. Until the species’ taxonomy will be defined more clearly, this assessment continues to use names and sub-specific classification as proposed by Rylands et al. (2000), Rylands (2012), Groves (2001, 2005), Rylands and Mittermeier (2013), and Cortés-Ortiz et al. (2015).

Hill (1962) and Stanyon et al. (1995) listed nine subspecies of the red howler monkey, Alouatta seniculus: A. s. seniculus, A. s. arctoidea, A. s. stramineus, A. s. macconnelli, A. s. insulanus, A. s. amazonica, A. s. juara, A. s. puruensis, and A. s. sara.

Groves (2001, 2005) considered Alouatta seniculus amazonica Lönnberg, 1941, from Codajáz, north of the Rio Solimões, west of the Rio Negro, and A. s. puruensis Lönnberg, 1941 from the Rio Purus to be junior synonyms of A. seniculus juara Elliot, 1910. Gregorin (2006) tentatively considered it to be a junior synonym of A. juara, extending the range of this species to the north of Rio Solimões. Gregorin (2006) himself stated that this was mere speculation, however, and the identity of the howling monkeys west of the Negro in the north-central Amazon (the eastern range limits of A. seniculus from Colombia) remains unclear.

In 1854, Wallace referred to black howler monkeys on the upper Amazonas that he called Mycetes caraya. Pelzeln (1883) later designated two specimens from Borba, Amazonas, as Mycetes villosus, following Gray (1845). Lönnberg (1941) described the species on the basis of material collected by A. M. Ollala from various localities in the state Amazonas between the rios Madeira and Tapajós. Cruz Lima (1945) noted that the form nigerrima was distinct, but recommended it be compared to the black howlers of Central America. Hershkovitz (1949) considered nigerrima to be a subspecies of the Red-Handed Howler, Alouatta belzebul, a classification that was maintained by several authors for 50 years (Napier 1976; Wolfheim, 1983). Cytogenetic studies indicated that A. b. nigerrima is sufficiently distinct to warrant species status (Armada et al. 1987; see also Lima and Seuánez 1989), and that it is more closely related to seniculus than to belzebul (see Oliveira 1996). Rylands (2000) and Groves (2001, 2005) raised nigerrima to species level, a classification maintained by Gregorin (2006). This taxonomic history was taken from Gregorin (2006). Cortés-Ortiz et al. (2015), however, argued that further genetic analyses and morphological studies are needed to confirm the status of A. nigerrima as a full species.

The taxonomy of the howlers of Mesoamerica, the Pacific coasts of Colombia and Ecuador and the Tumbes region of Northern Peru is based on Lawrence (1933), and recently revised by Cortés-Ortiz et al. (2015a). Through a comprehensive study of Mesoamerican howlers based on cranial features and pelage colouration patterns, Lawrence (1933) considered all Mesoamerican howlers to be subspecies of A. palliata, including: A. p. mexicana, A. p. palliata, A. p. aequatorialis, A. p. pigra, A. p. luctuosa, A. p. coibensis, and A. p. trabeata. Smith (1970) analysed pelage colouration patterns, and cranial and dental features of 238 specimens from across the range of A. palliata (including those studied by Lawrence, 1933) and compared them with a population sample of two sympatric forms of howler monkeys from the state of Tabasco, Mexico. He determined that the two (partially sympatric) forms from his sample constituted two well-differentiated species, and thus recommended A. pigra to be considered full species and separated from A. palliata. He considered A. p. luctuosa Lawrence, 1933 as junior synonym of A. pigra.

Froehlich and Froehlich (1986, 1987), analysed the dermal ridge patterns of howler monkeys from Nicaragua, Costa Rica, and Panama and suggested that the forms coibensis and trabeata be treated as subspecies of a distinct species, A. coibensis. Groves (2001, 2005) followed Froehlich and Froehlich and recognized A. palliata (Gray, 1849) and A. coibensis Thomas, 1902 as distinct species, but did not distinguish any subspecies.

Using mtDNA markers, Cortés-Ortiz et al. (2003) found that the Mantled Howler Monkeys from Mexico to Panama comprise a monophyletic group that is distinct from the clade of black howler monkeys (A. pigra). However, individuals from Coiba Island were found to share mitochondrial haplotypes with mantled howler monkeys from Costa Rica and Mexico, and howler monkeys from Azuero peninsula in Panama shared haplotypes with those from central and eastern Panama. In general, the divergence among mitochondrial lineages of individuals from Mexico, Costa Rica, Coiba Island, Azuero Peninsula and the rest of Panama was minimal and did not justify separating them into distinct species.

Hill (1962) and Stanyon et al. (1995) listed nine subspecies of the Red Howler Monkey, Alouatta seniculus: A. s. seniculus, A. s. arctoidea, A. s. stramineus, A. s. macconnelli, A. s. insulanus, A. s. amazonica, A. s. juara, A. s. puruensis, and A. s. sara.

Alouatta seniculus puruensis Lönnberg, 1941, from Jaburú, Rio Purus, is recognized as a distinct form by Gregorin (2006). He indicated that it occurs along the Ruo Purus basin and adjacent parts of the upper Rio Madeira (at least south from the lower Rio Aripuanã, about 10°S) into Rondônia. The southernmost record is Plácido de Castro, Acre. Groves (2001, 2005) placed it as a junior synonym of A. s. juara.

Alouatta ululata was originally described by Elliot, 1912, but was considered one of five subspecies of Alouatta belzebul (Hill 1962).  Groves (2001, 2005) still considers A. ululata as a synonym of A. belzebul. Gregorin (2006) noted that the sexual dichromatism found in specimens from Ceará and Maranhão was not described for any individual of A. belzebul or A. discolor, and concluded that A. ululata should be considered as a distinct species. Here, we follow Gregorin (2006) in recognizing A. ululata as a distinct species. However, no genetic study has included specimens of this taxon and therefore its genetic distinctiveness from A. belzebul and A. discolor remains an open question (Cortés-Ortiz et al. 2015).

The species of the genus Aotus are the only nocturnal primates in the Neotropics (Zunino et al. 1986, Ford 1994, Fernández-Duque 2007). The current taxonomy provides a frame on which a wide range of karyotypes is displayed (Menezes et al. 2010, Ruiz-Garcia et al. 2011). Various studies have reported about 18 different karyotypes with diploid number that are distributed on 46 to 58 chromosomes (Ruiz-Herrera et al. 2005, Menezes et al. 2010, Ruiz-Garcia et al. 2011).


To date, the Aotus taxonomy is based on morphological, karyological and carbonic anhydrase II electrophoretic data (Ford 1994, Sampaio et al. 1991). More recently, phylogenetic reconstructions were inferred from mtDNA data (partial cytochrome oxidase II; Ashley and Vaughn 1995; Plautz et al. 2009).


Hershkovitz's (1983) taxonomic revision comprises a total of nine species. In his scheme, the genus Aotus is divided into two groups, based on differences in pelage coloration (red neck or grey neck). Hershkovitz (1983) classified the genus on the basis of fur patterns, karyotypes and geographical distribution. However, more recent revisions of the genus consider eleven species (Defler and Bueno 2007; Menezes et al. 2010; Ruiz-Garcia et al. 2011).


Hershkovitz (1983) divided the genus into two groups: those species that live on the left bank of the Maranon-Solimões-Amazonas Rivers (gray-necked group) and those from the right bank (red-necked group). The gray-necked group comprises of four species: A. trivirgatus, A. vociferans, A. brumbacki, and A. lemurinus (A. l. lemurinus and A. l. griseimembra). Based on karyotypic data, at least seven species can be recognized in this group, being A. brumbacki, A. griseimembra, A. lemurinus, A. trivirgatus, A. vociferans, A. zonalis and a presumably new species named A. jorgehernandezi (Defler and Buneo 2007). The red-necked group comprises of five species: A. infulatus, A. nigriceps, A. nancymai, A. miconax, and A. azarae (A. a. azarae and A. a. boliviensis) (Pieczarka et al. 1991, Defler and Bueno 2007). While Hershkovitz (1983) recognized A. infulatus Kuhl, 1820 as a full species, Groves (2001, 2005) sunk it as a subspecies into Aotus azarae.


According to Schneider & Sampaio (2015) the molecular phylogeny of Aotus is relatively well explored. Menezes et al. (2010) carried out phylogenetic analysis using five mitochondrial markers and the nuclear SRY (Y-linked) gene in addition to karyological data. They identified a major diversification event around 4.62 mya (range: 3.07–6.43 mya) related to the presence of at least three refuges: the Andean refuge (Aotus azarae, A. infulatus, and A. nigriceps), the Guyanan refuge (A. trivirgatus), and the Brazilian refuge (A. griseimembra, A. lemurinus, A. zonalis, A. brumbacki, A. vociferans, A. miconax, and A. nancymae). The information published to date is insufficient to fully characterize the diversity of this genus (Fernández-Duque et al. 2008).


Here, the taxonomy essentially follows revisions of Hershkovitz (1983), Groves (2001, 2005), Rylands (2012) and Rylands & Mittermeier (2014).

The taxonomy of the night monkeys (Aotus spp.) is still debated and does not represent a complete picture of the diversity of the genus Aotus. The current taxonomy essentially follows the early revision of Hershkovitz (1983), with some modifications for the Colombian and Central American forms. However, Ruiz-Herrera et al. (2005) reported that cytogenetic studies characterized 18 different karyotypes with diploid numbers ranging from 46 to 58 chromosomes. Recent molecular studies have made valuable contributions towards the understanding of night monkeys’ taxonomy and their phylogenetic relations (Plautz et al. 2009, Menezes et al. 2010).

Reviewing the entire taxonomy and distributions of the night monkeys, Aotus, Ford (1994) carried out multivariate analyses of craniodental measures and pelage patterns and colour, and also took into consideration chromosomal data and blood protein variations. Ford (1994) concluded that there was “good support” for just two species north of the Río Amazonas: A. trivirgatus (Humboldt, 1812) east and north of the Rio Negro, and the polymorphic A. vociferans to the west of the Rio Negro. Aotus vociferans, as such, would include all the forms north of the Río Amazonas/Solimões in Brazil (west of the Rio Negro), Peru, Colombia and Ecuador, and in the Chocó, northern Colombia and Colombian Andes, and Panama: brumbacki, lemurinus, griseimembra, and zonalis.

Hernández-Camacho and Cooper (1976) restricted both lemurinus (Colombian Andes, elevations from 1,000 to 1,500 m up to 3,000-3,200 m) and griseimembra (northern lowlands, Santa Marta mountains, West to Río Sinú, Río San Jorge, lower Río Cauca and lowlands of middle and upper Río Magdalena) to Colombia, while recognizing the form zonalis as the night monkey of north-western Colombia (Chocó) and Panama. Hershkovitz (1983) recognized lemurinus and griseimembra as distinct, but considered them to be subspecies of a single species; he made no mention of the name zonalis, but as he ascribed Central American night monkeys to A. lemurinus lemurinus, by implication he was regarding it as a synonym of this latter form. Groves (2001) followed Hernández-Camacho and Cooper (1976) in recognizing zonalis as the form in Panama, and listed it as a subspecies of lemurinus along with griseimembra and brumbacki Hershkovitz, 1983. Defler et al. (2001) concluded that the karyotype of Aotus hershkovitzi Ramirez-Cerquera, 1983 (from the upper Río Cusiana, Boyacá, Colombia; 2n = 58) was in fact that of true lemurinus, and that the karyotypes which Hershkovitz (1983) had considered to be those of lemurinus were in fact of zonalis. Defler et al. (2001) and others (Defler 2003, 2004; Defler and Bueno 2003) concluded that Aotus lemurinus of Hershkovitz (1983) is in fact three karyotypically well-defined species, and that the night monkeys of the lowlands of Panama and the Chocó region of Colombia belong to the species A. zonalis, and those of the Magdalena valley to A. griseimembra, while those above altitudes of 1,500m should correctly be referred to as A. lemurinus. For a review of the taxonomy of the night monkeys of Panama and northern Colombia see Rylands et al. (2006).

Defler and Bueno (2007) discussed the karyology of the grey-necked night monkeys and reaffirmed the validity of A. brumbacki, A. griseimembra, A. lemurinus, A. trivirgatus, A. vociferans and A. zonalis.

Defler and Bueno (2007) described A. jorgehernandezi from a specimen in captivity in Quindío Department, Colombia, said to be from the Parque de los Nevados on the border between Quindío and Risaralda. The authors also discuss the karyology of the grey-necked night monkeys and reaffirm the validity of A. brumbacki, A. griseimembra, A. lemurinus, A. trivirgatus, A. vociferans and A. zonalis.

It is doubtful that the current taxonomy provides a true picture of the diversity of the genus Aotus. Ruiz-Herrera et al. 2005) reported that cytogenetic studies have characterized 18 different karyotypes with diploid numbers ranging from 46 to 58 chromosomes. The taxonomy of the night monkeys essentially follows the revision by Hershkovitz (1983), with some modifications for the Colombian and Central American forms.

It is doubtful that the current taxonomy provides a true picture of the diversity of the genus Aotus. Ruiz-Herrera et al. (2005) reported that cytogenetic studies have characterized 18 different karyotypes with diploid numbers ranging from 46 to 58 chromosomes.
