The taxonomy of the night monkeys essentially follows the revision by Hershkovitz (1983), with some modifications for the Colombian and Central American forms. Bodini and Ferreira (1986) conducted a pilot study on the craniometry and pelage characteristics of Venezuelan Aotus trivirgatus.

Reviewing the entire taxonomy and distributions of the night monkeys, Aotus, Ford (1994) carried out multivariate analyses of craniodental measures and pelage patterns and color, and also took into consideration chromosomal data and blood protein variations. Ford (1994) concluded that there was “good support” for just two species north of the Río Amazonas: A. trivirgatus (Humboldt, 1812) east and north of the Rio Negro, and the polymorphic A. vociferans to the west of the Rio Negro. Aotus vociferans, as such, would include all the forms north of the Río Amazonas/Solimões in Brazil (west of the Rio Negro), Peru, Colombia and Ecuador, and in the Chocó, northern Colombia and Colombian Andes, and Panama: brumbacki, lemurinus, griseimembra, and zonalis.

Amongst others, the karyotype of Aotus trivirgatus was described by Defler and Bueno (2007), and Hershkovitz (1983), who based his taxonomy primarily on karyotypes, indicated that further research may result in a revision of this and the forms he recognizes as miconax and infulatus. In Brazil, Santos-Mello and Thiago de Mello (1986) completed a preliminary analysis of the karyotype of Aotus trivirgatus collected near Manaus. They found a female with 52 chromosomes and a male with 51 chromosomes.

The precise phylogeny of the genus Aotus has been and continues to be a matter of debate. Different hypotheses have been proposed, from the existence of a single species (Aotus trivirgatus) with several allopatric subspecies (Hernández-Camacho and Cooper 1976; Hershkovitz 1949), to the 18 different karyotypes reported by Ruiz-Herrera et al. (2005) from cytogenetic studies. The current taxonomy essentially follows the revision by Hershkovitz (1983), with some modifications for the Colombian and Central American forms.

Hershkovitz (1983) included Aotus vociferans as a species of the “grey-necked group”, together with A. lemurinus (containing 2 subspecies, A. l. lemurinus and A. l. griseimembra), A. brumbacki and A. trivirgatus.  Ford (1994) included the forms lemurinus and griseimembra as subspecies of A. vociferans; however, Groves (2001) also included them as subspecies of A. lemurinus, and noted the differentiation between the lemurinus and vociferans forms. Defler and Bueno (2007) discussed the karyology of the gray-necked night monkeys and reaffirmed the validity of A. brumbacki, A. griseimembra, A. lemurinus, A. trivirgatus, A. vociferans and A. zonalis. Findings by Menezes et al. (2010) further supported the validity of A. griseimembra, A. lemurinus and A. vociferans as species.

Even though few molecular studies have been performed to resolve the phylogeny of Aotus, the available information indicates a close relation between A. vociferans, A. griseimembra and A. brumbacki (grey-necked group) and also between A. nancymaae and this group, especially with A. vociferans (Plautz et al. 2009; Menezes et al. 2010; Ruiz-García et al. 2011). Furthermore, Defler and Bueno (2007) proposed A. vociferans as one of the most ancient Aotus species, and evidence from molecular studies supports this hypothesis (Plautz et al. 2009; Ruiz-García et al. 2010).

The current taxonomy of spider monkeys (Ateles spp.) is based on Kellogg and Goldman’s (1944) seminal review and more recently, complemented by morphological and molecular analysis of Froehlich et al. (1991), Collins and Dubach (2000), Nieves et al. (2005) and Morales-Jimenez et al. (2015). The early classification of spider monkeys proposed by Kellogg and Goldman (1944) relied on the geographical distribution and several morphological characters. However, Ateles belzebuth comprised of several taxa characterized by the presence of a white patch on the forehead, including populations of white-bellied spider monkeys from northwestern Amazonia, the trans-Andean populations of Ateles hybridus, and the populations of spider monkeys from eastern Amazonia (Ateles marginatus). Spider monkeys without a whitish brow patch were also grouped together, including spider monkeys of the Guianas (Ateles paniscus) and spider monkeys from southwestern Amazonia (Ateles chamek). This initial taxonomic hypothesis was not parsimonious due to the geographical discordance between groups of spider monkeys with “similar” characters. In fact, Sampaio et al. (1993) had argued that the forms paniscus and chamek should be considered distinct species on the basis of the genetic distance between them.

The morphological and molecular studies conducted by Froehlich et al. (1991) and by Collins and Dubach (2000), respectively, brought up a new hypothesis that suggested that Ateles belzebuth was composed of three major Amazonian groups (Ateles b. belzebuth, Ateles b. chamek and Ateles b. marginatus), while Ateles paniscus was a sister group (and basal) to all other spider monkeys. Also, these studies provided evidence for an early divergence between Ateles hybridus in northern South America and Ateles belzebuth in the Amazon basin (Collins 1999; Collins and Dubach 2000). Later studies based on chromosomal and molecular markers supported the hypothesis that the belzebuth-chamek-marginatus group formed a monophyletic clade (Nieves et al. 2005). Since then there has been debate on the specific status of belzebuth, chamek and marginatus, and several authors have supported this new classification of Amazonian spider monkeys (e.g. Rylands et al. 2000). Recently, a new molecular study proposed that Ateles marginatus may well be the sister taxon to all other spider monkeys, and confirmed that Ateles belzebuth and Ateles chamek are indeed sister taxa that may have shared a common ancestor approximately 1.8 million years ago (Morales-Jimenez et al. 2015).

Traditionally, Ateles taxonomy is based on Kellogg and Goldman (1944) that recognize four species: Ateles paniscus (two subspecies, including Ateles paniscus chamek), A. belzebuth (3 subspecies), A. geoffroyi (nine subspecies) and A. fusciceps (two subspecies). Froehlich et al. (1991), Medeiros (1994) and Medeiros et al. (1997) argue that A. paniscus is a distinct species without subspecies. Boer and Bruijn (1990) indicated that A. chamek should be considered a full species, while Froehlich et al. (1991) and Collins (2008) classify the taxon as a subspecies of Ateles belzebuth (A. b. chamek). According to Collins (2008), genetic evidence shows that the morphological similarities that spider monkeys of Cocha Cashu National Park in Peru share with A. paniscus in Suriname and the Guiana Shield (black coat and pink face) are superficial and thus should be classified as Ateles belzebuth chamek. Rylands et al. (2000), Rylands and Mittermeier (2009) and Konstant and Rylands (2013) recognize A. chamek as a distinct species. According to van Roosmalen and van Roosmalen (2014) the species of spider monkey that occurs throughout the interfluve between the Rios Madeira, Mamoré, Guaporé and Tapajós, an area recognized for the occurrence of A. chamek, should be Ateles longimembris. In this region, Cruz Lima (1945) recognized this spider monkey as a subspecies of Ateles paniscus, while Groves (2001) considered A. longimembris as a synonym of A. chamek. Van Roosmalen and van Roosmalen (2014) report that they regard it as a distinct species of Ateles occurring between the Rios Purus and Madeira, south and west of the Rio Ipixuna (right bank tributary of the Rio Purus).

The taxonomy of spider monkeys (Ateles spp.) has been based on Kellogg and Goldman´s (1944) seminal study, and complemented by morphological and molecular studies more recently (Froehlich et al. 1991; Collins and Dubach 2000; Nieves et al. 2005; Morales-Jimenez et al. 2015b). The early studies of Kellogg and Goldman (1944) relied in the classification of spider monkeys based on the geographical distribution and several morphological characters. A. fusciceps robustus Allen, 1914 is considered a junior synonym of A. f. rufiventris Sclater, 1871 following Heltne and Kunkel (1975) (see Rylands et al. 2000). Silva-López et al. (1996) argued that Ateles geoffroyi pan was not a valid taxon. Since the earliest studies on the taxonomy of spider monkeys, A. fusciceps has been considered either within the geoffroyi clade or as a sister taxa to A. geoffroyi based on morphological characters (Froehlich et al. 1991) or molecular data (Collins and Dubach 2000).

Collins and Dubach (2000) argued that the forms fusciceps and rufiventris are subspecies of Ateles geoffroyi. The taxonomy and distributions of Ateles geoffroyi and Ateles fusciceps was reviewed by Rylands et al. (2006). Recent molecular data has suggested that the Mesoamerican spider monkeys (Ateles geoffroyi) and spider monkeys in north-western South America (Ateles fusciceps) shared a common ancestor nearly 2.2 Mya, and that both disjunct subspecies A. f. fusciceps and A. f. rufiventris shared a common ancestor nearly 1.3 Mya (Morales-Jimenez et al. 2015b). Mitochondrial DNA sequencing strongly supports Ateles geoffroyi and Ateles fusciceps being reciprocally monophyletic taxa (Morales-Jimenez et al. 2015b).

Ateles f. rufiventris Sclater, 1871, from the Río Atrato, Darien, Colombia, is listed as incertae sedis by Kellogg and Goldman (1944). Medeiros et al. (1997) indicated that, from the cytogenetic viewpoint, rufiventris Sclater, 1871, may well be reproductively isolated from A. geoffroyi.

The current taxonomy of Ateles geoffroyi is based on Kellogg and Goldman (1944), Rylands et al. 2006, and Morales-Jiménez et al. (2015). Originally, detail analyses of cranial morphology and pelage colouration by Kellogg and Goldman (1944) recognized nine distinct subspecies. Hill (1962), Hall (1981), and Konstant et al. (1985) retained all these subspecies, but morphological and genetic analyses over the past two decades challenged the validity of these taxa. For example, Silva-López et al. (1996) exemplified the enormous variation in pelage colouration of Ateles in Mexico, Guatemala and Belize and concluded that A. g. pan Schlegel, 1876 and A. g. yucatanensis Kellogg and Goldman, 1944 was within the variation of A. g. vellerosus. Napier (1976) also showed that the type specimen A. g. panamensis Kellogg and Goldman, 1944 falls within the variation of A. g. ornatus, Gray, 1870 and recommended considering the former a synonym of the latter. Based on phylogenetic analyses of small fragments of mitochondrial DNA genes, Collins and Dubach (2000) recognized a northern and a southern group of spider monkeys in Central America, but due to their fragmentary sampling could not properly evaluate subspecies distinctiveness. Using ~800 bp of the mtDNA control region, Morales-Jiménez et al. (2015) analysed the phylogenetic relationships of 49 spider monkeys sampled across Central America, and concluded that individuals from Mexico, Guatemala and Belize should be considered as part of A. g. vellerosus, while individuals from El Salvador should not be included in this taxon. They also found that individuals from southwestern Nicaragua and northwestern Costa Rica should be considered as A. g. frontatus and individuals from Azuero peninsula formed a monophyletic clade, supporting their recognition as distinct subspecies. However, despite recent efforts to improve our understanding of the phylogenetic relationships of the different subspecies of A. geoffroyi, conclusive results regarding the taxonomic validity of its subspecies still require analyses that include samples of individuals from southern Guatemala, Honduras, northern and eastern Nicaragua, central and western Panama, and eastern Costa Rica. Here, we tentatively recognized six subspecies: Ateles geoffroyi geoffroyi, Ateles geoffroyi azuerensis, Ateles geoffroyi frontatus, Ateles geoffroyi grisescens, Ateles geoffroyi ornatus, Ateles geoffroyi vellerosus.

The taxonomy and distributions of Ateles geoffroyi and Ateles fusciceps was reviewed by Rylands et al. (2006). Recent molecular data has suggested that the Mesoamerican spider monkeys (Ateles geoffroyi) and spider monkeys in north-western South America (Ateles fusciceps) shared a common ancestor nearly 2.2 Mya, and that both disjunct subspecies A. f. fusciceps and A. f. rufiventris shared a common ancestor nearly 1.3 Mya (Morales-Jimenez et al. 2015b). Mitochondrial DNA sequencing strongly supports Ateles geoffroyi and Ateles fusciceps being reciprocally monophyletic taxa (Morales-Jimenez et al. 2015b).

The taxonomy of the spider monkeys is based on Kellogg and Goldman (1944) and Hill (1962). The forms hybridus, chamek and marginatus are listed as distinct species and A. fusciceps robustus Allen, 1914 is considered a junior synonym of A. f. rufiventris Sclater, 1871 following Heltne and Kunkel (1975) (see Rylands et al. 2000).

Froehlich et al. (1991), and Medeiros (1994; Medeiros et al. 1997) argued that A. paniscus is a distinct form with no subspecies. De Boer and Bruijn (1990) indicated that chamek should be considered a full species, and likewise Sampaio et al. (1993) argued that the forms paniscus and chamek should be considered distinct species on the basis of the genetic distance between them. Ateles chamek was found to be closer to belzebuth than to paniscus (see also Nieves et al. 2005).

M.G.M. van Roosmalen reported (5 August 2003) an undescribed species of spider monkey within the supposed range of A. marginatus. It "occurs in the most south-eastern limit of the genus' distribution and inhabits the dry savanna forests and cerradão of northern Mato Grosso. Its western limit is the Rio Teles Pires and eastern limit is the Rio Culuene, a headwater tributary of the Rio Xingú. Its distribution is disjunct with that of Ateles marginatus along the lower and middle Rio Xingú, Pará, west as far as the Rio Tapajós and east as far as the left bank of the lower Rio Tocantins." It differs from A. marginatus by "the dark chestnut brown black fur, the pink instead of pitch-black muzzle and circumocular rings, and larger white whiskers and triangular blaze." According to van Roosmalen, it can be seen along the headwater effluents of the Rio Xingú, such as the Rios Culuene, Curisevo, Batoví, Ronuro, and Von den Steinen.

The taxonomy of the spider monkeys is based on Kellogg and Goldman (1944) and Hill (1962). The forms hybridus, chamek and marginatus are listed as distinct species and A. fusciceps robustus Allen, 1914 is considered a junior synonym of A. f. rufiventris Sclater, 1871 following Heltne and Kunkel (1975) (see Rylands et al. 2000).

Froehlich et al. (1991), and Medeiros (1994; Medeiros et al. 1997) argued that A. paniscus is a distinct form with no subspecies. De Boer and Bruijn (1990) indicated that chamek should be considered a full species, and likewise Sampaio et al. (1993) argued that the forms paniscus and chamek should be considered distinct species on the basis of the genetic distance between them. Ateles chamek was found to be closer to belzebuththan to paniscus (see also Nieves et al. 2005).

Vieira (1944) recognized two subspecies of Brachyteles. Recent evidence provided by Lemos de Sá et al. (1990), Fonseca et al. (1991) and Lemos de Sá and Glander (1993) indicated that Vieira’s original (1944) standing was valid, but that differentiation is even more extreme and justifies the classification of the two forms as separate species (see also Coimbra-Filho et al. 1993). Groves (2001, 2005) lists the two muriquis as separate species.

Vieira (1944) recognized two subspecies of Brachyteles. Recent evidence provided by Lemos de Sá et al. (1990), Fonseca et al. (1991) and Lemos de Sá and Glander (1993) indicated that Vieira’s original (1944) standing was valid, but that differentiation is even more extreme and justifies the classification of the two forms as separate species (see also Coimbra-Filho et al. 1993). Groves (2001, 2005) lists the two muriquis as separate species.

authority: Boubli, da Silva, Amado, Herbk, Pontual & Farias, 2008
taxonomicNotes: The taxonomy of this newly described species follows Boubli et al. (2008).

authority: Boubli, da Silva, Amado, Herbk, Pontual & Farias, 2008
taxonomicNotes: The taxonomy of this newly described species follows Boubli et al. (2008).

The taxonomy of Cacajao follows Hernández-Camacho and Cooper (1976), Hershkovitz (1987), Eisenberg (1989), Boubli (1994), Figueiredo (2006) and Boubli et al. (2008). The species name Cacajao ouakary has been suggested as more appropriate than Cacajao melanocephalus (A. Barnett pers. comm.) but Boubli et al. 2008 disagree.

Up until the end of the twentieth century, what is now considered the Callicebus personatus group consisted of a single species, with four subspecies (Hershkovitz 1988, 1990). Kobayashi and Langguth (1999) elevated the remaining taxa to the species level, resulting in a group of five species including Callicebus personatus.

A monotypic genus. Recent genetic studies of the captive population, and the indication of outbreeding depression have aroused suspicion that their may be more than one species in this genus (Vàsàrhelyi 2002).

In the past, the eastern Brazilian marmosets (penicillata É. Geoffroy, 1812; geoffroyi É. Geoffroy in Humboldt, 1812; aurita É. Geoffroy in Humboldt, 1812; and flaviceps Thomas, 1903) of the ‘jacchus group’ were considered to be subspecies of Callithrix jacchus, following Hershkovitz (1977). All taxa were later elevated to full species level (Coimbra-Filho 1984, Mittermeier et al. 1988, Marroig et al. 2004, Coimbra-Filho et al. 2006).

Coimbra-Filho (1986a, b, 1990, 1991) has argued that the similarity in dental morphology (Natori 1986), behaviour, pelage (infants of the two forms are practically identical in appearance), vocalizations (Mendes 1997b,c) and the recent discovery of wild groups of hybrids between C. aurita and C. flaviceps at Carangola, Minas Gerais (Ferrari and Mendes 1991), suggest subspecific status (Coimbra-Filho et al. 1993). Ferrari et al. (1996) studied and reviewed the ecology and behaviour of C. aurita and C. flaviceps groups and concluded that although undoubtedly very similar, the “comparison appears to have done more to re-emphasize the enormous flexibility underlying the behavioural ecology of the marmosets as a whole than clarify the relationships between these two taxa in particular”. Here, Rylands’ (2012) proposed taxonomy is followed; it considers C. aurita and C. flaviceps as full species.

In the past, the eastern Brazilian marmosets (penicillata É. Geoffroy, 1812, geoffroyi É. Geoffroy in Humboldt, 1812, aurita É. Geoffroy in Humboldt, 1812, and flaviceps Thomas, 1903) of the “jacchus group” were considered to be subspecies of Callithrix jacchus, following Hershkovitz (1977). All are now considered to be full species (see Coimbra-Filho and Mittermeier 1973, Coimbra-Filho 1984, Mittermeier et al. 1988, Mendes 1997b, Marroig et al. 2004, Coimbra-Filho et al. 2006).

Coimbra-Filho (1986a,b, 1990) and Coimbra-Filho et al. (1993b) argued that Callithrix flaviceps should be considered a subspecies of C. aurita. The similarities between C. flaviceps and C. aurita in pelage patterns such as the ear tufts and the skull-like facial mask, ecological adaptations, ontogeny (the infants are extremely similar), vocalizations and clinal variation in overall pelage colour, based this opinion (Coimbra-Filho 1986a,b; Coimbra-Filho et al. 1993). However, Ferrari et al. (1996) rejected the subspecies status of C. flaviceps based on ecological and behavioural studies of groups of C. flaviceps and C. aurita. Rylands (2012) corroborates this view and considers C. flaviceps as a full species.

In the past, the eastern Brazilian marmosets (penicillata É. Geoffroy, 1812, geoffroyi É. Geoffroy in Humboldt, 1812, aurita É. Geoffroy in Humboldt, 1812, and flaviceps Thomas, 1903) of the “jacchus group” were considered to be subspecies of Callithrix jacchus, following Hershkovitz (1977). All are now considered to be full species (see Coimbra-Filho 1984, Mittermeier et al. 1988, Marroig et al. 2004, Coimbra-Filho et al. 2006).

The validity and authorship of the name Callithrix kuhlii has been the subject of some debate. Hershkovitz (1975, p.142) was the first to indicate that Wied-Neuwied (1826) had referred to the marmoset of south-east Bahia as “Hapale penicillata Kuhlii” [sic]. However, Hershkovitz (1975, 1977) argued at length that kuhlii was not a valid taxon, being merely an intergrade between C. j. penicillata and C. j. geoffroyi. Vivo (1991, pp.80-81), on the other hand, argued that Wied-Neuwied (1826) had not intentionally given it this name, merely, and incorrectly, ascribing the authorship of the name penicillatato Kuhl. The first person to intentionally use the name kuhlii to describe the marmosets from south-east Bahia was Hershkovitz (1975), but his argument that it was not a valid taxonomic entity disqualifies the possibility of him being attributed authorship. This is therefore given to Coimbra-Filho (1985). A full description of the species is given in Coimbra-Filho et al. (2006).

In the past, the eastern Brazilian marmosets (penicillata É. Geoffroy, 1812, geoffroyi É. Geoffroy in Humboldt, 1812, aurita É. Geoffroy in Humboldt, 1812, and flaviceps Thomas, 1903) of the “jacchus group” were considered to be subspecies of Callithrix jacchus, following Hershkovitz (1977). All are now considered to be full species (see Coimbra-Filho 1984, Mittermeier et al. 1988, Marroig et al. 2004, Coimbra-Filho et al. 2006).

Hershkovitz (1949) listed thirteen subspecies of Cebus albifrons (Humboldt, 1812), including C. a. cuscinus Gray 1901, from the upper Río Madre de Dios, Peru.  Groves (2001) considered C. a. yuracus as a junior synonym of C. a. cuscinus.

Molecular genetic analyses by Boubli et al. (2012) indicated that Cebus albifrons sensu lato is polyphyletic within Cebus and that several subspecies should be considered provisionally as distinct species. However, this publication did not sample C. cuscinus, so its genetic relationship to other gracile capuchins is still largely unknown. Ruiz-García et al. (2010) sampled the mitochondrial COII gene for C. a. cuscinus as well as for other subspecies of C. albifrons sensu lato, but their results were difficult to interpret, with one cuscinus specimen forming a clade with C. a. albifrons and C. a. versicolor, and another with C. a. albifrons and C. olivaceus. More work is needed to determine if C. cuscinus is a species, or whether it should be lumped with C. yuracus (as suggested by Groves 2001, based on morphological characteristics), or with C. albifrons or C. unicolor (based on genetic similarity, Ruiz-García et al. 2010).

Formerly a subspecies of Cebus albifrons, the species was recognized by Boubli et al. (2012) based on a time-calibrated phylogeny using mitochondrial DNA sequences from 50 Cebus samples from across their range.

To date there have been only preliminary and non-conclusive molecular genetic assessments of Cebus aequatorialis (Boubli et al. 2012; Ruiz-García et al. 2010, 2018), and so its provisional status as a species is based on its geographic isolation from other Cebus albifrons populations and its unique morphological characteristics such as pelage colouration. Jack and Campos (2012) suggest elevating C. aequatorialis to species level following the phylogenetic species concept. Albuja et al. (2018) provide a preliminary cranio-dental and morphological analysis showing differences between Cebus aequatorialis and another Ecuadorian capuchin species, Cebus yuracus; however, their sample size is too small to be conclusive in terms of species distinction.

Hill (1960) listed three species of bearded saki: Chiropotes chiropotes, C. satanas and C. albinasa [sic]. Hershkovitz (1985) described a new species, utahickae, and classified satanas and utahickae as subspecies of C. chiropotes. Groves (2001, 2005) followed the taxonomy of Hershkovitz (1985). The three subspecies of Chiropotes satanas (satanas, chiropotes and utahicki) are here listed as full species following the recommendation of Silva-Júnior and Figueiredo (2002), Figueiredo et al. (2006), and Silva-Júnior et al.(2013). Bonvicino et al. (2003) resurrected the name Chiropotes israelita (Spix, 1823) for the bearded saki discovered by Boubli (2002) to the west of the Rio Branco, a tributary of the Rio Negro, Amazonas, Brazil. Genetic and pelage differences, notably a greenish brown (olive) dorsum as opposed to light golden brown as is typical of C. chiropotes, distinguish it from the bearded sakis of the Guianas to the east of the Rio Branco. There is however, a possible confusion concerning the correct names. Silva-Júnior and Figueiredo (2002) argued that the form west of the Rio Branco is, correctly Chiropotes chiropotes (Humboldt, 1811), according to its type locality, and the form to the east of the Rio Branco, extending through the states of Pará and Amapá, and into the Guianas (Guyana, Suriname, French Guiana) is C. sagulatus (Traill, 1821) from Demerara (see Silva-Júnior et al. (2013). Doubts still remain, however, concerning Hershkovitz’s interpretation of Humboldt’s type locality of C. chiropotes, which would accordingly alter the nomenclature (J. P. Boubli, pers. comm). With the further research and phylogenetic analysis, both Traill’s sagulatus and Spix’s israelita may be valid species names for different populations of this wide ranging genus.

Described by Hershkovitz (1988, 1990) as a subspecies of Callicebus personatus. Kobayashi and Langguth (1999) argued that the titis of the Atlantic forest should be considered species rather than subspecies of C. personatus. They listed C. nigrifrons, C. personatus, C. melanochir and C. coimbrai besides C. barbarabrownae. According to Printes (2007), the name Callicebus barbarabrownae (Hershkovitz, 1990), may prove to be a junior synonym of Callicebus gigot (Spix, 1823), according to the principle of priority.

Silva Jr. (2001, 2002) argued that the tufted capuchins and the untufted capuchins (sensu Hershkovitz 1949, 1955) are so distinct in their morphology that they should be considered separate genera. Cebus Erxleben, 1777 is referable to the untufted group, and Sapajus Kerr, 1792 is the name available for the tufted capuchins. 

Hershkovitz (1949) listed thirteen subspecies of Cebus albifrons (Humboldt, 1812) as follows: C. albifrons albifrons Humboldt, 1812, from the banks of the Orinoco, near the mouth of the Río Ventuari; C. a. hypoleucus Humboldt, 1812, from the Río Sinu, Bolívar, Colombia; C. a. malitiosus Elliot, 1904, from the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta, Colombia;C. a. cesarae Hershkovitz, 1949, from the Río Cesar, Magdalena valley, Colombia; C. a. pleei Hershkovitz, 1949, from Mompós, west bank of the Río Magdalena, at the base of the northern extremity of the Cordillera Central, Colombia; C. a. versicolor Pucheran, 1917, from the middle Río Magdalena, Colombia; C. a. leucocephalus Gray, 1865, considered by Hershkovitz to be from the Rio Lebrija, Santander, Colombia; C. a. adustus Hershkovitz, 1949, from the eastern base of the Sierra de Perijá in Venezuela and Colombia; C. a. unicolor Spix, 1823, from the Rio Tefé, Amazonas, Brazil; C. albifrons yuracus Hershkovitz, 1949, from the Ríos Marañón and Napo, eastern Ecuador and northern Peru; C. a. cuscinus Gray 1901, from the upper Río Madre de Dios, Peru; C. a. aequatorialis Allen, 1921, from north-western Ecuador (and probably also the Tumbes region in northern Peru [Encarnación and Cook 1998]); and C. a. trinitatis Von Pusch 1941, from Trinidad.

Groves (2001, 2005), influenced by Hernández-Camacho and Cooper (1976), reduced the number of subspecies to six: C. albifrons albifrons, C. a. cuscinus (yuracus as a junior synonym), C. a. unicolor, C. a. trinitatis, C. a. aequatorialis, and C. a. versicolor (leucocephalus, malitiosus, adustus, cesarae and pleei as synonyms). Silva Jr. (2001) did not recognize any subspecific variation in Cebus albifrons.
Groves (2001, 2005) listed Cebus albifrons unicolor Spix, 1823. Defler and Hernández-Camacho (2002) established a neotype for C. a. albifrons, and argued that C. a. unicolor was a junior synonym (see also Defler 2004). 
Defler (2004) listed and described five subspecies for mainland Colombia: 1) Cebus albifrons albifrons (Humboldt, 1812) (C. a. unicolor a synonym), 2) Cebus albifrons yuracus Hershkovitz, 1949 (considered a synonym of C. a. cuscinus Thomas, 1901, by Groves [2001]); 3) Cebus albifrons malitiosus Elliot, 1909 (considered a synonym of C. a. versicolor Pucheran, 1845, by Groves [2001]), Cebus albifrons cesarae Hershkovitz, 1949 (considered a synonym of C. a. versicolor Pucheran, 1845, by Groves [2001]), Cebus albifrons versicolor Pucheran, 1845 (with C. a. leucocephalus Gray 1865 and C. a. pleei Hershkovitz, 1949, as synonyms). 

Recent molecular studies have evidenced that the former C. a. albifrons populations are not sister taxa to other gracile capuchin populations in northern South America (C. capucinus, C. versicolor, C. malitiosus, C. leucocephalus or C. brunneus) (Boubli et al. 2012; Lynch Alfaro et al. 2012). Thus, independent of their morphological similarities to these geographically disjunct populations, C. albifrons currently refers to gracile capuchins living in the upper Amazon basin in Southeastern Colombia, southern Venezuela and northwestern Brazil (Mittermeier et al. 2014).  There is some uncertainty whether the range of C. albifrons should be restricted to between the Rio Negro and Rio Branco (Boubli et al. 2012) or should extend south as well from the Rio Negro to the Rio Solimões in western Brazil (Rylands et al. 2014).

Hill (1960) listed three species of bearded saki: Chiropotes chiropotes, C. satanas and C. albinasa [sic]. Hershkovitz (1985) described a new species, utahickae, and classified satanas and utahickae as subspecies of C. chiropotes. Groves (2001, 2005) followed the taxonomy of Hershkovitz (1985). The three subspecies of Chiropotes satanas (satanas, chiropotes and utahicki) are here listed as full species following the recommendation of Silva-Júnior and Figueiredo (2002), Figueiredo et al. (2006), and Silva-Júnior et al.(2013). Bonvicino et al. (2003) resurrected the name Chiropotes israelita (Spix, 1823) for the bearded saki discovered by Boubli (2002) to the west of the Rio Branco, a tributary of the Rio Negro, Amazonas, Brazil. Genetic and pelage differences, notably a greenish brown (olive) dorsum as opposed to light golden brown as is typical of C. chiropotes, distinguish it from the bearded sakis of the Guianas to the east of the Rio Branco. There is however, a possible confusion concerning the correct names. Silva-Júnior and Figueiredo (2002) argued that the form west of the Rio Branco is, correctly Chiropotes chiropotes (Humboldt, 1811), according to its type locality, and the form to the east of the Rio Branco, extending through the states of Pará and Amapá, and into the Guianas (Guyana, Suriname, French Guiana) is C. sagulatus (Traill, 1821) from Demerara (see Silva-Júnior et al. (2013). Doubts still remain, however, concerning Hershkovitz’s interpretation of Humboldt’s type locality of C. chiropotes, which would accordingly alter the nomenclature (J. P. Boubli, pers. comm). With the further research and phylogenetic analysis, both Traill’s sagulatus and Spix’s israelita may be valid species names for different populations of this wide ranging genus. Barnett et al. (2012) proposed the black cuxiú for the common name.

Cebus kaapori was originally described by Queiroz in 1992, as who pointed out its resemblance with Cebus olivaceus. It had been previously recorded from Pará and Maranhão (Goeldi and Hagmann 1906 apud Silva Jr. 2001, Vieira 1957) as Cebus nigrivittatus and overlooked in subsequent assessments of the range of the species. Harada and Ferrari (1996), based on genetic data, argued that Cebus kaapori should be considered as a subspecies of C. olivaceus. However, Cebus kaapori was considered a valid species by Groves (2001, 2005) and Silva Jr. (2001) in regard of morphological evidence. Later on, new molecular evidence (Alfaro et al. 2012a,b) supported the current understanding that it is a valid species, and this is the current prevailing systematic arrangement (Paglia et al. 2012).

The marmosets of the Brazilian Atlantic Forest (penicillata É. Geoffroy, 1812, geoffroyi É. Geoffroy in Humboldt, 1812, aurita É. Geoffroy in Humboldt, 1812 and flaviceps Thomas, 1903) belonged to the jacchus group and were all considered subspecies of Callithrix jacchus (Hershkovitz 1977). Currently all are recognized as full species (Coimbra-Filho 1984; Mittermeier et al. 1988; Marroig et al. 2004, Coimbra-Filho et al. 2006). However, some authors still consider Callithrix genus as belonging to the family Cebidae, subfamily Callitrichinae (Groves 2005).

In the past, the eastern Brazilian marmosets (penicillata É. Geoffroy, 1812, geoffroyi É. Geoffroy in Humboldt, 1812, aurita É. Geoffroy in Humboldt, 1812, and flaviceps Thomas, 1903) of the “jacchus group” were considered to be subspecies of Callithrix jacchus, following Hershkovitz (1977). All are now considered to be full species (Coimbra-Filho 1984; Mittermeier et al. 1988; Marroig et al. 2004; Coimbra-Filho et al. 2006; Rylands et al. 1993, 2008). Here the taxonomy proposed by Rylands (2012) is being followed. The taxonomic history and a discussion of the type locality can be found in Vivo (1991) and Coimbra-Filho et al. (2006).

authority: (M. van Roosmalen, T. van Roosmalen, R.A. Mittermeier & de Fonseca, 1998)
taxonomicNotes: Previously included in the genus Callithrix (see Rylands et al. 2000, 2008). Groves (2001, 2005) lists this species as Callithrix (Callibella) humilis. This marmoset is very distinct, intermediate in size between the Pygmy Marmoset and other Amazonian marmosets. Morphological and genetic studies argued for its placement in a separate genus (Aguiar and Lacher Jr. 2003, van Roosmalen and van Roosmalen 2003). Schneider et al. (2012) transferred it to the genus Mico. Silva et al. (2018) support placing the dwarf marmoset into its own genus, Callibella. We are following their arrangement here.

Hershkovitz (1949) listed five subspecies of the wedge-capped capuchin, C. nigrivittatus Wagner 1848. Neither Silva-Júnior (2001) nor Groves (2001, 2005) considered them to be valid. Their ranges are not well known. Hershkovitz (1949) plotted only their type localities. Bodini and Pérez-Hernández (1987) indicated that C. n. nigrivittatus was the form in the Territorio Federal Amazonas of Venezuela, C. n. apiculatus in the llanos south of the middle and lower Orinoco, east as far as the Río Caroni, and C. n. olivaceus, in the llanos west of the Río Caroni. Genetic material obtained from wedge-capped capuchins with the putative ranges these subspecies in Venezuela by Lynch Alfaro et al. (2010) and Boubli et al. (2010, 2012) indicated that they were all of one taxon, and the oldest name ascribed was olivaceus Schomburgk, 1848. No material for genetic analysis was obtained from the llanos north of the Orinoco, which Bodini and Pérez-Hernández (1987) considered to be a form that, as of then, was undescribed. For the present it is ascribed to C. olivaceus. Of Hershkovitz’s five subspecies only Cebus brunneus Allen, 1914 (Cordillera de la Costa, extreme northern Venezuela), Cebus olivaceus Schomburgk, 1848 (south of the Orinoco in Venezuela), and a specimen from southern Guyana ascribed to Cebus castaneus I. Geoffroy Saint-Hilaire, 1851, on the basis of proximity to its type locality, are considered valid and ‘good’ species.

In 1940, Lönnberg described the subspecies Cebuella pygmaea niveiventris from Lago Ipixuna, south bank of the Rio Solimões, based on its sharply contrasting whitish chest, belly, and inner surface of arms and legs. The ventral surface of C. p. pygmaea is ochraceous. Cruz Lima (1945) and Napier (1976) also recognized and described the two subspecies. Hershkovitz (1977) argued that the colour of the underparts is individually and locally variable and not justifying the subspecific status of niveiventris. However, van Roosmalen and van Roosmalen (1997) recently presented evidence for the validity of the two subspecies based on field observations and captive specimens of C. p. niveiventris, and confirmed its presence in the interfluvium of the Rios Purus and Madeira.

A phylogenetic study by Boubli et al. (2018), which included the mtDNA cytochrome b gene and a reduced representation genome sequencing approach (ddRADseq) for geographically representative samples from the Brazil, showed that the forms pygmaea Spix (from the north of the Solimões-Amazonas) and niveiventris Lönnberg (from the south of the Solimões-Amazonas) were distinct species.

Hill (1960) listed three species of bearded saki: Chiropotes chiropotes, C. satanas and C. albinasa [sic]. Hershkovitz (1985) described a new species, utahickae, and classified satanas and utahickae as subspecies of C. chiropotes. Groves (2001, 2005) followed the taxonomy of Hershkovitz (1985). The three subspecies of Chiropotes satanas (satanas, chiropotes and utahicki) are here listed as full species following the recommendation of Silva-Júnior and Figueiredo (2002), Figueiredo et al. (2006), and Silva-Júnior et al.(2013). Bonvicino et al. (2003) resurrected the name Chiropotes israelita (Spix, 1823) for the bearded saki discovered by Boubli (2002) to the west of the Rio Branco, a tributary of the Rio Negro, Amazonas, Brazil. Genetic and pelage differences, notably a greenish brown (olive) dorsum as opposed to light golden brown as is typical of C. chiropotes, distinguish it from the bearded sakis of the Guianas to the east of the Rio Branco. There is however, a possible confusion concerning the correct names. Silva-Júnior and Figueiredo (2002) argued that the form west of the Rio Branco is, correctly Chiropotes chiropotes (Humboldt, 1811), according to its type locality, and the form to the east of the Rio Branco, extending through the states of Pará and Amapá, and into the Guianas (Guyana, Suriname, French Guiana) is C. sagulatus (Traill, 1821) from Demerara (see Silva-Júnior et al. (2013). Doubts still remain, however, concerning Hershkovitz’s interpretation of Humboldt’s type locality of C. chiropotes, which would accordingly alter the nomenclature (J. P. Boubli, pers. comm). With the further research and phylogenetic analysis, both Traill’s sagulatus and Spix’s israelita may be valid species names for different populations of this wide ranging genus.

Cebus leucocephalus Gray, 1865, Colombia, restricted by P. Hershkovitz in 1949 to El Tambor, Rio Labrija, 25 km north-west of Bucaramanga, Santander, Colombia. Recent molecular study based on mitochondrial markers however, showed that Cebus leucocephalus and C. adustus are not distinct enough to comprise different taxa. Further studies including more samples as well as more genetic markers would be necessary to confirm that these two taxa are synonyms. If confirmed that adustus is the same taxon as leucocephalus, leucocephalus would be the senior synonym. Thus, C. leucocephlus taxonomic status and distribution remains uncertain.

Cebus unicolor was first described by Spix, 1823, for a specimen collected in the Rio Tefé, near its confluence with the Rio Solimões, Amazonas, Brazil. Defler and Hernandez-Camacho (2002) argued that unicolor is a synonym of C. albifrons, a widespread species in the Amazon. A recent study based on new molecular evidence shows that white-fronted capuchins south of Rio Negro, i.e. C. unicolor (Spix 1823) are distinct from C. albifrons found north of Rio Negro (Boubli et al. 2012). Morphological and genetic diversity of white fronted capuchins in the south-central Amazon Basin is yet to be investigated. Monotypic.

Silva Jr (2001, 2002) argued that the tufted capuchins and the untufted capuchins (sensu Hershkovitz 1949, 1955) are so distinct in their morphology that they should be considered separate genera. Cebus Erxleben, 1777 is referable to the untufted group, and Sapajus Kerr, 1792 is the name available for the tufted capuchins. 

Defler (2004) noted that three subspecies had been recorded for Colombia: C. c. capucinus (Linnaeus, 1758), C. c. nigripectus Elliot, 1909; and C. c. curtus Bangs, 1905, of the Pacific Island of Gorgona. They are not recognized as valid by Hershkovitz (1949), Hernández-Camacho and Cooper (1976), nor by Groves (2001, 2005).

The assessment of C. capucinus previously included four subspecies but capucinus is now treated as being limited to Colombia with just two subspecies – C. c. capucinus and the Gorgona Island C. c. curtus. Subspecies imitator is now considered a good species (from Panama) and subspecies limitaneus is now a junior synonym of C. imitator. These changes are based on Molecular genetic studies by Ruiz-García et al. (2012) and Boubli et al. (2012) which validated C. imitator as the Central American form, restricting C. c. capucinus to Colombia, and eliminating limitaneus as a junior synonym of imitator.

Until recently, Central American capuchins were considered to be subspecies of Cebus capucinus; however, recent genetic analyses (Boubli et al. 2012) suggest a phylogenetic division between C. capuchinus from South America and Eastern Panama and the Central American populations with no evidence of division within the latter group.

Cebus olivaceus Schomburgk, 1848, Venezuela, southern foot of Mount Roraima, Bolivar State, elevations 945 m. P. Hershkovitz (1949) listed five forms that he “provisionally recognized” as subspecies of a monotypic weeper capuchin, C. nigrivittatus, named by Wagner in 1848. Although the name nigrivittatus was used for the Guianan Weeper Capuchin through the 1970s, J. G. Robinson pointed out that in 1941 B. von Pusch combined Saimiri and Cebus, resulting in nigrivittatus being a secondary homonym due to the prior description of the squirrel monkey Chrysothrix nigrivittatta by Wagner in 1848 (a junior synonym of Saimiri sciureus). Notwithstanding, the name for the Guianan Weeper Capuchin thus became C. olivaceus. C. P. Groves in 2001 did not consider any of the subspecies valid and concluded that C. olivaceus was monotypic. A phylogenetic analysis of C. olivaceus by J. Boubli and co-workers in 2012 largely confirmed the conclusion of Groves, except for one specimen from Guyana that could be distinguished as a distinct taxon; it diverged from the C. olivaceus app. 700,000 years ago. This was ascribed to C. castaneus as listed by Hershkovitz in 1949. Its type locality is Cayenne, French Guiana, and it was considered to be the weeper capuchin of Guyana by G. Tate in 1939.

Scotonycteris zenkeri was considered to be widely distributed from Liberia in the west to the Democratic Republic of Congo in central Africa until the taxonomy of the tribe Scotonycterini was resolved (Hassanin et al. 2015) and S. zenkeri is now considered restricted to southwestern Cameroon and southeastern Nigeria.

The most detailed taxonomic treatment for this species remains that of Fooden (1963) who placed it in the genus Lagothrix. However, as a result of his comparative studies of cranial morphology in the atelines, Groves (2001, 2005) and Paredes (2003) concluded that the Peruvian Yellow-tailed Woolly Monkey should properly be considered a monotypic genus, Oreonax Thomas, 1927, quite separate from the woolly monkeys. More recent genetic studies by Di Fiore et al. (2014) and Ruiz Garcia et al. (2014) provide support for its position within the genus Lagothrix.

The taxonomy of Lagothrix is based on Fooden (1963), although Groves (2001, 2005) classified cana (É. Geoffroy Saint-Hilaire, 1812), lugens Elliot, 1907, and poeppigii Schinz, 1844 as full species rather than subspecies of L. lagothricha (Humboldt, 1812). Botero and Stephenson (2014), Defler (2014) and Ruiz-García et al. (2014) argued that there is only recent (Pleistocene) divergence, overlap and interbreeding between neighbouring taxa, and considerable phenotypic plasticity amongst them, arguing in favour of the classification of Fooden (1963) that has just one species with four subspecies. Groves (2001. 2005) also recognized the form tschudii Pucheran, 1857. Cruz Lima (1945) and gave the type locality as Peru. Fooden (1963) considered it a junior synonym of L. lagotricha cana. The name based on a Peruvian specimen was referred to as L. humboldtii by I. Geoffroy Saint-Hilaire, 1851; report of a specimen “indiqué comme originaire de Bolivie”. Groves (2001, 2005) recognized Lagothrix cana tschudii as a valid subspecies, but the type locality is not known (Bolivia or Peru). He indicated that two forms with more precise type localities were junior synonyms: 1) Alouatta nigra J. A. Allen, 1900 – Peru, Puno, “Juliaca” [= Inca mines], 5,000 ft, Allen, 1901, field notes; 2) Lagothrix thomasi Elliot, 1909, Peru: Cuzco, Rio Comberciato, Callanga, 1,500 m. BM 98.11.6.2. Both are localities in the southeast of Peru.

The taxonomy of Leontocebus fuscicollis is based on Hershkovitz (1977; see also Cheverud and Moore 1990). Considering their biogeography, morphology, behaviour, ecology, and phylogeny, Rylands et al. (2016) placed Hershkovitz’s (1977) white-mouthed, or nigricollis, group of tamarins (the saddleback and black-mantled tamarins), formerly in the genus Saguinus, into a separate genus: Leontocebus Wagner, 1839.

The nigricollis group of Hershkovitz (1977) included two species, Saguinus nigricollis and Saguinus fuscicollis. A genetic analysis (mitochondrial cytochrome b and hypervariable region 1 of the D-loop) by Matauschek (2010; Matauschek et al., 2011) showed that this group was paraphyletic, and as such required a re-assessment of the taxonomic status of the component species and subspecies (sensu Hershkovitz, 1977). Matauschek et al. (2011) identified four clades with the following compositions: 1) S. f. illigeri, S. f. leucogenys (north of the Río Pachitea); 2) S. f. fuscicollis, S. f. leucogenys (south of the Río Pachitea), S. f. weddelli, S. f. melanoleucus, S. f. nigrifrons; 3) S. n. nigricollis, S. n. graellsi; and 4) S. tripartitus, S. f. lagonotus.

 

For S. fuscicollis sensu Hershkovitz (1977), Matauschek et al. (2011) concluded that the subspecies lagonotus, tripartitus, nigrifrons, weddelli and fuscicollis are morphologically distinct and well-defined taxa and recommended they be given species’ status. The same is true for nigricollis, but with graellsi as a subspecies. They recommended that melanoleucus, although genetically very close to weddelli, should continue to be considered valid because of its distinct coat color, but as a subspecies of weddelli along with the form crandalli. The northern populations of leucogenys and illigeri could be considered distinct species, but each with modified geographic distributions. Either the northern or the southern populations of leucogenys (sensu Hershkovitz, 1977) would require a new definition and name. The central Amazonian forms avilapiresi, cruzlimai, primitivus, and mura were not included in the analysis of Matauschek et al. but are attributed to the fuscicollis, weddelli, melanoleucus, nigrifons clade, all except for cruzlimai, as subspecies of fuscicollis. Saguinus n. hernandezi and S. fuscus were not included in the analysis of Matauschek et al. but are here attributed to the S. nigricollis clade, the former as a subspecies but the latter as a species (following Cropp et al., 1999). Sampaio et al. (2015) discovered the provenance of cruzlimai and considered it to be a species.

 

Peres et al. (1996) concluded that Saguinus fuscicollis acrensis Carvalho, 1957 listed by Hershkovitz (1977) from the upper Rio Juruá is not a valid taxon but a hybrid S. f. fuscicollis × S. f. melanoleucus.

 

The forms melanoleucus and crandalli of Hershkovitz (1977) were listed as subspecies of S. melanoleucus by Coimbra-Filho (1990) and Groves (2001, 2005). Both are now considered subspecies of weddelli. The form crandalli is of unknown provenance (Hershkovitz, 1977), but may also be a hybrid.

The Saguinus nigricollis group of Hershkovitz (1977; see also Cheverud and Moore, 1990) included two species, Saguinus nigricollis and Saguinus fuscicollis. A genetic analysis (mitochondrial cytochrome b and hypervariable region 1 of the D-loop) by Matauschek et al. (2011) showed that this group was paraphyletic, and as such required a re-assessment of the taxonomic status of the component species and subspecies (sensu Hershkovitz, 1977, 1982). Matauschek et al. (2011) identified four clades with the following compositions: 1) S. f. illigeri, S. f. leucogenys (north of the Río Pachitea); 2) S. f. fuscicollis, S. f. leucogenys (south of the Río Pachitea), S. f. weddelli, S. melanoleucus, S. f. nigrifrons; 3) S. n. nigricollis, S. n. graellsi; and 4) S. tripartitus, S. f. lagonotus.

In S. fuscicollis sensu Hershkovitz (1977), Matauschek et al. (2011) concluded that lagonotus, tripartitus, nigrifrons, weddelli and fuscicollis are morphologically distinct and well-defined taxa and recommended they be given species’ status. The same is true for nigricollis, but with graellsi as a subspecies. They recommended that melanoleucus, although genetically very close to weddelli, be considered a subspecies of S. weddelli because of its distinct coat colour. The central Amazonian forms avilapiresi, cruzlimai, primitivus, and mura were not included in the analysis of Matauschek et al. but may be attributed to the fuscicollis, weddelli, melanoleucus, nigrifons clade pending genetic analyses.

The Saguinus nigricollis or “white-mouthed tamarin” group of Hershkovitz (1977) was given its own genus, Leontocebus Wagner, 1839, by Rylands et al. (2016).

The lion tamarins, Leontopithecus, are listed as separate species following Della Serra (1951), Rosenberger and Coimbra-Filho (1984), Mittermeier et al. (1988), Natori (1989), and Rylands et al. (1993). They have been listed as subspecies of L. rosalia by Coimbra-Filho and Mittermeier (1972, 1973), Hershkovitz (1977), Mittermeier and Coimbra-Filho (1981), Forman et al. (1986) and Seuánez et al. (1988), the latter two publications on the basis of identical chromosome morphologies.

The lion tamarins, Leontopithecus, are listed as separate species following Della Serra (1951), Rosenberger and Coimbra-Filho (1984), Mittermeier et al. (1988), Natori (1989), and Rylands et al. (1993). They have been listed as subspecies of L. rosalia by Coimbra-Filho and Mittermeier (1972, 1973), Hershkovitz (1977), Mittermeier and Coimbra-Filho (1981), Forman et al. (1986) and Seuánez et al. (1988), the latter two publications on the basis of identical chromosome morphologies.

Formerly in the genus Callithrix (Rylands et al. 1993, 2000 & 2008). Groves (2001 & 2005) lists this species as Callithrix (Mico) chrysoleucus. 
M. chrysoleucus is almost completely white, with an unpigmented face and long white ear-tufts. The body is pale gold to whitish, and the tail, fore and hind limbs are golden to orange (Hershkovitz 1977).

Previously in the genus Callithrix (see Rylands et al. 1993, 2000, 2008). Groves (2001, 2005) lists this species as Callithrix (Mico) argentata.

Hershkovitz (1977) believed that Mico emiliae (Thomas, 1920) - type locality, Maloca, upper Rio Curuá, (illustrated by Cruz Lima, 1945) - was a dark form of M. argentatus. Rylands et al. (1993, 2000, 2008) listed M. emiliae as a distinct species.

A. Humboldt is often credited in various ways with the name of this species, but É. Geoffroy Saint-Hilaire (1812) is the rightful authority (Rylands and Mittermeier 2013). Formerly in the genus Callithrix (see Rylands et al. 1993, 2000, 2008). Groves (2001, 2005) lists this species as Callithrix (Mico) humeralifera.

authority: (M. van Roosmalen, T. van Roosmalen, R.A. Mittermeier & Rylands, 2000)
taxonomicNotes: Previously in the genus Callithrix (see Rylands et al. 2000, 2008). Groves (2001, 2005) lists this species as Callithrix (Mico) acariensis.

Formerly in the genus Callithrix (see Rylands et al. 2000, 2008). Groves (2001, 2005) lists this species as Callithrix (Mico) marcai. To date the only work that covers all species of the genus Mico is Garbino (2013), where the phylogeny is based on morphological characters of 21 species recognized for the Callitrichini tribe. In the cladogram presented in this paper, Mico mauesi is more related to Mico humeralifer, as was suspected by Mittermeier et al. (1992) and seen in Schneider et al. (2012). Hershkovitz (1977) separates the taxa of "Amazonian marmosets" into two groups, the "tufted marmosets" and the "untufted marmosets ". In Garbino (2013) this division made by Hershkovitz (1977) is held to be more parsimonious, but makes it clear that it does not correspond to a monophyletic group.

Formerly in the genus Callithrix (see Rylands et al. 1993, 2000, 2008). Groves (2001, 2005) lists this species as Callithrix (Mico) emiliae. 
The reason for the resurrection of this form, considered a junior synonym (a dark form) of Callithrix argentata argentata by Hershkovitz (1977) is effectively by default. Hapale emiliae was first described by Thomas (1920) from the Rio Irirí, southern Pará. It was not recognized by Hershkovitz (1977) who regarded it as a dark form of Callithrix argentata. Vivo (1985, 1991) revalidated this form on the basis of specimens from the state of Rondônia. However, Rylands et al. (1993) indicated that the Rondônia marmosets described by Vivo should be considered a distinct form based on the fact that the species’ distribution and that of the Hapale emiliae Thomas, 1904 from Maloca on the Rio Curuá (see Vivo 1985; Ávila Pires 1986) are disjunct, and separated by M. melanurus. That the Rondônia “emiliae” is distinct from emiliae Thomas, 1904 was confirmed by Sena (1998) and Ferrari et al. (1999), who found M. emiliae to be more similar to M. argentatus than the “emiliae” from Rondônia. These authors argue that the Rio Tapajós separates two distinct, very recent, radiations of Mico. Alperin (1995) argued that Mico nigriceps (Ferrari and Lopes 1992) and “emiliae” from Rondônia belong to the same species. Nevertheless, Ferrari et al. (2010) confirmed the “emiliae” from Rondônia as a new species, namely Mico rondoni. Groves (2001) lists M. emiliae as a valid species.

Mico saterei was described by Silva Júnior and Noronha as Callithrix saterei in 1998 belonging to C. argentata species group within bare-eared and smooth-tailed subgroup. The diagnosis characters included the morphology of external genitalia of both sexes, the unpigmented facial skin and pigmented auricular skin, bright orange coloration in the facial skin and genitalia (in natura), and a mantle strongly contrasting with the dorsum and anterior limbs (Silva Júnior and Noronha 1998).
According to Hershkovitz (1977) classification, the Callithrix genus was subdivided into two species groups, C. jacchus group (Atlantic marmoset), and C. argentata group (Amazonian marmoset). In 2000, Rylands and collaborators, based on phylogenetic studies, suggested the Callithrix genus division, proposing the term Callithrix for species living from Atlantic Forest, Caatinga and Cerrado (savanna-like vegetation) and a revalidation of Mico Lesson, 1840 genus to the Amazonian taxa, reinforcing that it is not a paraphyletic genus (Rylands et al. 2000). Groves (2001, 2005) dealt Mico like subgenus. Finally, the study from Rylands et al. (2000) has largely been accepted and used, inclusive in the taxonomy proposed by Rylands (2012), which is succeeding to this work.
The current taxonomy of the Mico genus harbors 14 recognized species: M. humilis, M. argentatus, M. leucippe, M. emiliae, M. melanurus, M. intermedius, M. rondoni, M. nigriceps, M. marcai, M. acariensis, M. mauesi, M. chrysoleucos, M. saterei, and M. humeralifer (Garbino 2014; Rylands and Mittermeier 2013; Schneider et al. 2012). There are few studies addressing phylogenetical relationships within this genus. The unique work that embraces all species is from Garbino (2013), which is a morphology-based phylogeny using 21 species of the Callitrichini tribe. According to Garbino´s cladogram, Mico saterei is a sister-group of M. intermedius sustained by three morphological synapomorphies. The division of the Amazonian marmosets’ taxon into two groups (“with auricular tufts” and “without auricular tufts” - Hershkovitz 1977), is supported by Garbino (2013), but is recognized that such groups are not monophyletic. Thus, M. chrysoleucos, M. humeralifer, M. mauesi, M. saterei and M. humilis belongs to the “with auricular tussock” group. Molecular evidences remain unclear regarding to phylogenetical relationships of M. saterei. For instance, Sena et al. (2002), based on DNA-mitochondrial markers, indicated that M. mauesi, M. melanurus and M. humeralifer are closer taxa to M. saterei. On the other hand, Schneider et al. (2012), using mitochondrial and four nuclear-regions, suggested that M. saterei is included in a higher group composed by M. mauesi and M. humeralifer. Both works, however, focused the relationships among genera (Callithrix, Callibella, Cebuella and Mico) with few species from Mico genus represented. Further studies are needed for clarifying such phylogenetic relationships.
Formerly in the genus Callithrix (see Rylands et al. 1993, 2000, 2008a, 2008b). Groves (2001, 2005) lists this species as Callithrix (Mico) melanura.

Vivo (1985) was the first to alert the scientific community to this marmoset of the state of Rondônia, Brazil, and provided a detailed description of it. He believed it to be Callithrix emiliae Thomas, 1920, as it is similar in pelage colour, if just a little darker. These Rondônia marmosets should be considered a new species: similar to, but distinct from, both emiliae and melanura, due to their range being widely separated from M. emiliae of southern Pará (Rylands et al. 1993, 2000, 2008, Ferrari et al. 1999). Nagamachi et al. (1996, 1997, 1999) analysed the karyotype, and Sena et al. (2002) carried out a phylogenetic analysis of mitochondrial cytochrome oxidase II gene sequences that substantiated the distinctiveness of Vivo’s Rondônia marmoset.
All Pithecia taxonomy follows Marsh (2014).
All Pithecia taxonomy follows Marsh (2014).
All Pithecia taxonomy follows Marsh (2014).
All Pithecia taxonomy follows Marsh (2014).
All Pithecia taxonomy follows Marsh (2014).
The taxonomy and distribution of Pithecia follows the revision by Marsh (2014).
All Pithecia taxonomy follows Marsh (2014)
All Pithecia taxonomy follows Marsh (2014).
All Pithecia taxonomy follows Marsh (2014).

This species was previously known as Callicebus donacophilus (D'Orbigny, 1836). Taxonomical assessments of titi monkeys have recognized different number of species groups (Hershkovitz 1963, 1988, 1990, Kobayashi 1995, Kobayashi and Langguth 1999, van Roosmalen et al. 2002, Groves 2005). This titi monkey species was the reference for a group of species recognized in all the taxonomical revisions: the donacophilus group. In the new phylogenetic arrangement proposed by Byrne et al. (2016), where Callicebus is currently divided in three genera: Cheracebus, Callicebus, and Plecturocebus; the donacophilus group remains and falls into Plecturocebus, and contains Plecturocebus donacophilus, along with P. modestus, P. oenanthe, P. olallae, P. pallescens and P. urubambensis.

This taxon was initially recognized by Hershkovitz (1990) as the southern subspecies of the Bolivian titi monkey (Callicebus donacophilus pallescens), and was later upgraded to full species status by van Roosmalen et al. (2002). Recent molecular analyses of Titi monkey species (Byrne et al. 2016) propose to split the genus Callicebus into three genera: Cheracebus (the torquatus species group, mostly north of the Amazon), Callicebus (the personatus group, in the Atlantic forest) and Plecturocebus (donacophilus and moloch groups, south of the Amazon to the Chaco of Paraguay).  Plecturocebus pallescens shares the donacophilus group with P. donacophilus, P. modestus, P. oenanthe, P. ollalae and P. urubambensis (Byrne et al. 2016).

Byrne et al. (2016) split the genus Callicebus into three new genera, namely:  Cheracebus (torquatus-group sensu Roosmalen et al. 2002), Plecturocebus (cupreus-, moloch-, donacophilus-groups sensu Roosmalen et al. (2002) and Callicebus (personatus-group, sensu Roosmalen et al. 2002). According to Byrne et al. (2016), Plecturocebus includes 22 species.  The use of the name discolor for the white-fronted titi monkey is disputed (Vermeer et al. 2011).

authority: M. van Roosmalen, T. van Roosmalen & R.A. Mittermeier, 2002
taxonomicNotes: Byrne et al. 2016 have separated the genus Callicebus into three new genera, namely:  Cheracebus (Torquatus group sensu Roosmalen et al. 2002), Plecturocebus (Cupreus + moloch+ donacophilus  groups sensu Roosmalen et al. 2002 and Callicebus (personatus group, sensu Roosmalen et al. 2002). According to Byrne et al. (2016) , Plecturocebus includes 22 species.  The precise type locality of this species is unknown. The holotype is aid to have come from along the middle to upper Rio Purús together with the paratypes.   Byrne et al. (2015) have made P. Dubius as a junior synonim of P. caligatus.  Thus, it is likely that P. Stephennashi is also simply a morphotype of P. caligatus.

Kobayashi and Langguth (1999) and van Roosmalen et al. (2002) recognized five species groups – cupreus, donacophilus, moloch, personatus and torquatus. The moloch group consists of P. brunneus, P. bernhardi, P. baptista, P. cinerascens, P. hoffmannsi, P. moloch, P. miltoni, P. vieirai, and P. grovesi.

Considering molecular, morphological and biogeographic evidence, Byrne et al. (2016) proposed a new genus level taxonomy for the titi monkeys Callicebus: Cheracebus n. gen. in the Orinoco, Negro and upper Amazon basins (torquatus group); Callicebus Thomas, 1903, for the Atlantic Forest titis (personatus group); and Plecturocebus n. gen. for those of the Amazon basin and Chaco region (donacophilus and moloch groups).

Byrne et al. (2016) split the genus Callicebus into three new genera, namely:  Cheracebus (torquatus-group sensu Roosmalen et al. 2002), Plecturocebus (cupreus-, moloch-, donacophilus-groups sensu Roosmalen et al. (2002) and Callicebus (personatus-group, sensu Roosmalen et al. 2002).  According to Byrne et al. (2016), Plecturocebus includes 22 species. This recently described species shows phenotypical similarities to members of the cupreus group, but its distribution borders that of members of the moloch and donacophilus groups in eastern Bolivia (Wallace et al. 2006), and P. toppini in the Pando Department of northern Bolivia (Porter et al. 2013; Wallace et al. 2013). Vermeer and Tello-Alvarado (2015) hypothesize that P. aureipalatii might be a junior synonym of P. toppini, but genetic studies are required to approve this assertion.

Byrne et al. (2016) split the genus Callicebus into three new genera, namely:  Cheracebus (torquatus-group sensu Roosmalen et al. 2002), Plecturocebus (cupreus-, moloch-, donacophilus-groups sensu Roosmalen et al. (2002) and Callicebus (personatus-group, sensu Roosmalen et al. 2002). According to Byrne et al. (2016), Plecturocebus includes 22 species.

Hershkovitz (1990) considered three subspecies: Callicebus cupreus cupreus, Callicebus cupreus discolor and Callicebus cupreus ornatus and placed them in the moloch group of titi monkeys. Groves (2001) considered C. cupreus to be monotypic. Byrne et al. (2016) split the genus Callicebus into three new genera, namely:  Cheracebus (torquatus-group sensu Roosmalen et al. 2002), Plecturocebus (cupreus-, moloch-, donacophilus-groups sensu Roosmalen et al. (2002) and Callicebus (personatus-group, sensu Roosmalen et al. 2002). According to Byrne et al. (2016), Plecturocebus includes 22 species.
Taxonomy follows Hershkovitz (1977). See also Groves (2001, 2005). Defler (2004) pointed out that two subspecies may exist as mentioned by Hernández-Camacho and Cooper (1976).

Hershkovitz (1977) considered Saguinus geoffroyi to be a subspecies of S. oedipus. Comparative morphological studies by Hanihara and Natori (1987), Moore and Cheverud (1992) and Skinner (1991) argued for them being separate species. Eisenberg (1989), Rylands (1993), Hernández-Camacho and Cooper (1976), Mittermeier and Coimbra-Filho (1981), Hernández-Camacho and Defler (1989), Mittermeier et al. (1988), Rylands et al. (1993), Groves (1993, 2001, 2005), Mast et al. (1993) and Defler (1994) all list S. geoffroyi and S. oedipus as separate species.

Hershkovitz (1977) considered Saguinus bicolor to have three subspecies: the nominate, S. b. ochraceus and S. b. martinsi. Groves (2001, 2005) and Rylands et al. (1993, 2000) listed the forms ochraceus and martinsi as subspecies of S. martinsi.

Hershkovitz (1977) considered Saguinus geoffroyi to be a subspecies of S. oedipus. Comparative morphological studies by Hanihara and Natori (1987), Moore and Cheverud (1992) and Skinner (1991) argued them being separate species. Eisenberg (1989), Rylands (1993), Hernández-Camacho and Cooper (1976), Mittermeier and Coimbra-Filho (1981), Hernández-Camacho and Defler (1988, 1991), Mittermeier et al. (1988), Rylands et al. (1993), Groves (2001, 2005), Mast et al. (1993) and Defler (1994) list S. geoffroyi and S. oedipus as separate species. Recent molecular analyses have evidenced that S. geoffroyi and S. oedipus are indeed sister taxa with an estimated divergence time of approximately 1.2 Mya (Buckner et al. 2015).

Leontocebus midas inustus Schwarz, 1951, Tabocal, Amazonas, Brazil. J. Hernández-Camacho and T. Defler (1989) indicated the possibility of two subspecies of S. inustus in Colombia. The taxonomy proposed by Rylands (2012) is followed.

Taxonomy follows Hershkovitz (1977) except for Saguinus labiatus rufiventer (Gray, 1843), which he listed as a junior synonym of S. l. labiatus. He recognized that red-bellied tamarins in the north of their range were distinct but argued that there is probably a clinal variation between populations. However, it was considered a valid subspecies by Groves (2001, 2005), with a provisional distribution (also indicated by Hershkovitz) which extends south from the Rio Solimões between the Rios Madeira and Purus to the Rio Ipixuna, an east bank tributary of the Rio Purus.

Taxonomy follows Hershkovitz (1977), except in the recognition of the two former subspecies (S. m. midas and S. m. niger) as full species (see S. niger). Vallinoto et al. (2006) found that samples from S. midas from the Río Uatumã separated out from those from the Rio Trombetas to the east, about 200km. This indicates a possibility that red-handed and yellow-handed forms of S. midas may be geographical races or distinct species (J. de Sousa e Silva Jr. pers. comm., April 2007).

Taxonomy according to Hershkovitz (1977), but Groves (2001, 2005) found that, while S. m. mystax and S. m. pluto are very similar to each other, the form pileatus is quite distinct, and he listed it as a separate species, S. pileatus. The problem with this is geographic. The three forms have a continuous distribution but pileatus completely separates the geographic ranges of mystax and pluto (see Rylands et al. 1993). The taxonomic status – species or subspecies – remains to be determined in future genetic analyses.

Hershkovitz (1977) considered Saguinus bicolor to have three subspecies: S. b. bicolor, S. b. ochraceus and S. b. martinsi, besides the nominate form. Groves (2001, 2005) and Rylands et al. (2000) listed the forms ochraceus and martinsi, as subspecies of S. martinsi.

Vallinoto et al. (2006) indicated that the Rio Tocantins could act as a barrier to gene flow for Saguinus niger. This was presaged in a molecular genetic analysis by Tagliaro et al. (2005). The form described as Mystax ursulus umbratus Thomas, 1922, from Cametá, Rio Tocantins, Pará, listed by Groves (2001, 2005) as a junior synonym of S. niger, and by Hershkovitz (1977) as a junior synonym of S. midas niger, was indicated as a distinct geographical race or species (J. de Sousa and Silva Jr. pers. comm., cited in Rylands and Mittermeier 2008). Recently, Gregorin and de Vivo (2013) revalidated Saguinus ursula Hoffmannsegg, 1807 as a distinct species. Based on pelage coloration, morphology and molecular data, the authors described the samples from the east bank of the Tocantins River as S. ursulus which are distinct from specimens of S. niger from the west bank. Saguinus niger and S. ursulus are allopatric, and Tocantins River is acting as an effective barrier for gene flow (Gregorin and De Vivo 2013).

Hershkovitz (1977), Eisenberg (1989), Rylands et al. (1993) and Rylands and Mittermeier (2008) listed the Black-handed Tamarin as a subspecies of Saguinus midas. It is now considered as a distinct species (Rylands et al. 1993, 2000; Groves 2001, 2005). Vallinoto et al. (2006) indicated that the Rio Tocantins could act as a barrier to gene flow for Saguinus niger. This was presaged in a molecular genetic analysis by Tagliaro et al. (2005). The form described as Mystax ursulus umbratus Thomas, 1922, from Cametá, Rio Tocantins, Pará, listed by Groves (2001, 2005) as a junior synonym of S. niger, and by Hershkovitz (1977) as a junior synonym of S. midas niger, was indicated as a distinct geographical race or species (J. de Sousa e Silva Jr. pers. comm., cited in Rylands and Mittermeier 2008). Recently, Gregorinand and de Vivo (2013) revalidated Saguinus ursula Hoffmannsegg, 1807 as a distinct species from Saguinus niger. Based on pelage coloration, pattern of morphological divergence and molecular data, the authors described the samples from the east bank of the Tocantins River as S. ursulus which are distinct from specimens of S. niger from the west bank. Saguinus niger and S. ursulus are allopatric, and the Tocantins River is acting as an effective barrier for gene flow (Gregorin and De Vivo 2013).

Saimiri taxonomy follows Hershkovitz (1984) and Groves (2001, 2005). An alternative taxonomy is presented by Thorington Jr. (1985) as follows: S. sciureus sciureus (includes the forms albigena, macrodon, and ustus recognized by Hershkovitz [1984]), S. sciureus boliviensis (includes the forms pluvialis Lönnberg, 1940 and jaburuensis Lönnberg, 1940 recognized by Hershkovitz [1987]), S. sciureus cassiquiarensis, S. sciureus oerstedii (includes the form citrinellus recognized by Hershkovitz [1984]), and S. madeirae (given as a junior synonym of S. ustus by Hershkovitz [1984]). Hernández-Camacho and Defler (1989) recognize S. sciureus caquetensis Allen 1916, given as a junior synonym of S. sciureus macrodon by Hershkovitz (1984). Costello et al. (1993) argued for the recognition of just two species: S. sciureus in South America, and S. oerstedii in Panama and Costa Rica. Boinski and Cropp (1999) using two nuclear genes (IRBP and ZFX) and one mitochondrial (D-Loop) strongly support the Hershkovitz (1984) taxonomy, advocating four distinct species: Saimiri sciureus, S. boliviensis, S. oerstedii and S. ustus.

Hershkovitz (1987, footnote page 22) recognized Saimiri boliviensis jaburuensis Lönnberg, 1940 and S. b. pluvialis Lönnberg, 1940 (given as junior synonyms of S. b. boliviensis in Hershkovitz 1984) as valid subspecies. They are listed by Groves (2001, 2005) as synonyms of S. b. boliviensis.

Saimiri ustus I. Geoffroy, 1843 was described based on material collected by Alexandre Rodrigues Ferreira, deposited initially in the Museu Real d’Ajuda, in Lisbon. During Napoleon’s invasion of Portugal, the specimen was confiscated and taken to the Museum National d’Histoire Naturelle, in Paris, registered as number 476 (532), and later described by I. Geoffroy (Hershkovitz 1984). In his description, Geoffroy (1843) gave the diagnostic characters as bright golden-orange forearms, hands and feet and nearly completely nude ears. The validity of Saimiri ustus was accepted by Allen (1916), Elliot (1913), Cruz Lima (1945), Hill (1960) and Hershkovitz (1984).

Saimiri madeirae Thomas, 1908 was described based on a specimen collected in Humaitá, on the left bank of the Madeira River, Amazonas, Brazil, and deposited in the British Museum of Natural History, registered as number 1908.5.9.6. Thomas (1908) emphasized among the diagnostic characters of the new species the general blue grey colouration of the dorsal area and the yellow of the extremities, confined to the hands and feet. The validity of the name Saimiri madeirae was accepted by Elliot (1913), Allen (1916), Cruz Lima (1945) and Hill (1960), who all considered S. madeirae as a species distinct from S. ustus.

Hershkovitz (1984) considered S. madeirae as a junior synonym of S. ustus. On the other hand, Thorington (1985) validated S. madeirae, as distinct from S. ustus. Following Thorington (1985), S. ustus would be a variant form of S. sciureus, with nearly hairless ears. Costello et al. (1993) invalidated S. ustus, considering it a junior synonym of S. sciureus. Subsequent authors (e.g. Rylands et al. 2000, 2012; Groves 2001, 2005; Rylands and Mittermeier 2009; Lavergne et al. 2010; Chiou et al. 2011; Paglia et al. 2012) follow Hershkovitz (1984), considering S. ustus the valid name for the squirrel monkey species with naked ears.

Saimiri taxonomy follows Hershkovitz (1984) and Groves (2001, 2005). An alternative taxonomy is presented by Thorington Jr. (1985) as follows: S. sciureus sciureus (includes the forms albigena, macrodon, and ustus recognized by Hershkovitz, [1984]), S. sciureus boliviensis (includes the forms pluvialis Lönnberg, 1940 and jaburuensis Lönnberg, 1940 recognized by Hershkovitz [1987]), S. sciureus cassiquiarensis, S. sciureus oerstedii (includes the form citrinellus recognized by Hershkovitz [1984]), and S. madeirae (given as a junior synonym of S. ustus by Hershkovitz [1984]). Hernández-Camacho and Defler (1989) recognize S. sciureus caquetensis Allen 1916, given as a junior synonym of S. sciureus macrodon by Hershkovitz (1984). Costello et al. (1993) argued for the recognition of just two species: S. sciureus in South America, and S. oerstedii in Panama and Costa Rica.  Boinski and Cropp (1999) using two nuclear genes (IRBP and ZFX) and one mitochondrial (D-Loop) strongly support the Hershkovitz (1984) taxonomy, advocating four distinct species: Saimiri sciureus, S. boliviensis, S. oerstedii and S. ustus. Thorington (1985) described the existence of two different pelage colouration phenotypes (S. ustus vs. S. madeirae) based on geography (see Lynch Alfaro et al. 2015). Mitochondrial molecular data suggests S. ustus as currently defined may be paraphyletic (Lynch Alfaro et al. 2015).

Saimiri taxonomy follows Hershkovitz (1984) and Groves (2001, 2005). An alternative taxonomy is presented by Thorington Jr. (1985) as follows: S. sciureus sciureus (includes the forms albigena, macrodon, and ustus recognized by Hershkovitz, [1984]), S. sciureus boliviensis (includes the forms pluvialis Lönnberg, 1940 and jaburuensis Lönnberg, 1940 recognized by Hershkovitz [1987]), S. sciureus cassiquiarensis, S. sciureus oerstedii (includes the form citrinellus recognized by Hershkovitz [1984]), and S. madeirae (given as a junior synonym of S. ustus by Hershkovitz [1984]). Hernández-Camacho and Defler (1989) recognize S. sciureus caquetensis Allen 1916, given as a junior synonym of S. sciureus macrodon by Hershkovitz (1984). Costello et al. (1993) argued for the recognition of just two species: S. sciureus in South America, and S. oerstedii in Panama and Costa Rica. Boinski and Cropp (1999) using two nuclear genes (IRBP and ZFX) and one mitochondrial (D-Loop) strongly support the Hershkovitz (1984) taxonomy, advocating four distinct species: Saimiri sciureus, S. boliviensis, S. oerstedii and S. ustus.

Phylogenetic studies by Lynch Alfaro et al. (2015) and Mercês et al. (2015) resulted in the classification  of Saimiri sciureus as a monotypic species, restricted to the northeastern Amazon on the Guiana Shield extending in Brazil, north of the Amazon into French Guiana, Suriname and Guyana.

The description of Saimiri sciurea collinsi Osgood, 1916 was based on a specimen that belonged to a series of four collected by Emília Snethlage, an ornithologist and at the time the Director of the Museu Paraense Emílio Goeldi (MPEG).  The holotype was depoited in the Field Museum of Natural History (specimen number 19534). In the original description, Osgood (1916) omitted the other three specimens from the same series that remained in the mammal collection at MPEG (MPEG 1378, 1379, 1380). The type locality is Fazenda Teso, Soure municipality, Marajó Island, Pará, Brazil. Cruz Lima (1945), Cabrera (1958) and Hill (1960) reiterated the validity of the taxon as a subspecies of S. sciureus. However, Hershkovitz (1984) considered S. s. collinsi a junior synonym of S. s. sciureus, and this designation was followed by most subsequent authors (e.g., Thorington 1985, Boinski & Cropp 1999, Rylands et al. 2000, Groves 2001, 2005, Rylands & Mittermeier 2009). Despite having observed morphological diferences between specimens from the two banks of the Amazon River, Thorington (1985) interpreted these differences as geographic variation. While Costello et al. (1993) included S. collinsi representatives in their samples, they did not mention the name published by Osgood. In fact, Costello et al. (1993) considered all the names that had been applied to different forms of South American Saimiri to be junior synonyms of Saimiri sciureus. Despite the large differences among the taxonomic arrangements of Hershkovitz (1984), Thorington (1985) and Costello et al. (1993), there was consensus (see also Hill 1960, Boinski & Cropp 1999) in recognizing the populations in all of the eastern Amazon as belonging to a single terminal taxon. More recently, Pinheiro (2003) observed, using mitochondrial genetic analysis of the D-loop region, that the samples coming from the two sides of the Amazon River were presenting genetic differentiation of a similar magnitude as that observed across other taxa within Saimiri. Pinheiro (2003) proposed that the forms north and south of the eastern Amazon River were distinct taxa but did not verify the available names for these taxa. Lavergne et al. (2010) found similar results and proposed the revalidation of Saimiri collinsi Osgood, 1916 as a species, more closely related to Saimiri ustus than to Saimiri sciureus (= S. s. sciureus, also elevated to the level of species). Chiou et al. (2011) replicated the results of Lavergne et al. (2010) with a larger data set. The taxonomic recommendations of Lavergne et al. (2010) and Chiou et al. (2011) were followed by Paglia et al. (2012). Using a larger dataset and an interdisciplinary framework, Mercês et al. (2015) corroborated the results of Lavergne et al. (2010) and updated our knowledge of the geographic distribution of S. collinsi.

The forms macrodon and cassiquiarensis were considered to be subspecies of S. sciureus by Hill (1960), Hershkovitz (1984) and Groves (2001, 2005). Lavergne et al. (2010; see also Carretero-Pinzón et al., 2009) considered them to be full species following a molecular genetic study of the MtDNA cytochrome b gene. The Colombian endemic albigena was considered a junior synonym of S. s. caquetensis J. A. Allen, 1916, by Hill (1960).
